What did you fact-check?: A video in which the man introduces and dubs another video from an interview with Stefano Montanari in the Byoblu video blog. Montanari calls himself a “nanopathologist” and claims that masks cause us to inhale the carbon dioxide that we expelled by breathing. This supposedly produces hypercapnia (excess carbon dioxide).
Explanation: Wearing a mask does not cause hypoxia or hypercapnia in healthy people, so it is not the origin of diseases such as cancer.

What did you fact-check?: An image claims that chroma screen panels are being used to make up coronavirus deaths.
Explanation: The image has been manipulated. The real one is a video frame published by Atlas news Agency last April in the cementery of Vila Formosa, Brazil.

What did you fact-check?: A video refers to a supposed “NASA anticovid necklace”, a device that theoretically ionizes the air around the head, disinfecting it.
Explanation: There is no evidence that this device serves as protection against COVID-19. Air ionization is used in some environments to improve its quality, but there is no evidence that this collar can disinfect the air of SARS-CoV-2, something that the same companies that distribute it deny, and therefore replace the protection of the mask.

What did you fact-check?: WHO said coronavirus is losing potency.
Explanation: World Health Organization (WHO) didn’t say coronavirus is losing potency. The viral post was attributed to World Health Organization (WHO) but is fake.

What did you fact-check?: A picture of the Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte eating pizza in a crowded space where no one is respecting social distancing measures or wearing protective masks. The picture would have been taken during the Stati generali conference, which took place in Rome in June 2020.
Explanation: The picture is real but it was taken in May 2019. It is not related with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Two photos which show human throats have been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts warning about the seriousness of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
Explanation: The photos have been shared in a misleading context; both images have circulated online before the COVID-19 pandemic; health experts have clarified that only a small percentage of COVID-19 patients are likely to develop the most severe symptoms.

What did you fact-check?: Samsung is giving free phones to students during coronavirus pandemic for online studies.
Explanation: No, Samsung is not offering free phones to students during coronavirus pandemic. The viral post is fake. Samsung has also asked to beware of such phishing scams.

What did you fact-check?: Quarantine is a special operation to create a concentration camp in Ukraine.
Explanation: Restrictive measures are introduced to slow down the spread of the pandemic, not to create a concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: A scientific study shows that cannabis is more effective at preventing and treating COVID-19 than hydroxychloroquine.
Explanation: The World Health Organization recognizes some therapeutic uses of cannabinoids. A recent scientific preprint reported that some cannabis strains might modulate the expression of ACE2, the viral receptor for SARS-CoV-2, in an in vitro study. However, the study does not present data on clinical outcomes in animals or humans (in vivo) during infection, nor does it test whether the cannabis extracts affect the infectivity of SARS-CoV-2. It is thus impossible to know whether these specific cannabis strains could prevent or cure COVID-19 in people. The study also did not compare the effect of cannabis extracts with that of hydroxychloroquine on COVID-19, so it does not provide any evidence for the claim that cannabis works better than hydroxychloroquine.

What did you fact-check?: Information circulating across social media platforms claims that Nigeria’s Federal Government has approved to disburse 30,000 to citizens as Covid-19 lockdown funds.
Explanation: The site lacks credibility for the claims it has made. Besides, requiring users to share its links and provide their bank details makes the site more suspicious and questionable. In sum, its methods make it look like a typical site for fraudsters. The claim is FALSE.

What did you fact-check?: A short portion of an interview given by discredited researcher Judy Mikovits, in which she claims that a vaccine for COVID-19 will be deadly, warns against immunization, and advocates for a five-year moratorium to test all vaccines, has been watched tens of thousands of times on YouTube and Facebook.
Explanation: The claims are false; vaccine candidates go through three phases of clinical trials, are carefully monitored for adverse effects, and multiple doctors told AFP vaccines are safe.

What did you fact-check?: Nurses from hospital Messejana, in Brazil’s Ceará, record a video celebrating the closing of COVID-19 room due to lack of patients
Explanation: Video was recorded in another health facility and does not shows closure of the COVID-19 area. In fact, the same health facility received new patients the very next day.

What did you fact-check?: A video of the doctor linked to the anti-vaccine movement, Chinda Brandolino, on the origin of COVID-19.
Explanation: In the video circulating on Facebook, the doctor disseminates various falsehoods that have already been verified and denied. In his presentation, he maintains that the pandemic is "invented" and that its purpose is to guarantee worldwide control of people. He also claims that there are cures for COVID-19, which is false since there is no effective specific vaccine or treatment for the disease so far.

What did you fact-check?: A video in which the man introduces and dubs another video from an interview with Stefano Montanari in the Byoblu video blog. Montanari calls himself a “nanopathologist” and claims that masks cause us to inhale the carbon dioxide that we expelled by breathing. This supposedly produces hypercapnia (excess carbon dioxide).
Explanation: Wearing a mask does not cause hypoxia or hypercapnia in healthy people, so it is not the origin of diseases such as cancer.

What did you fact-check?: An image claims that chroma screen panels are being used to make up coronavirus deaths.
Explanation: The image has been manipulated. The real one is a video frame published by Atlas news Agency last April in the cementery of Vila Formosa, Brazil.

What did you fact-check?: A “face mask exempt card” allows you to cite the ADA and not wear a mask.
Explanation: The Justice Department has debunked the claim. The Freedom to Breathe Agency isn’t a real federal agency. The Americans with Disabilities Act, a federal civil rights law that prohibits discrimination based on disability, does not specifically say anything about face masks. While it’s true that businesses are not allowed to ask customers about their disabilities, and there may be some exceptions to the law, governments have broad authority to issue health mandates during a pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates said that the COVID-19 vaccine will permanently change your DNA.
Explanation: The new RNA and DNA vaccine candidates are experimental  but in no way capable of modifying human genetic material.

What did you fact-check?: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted, “It’s vital that Governors maintain restrictions on businesses until after the November Elections because economic recovery will help Trump be re-elected. A few business closures or job losses is a small price to pay to be free from his presidency. #KeepUsClosed.”
Explanation: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez didn’t tweet this.

What did you fact-check?: Doctor says on video that prolonged use of masks acidifies the blood.
Explanation: The process, called hypercapnia, actually occurs when a large amount of CO₂ is inhaled, but, according to the Brazilian Ministry of Health and a specialist who talked to Aos Fatos, this wouldn't happen with the masks recommended today, as they have pores that allow gas exchange in breathing.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook post which would list the ingredients for the Covid-19 vaccine.
Explanation: At the moment there is no vaccine against COVID-19. The list of ingredients is false.

What did you fact-check?: A Japanese professor said that the coronavirus was fabricated in China.
Explanation: Tasuku Honjo has not made such a statement.

What did you fact-check?: COVID19 dead patients are dropped from a plane in Mexico.
Explanation: The video is from a parachuting video in 2018 long before the COVID-19 pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: “Break the quarantine and this will be our future. Then don’t cry. (Photo from Ecuador) ”, says a photograph that shows piles of human bodies on the ground.
Explanation: The scene captured in the photograph happened in 2015, after a human stampede in Mina, Saudi Arabia. It has nothing to do with COVID-19 or Ecuador.

What did you fact-check?: Social media posts shared thousands of times in the United States contain multiple false or misleading claims about face masks used to stop the spread of COVID-19,
Explanation: The claims are misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is a global fraud, and lockdown is genocide.
Explanation: The coronavirus is real, and lockdown measures help to curb the spread of the pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: In the Philippines, the Office of the Vice President (OVP) donated spoiled food to frontliners at Diliman Doctors Hospital in Quezon City.
Explanation: The Diliman Doctors Hospital released a statement on Tuesday, June 23, denying the rumors. Vice President Leni Robredo also said the incident “never happened.”

What did you fact-check?: Video shows Elisa Carrió, former deputy of the Nation for the Autonomous City of Buenos Aires, calling for a march for freedom.
Explanation: The filmed message that went viral now was actually shared by the former national deputy on October 13, 2019 on Twitter, to call the "Million March", prior to the presidential elections.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of a list of purported symptoms and treatments for the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19, has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. The purported remedies include a daily dose of vitamins; exposure to sunlight; and a diet of alkaline foods.
Explanation: The claims are false; as of June 29, 2020, experts say there is no known cure for COVID-19; AFP has previously debunked hoax claims about the purported coronavirus symptoms and remedies.

What did you fact-check?: Two photos which show human throats have been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts warning about the seriousness of the novel coronavirus, which causes the disease COVID-19.
Explanation: The photos have been shared in a misleading context; both images have circulated online before the COVID-19 pandemic; health experts have clarified that only a small percentage of COVID-19 patients are likely to develop the most severe symptoms.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is the most massive scam and is a robbery of Ukrainians.
Explanation: SARS-CoV-2 is not a scam. The virus has a natural origin. To fight the epidemics, the government has allocated a lot of money, although it is a necessary measure.

What did you fact-check?: Despite the crisis the German government is taking two months of holidays.
Explanation: There is the usual summer break in parliamentary meetings, but in emergency the parliament will still gather. Not all members of parliament or government are on holidays, they are still working.

What did you fact-check?: Samsung is giving free phones to students during coronavirus pandemic for online studies.
Explanation: No, Samsung is not offering free phones to students during coronavirus pandemic. The viral post is fake. Samsung has also asked to beware of such phishing scams.

What did you fact-check?: Quarantine is a special operation to create a concentration camp in Ukraine.
Explanation: Restrictive measures are introduced to slow down the spread of the pandemic, not to create a concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing a protest by doctors from La Rioja against Alberto Fernández, president of Argentina.
Explanation: The original video was recorded in Belgium, during a protest by hospital health personnel against that country's prime minister.

What did you fact-check?: Fighting COVID-19, the authorities have banned everything favorable to health.
Explanation: The imposed restrictive measures do not violate people's right to health.

What did you fact-check?: A picture which would show a mother and her premature baby in a hospital, both infected with Covid-19.
Explanation: The picture is real, but it was taken in the UK in 2018. It has nothing to do with the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates, who is supporting COVID-19 vaccine research, visited in New Zealand during May.
Explanation: The Gates Foundation said Mr Gates has not been in New Zealand in 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Iván Duque Márquez, president of Colombia, compares COVID-19 figures with other countries without due context.
Explanation: In his television program on managing the pandemic in Colombia, the president presents charts that ignore the differences between countries and omit some that are better.

What did you fact-check?: “Joe Biden and the Democrats want to prosecute Americans for going to church, but not for burning a church.”
Explanation: We found no statements from Joe Biden or other leading Democrats suggesting that they want to prosecute churchgoers, but not people who set churches on fire. Biden and other Democrats have spoken out against the violence and destruction that took place at some Black Lives Matter protests.

What did you fact-check?: Thyroce lab in Thane, India is sealed over false positive covid-19 testing.
Explanation: This lab was not shut down over false positiveCOVID-19testing.

What did you fact-check?: Tunisia announces in the coming hours that its sea, air and land borders will be closed again to counter Covid-19.
Explanation: Misbar verified the news and found it to be false, as neither the Tunisian Ministry of Transport nor the Presidency of the government announced the possibility of closing the borders until next July.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook post names several claims about the name “COVID-19” including that is an acronym for ‘See a Sheep Surrender’.
Explanation: The name “COVID-19” is an acronym for coronavirus disease 2019 as announced by the World Health Organization. The post’s claims that Ovid is Latin for sheep and the letter C means to “see” are also false.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook post which would list the ingredients for the Covid-19 vaccine.
Explanation: At the moment there is no vaccine against COVID-19. The list of ingredients is false.

What did you fact-check?: Alberto Fernández (President of Argentina), on the increase in cases in Buenos Aires: “They wanted to go running, go running. This is the consequence.”
Explanation: The President related the growth of coronavirus cases in the Autonomous City of Buenos Aires to the relaxation of the quarantine for runners ordered by the Buenos Aires Government. However, according to the numbers of the City and the Province of Buenos Aires -where in the 40 municipalities of the AMBA it is not allowed to go running-, there is no correlation between flexibility and the increase in cases. Scientific studies enable the option of going for a run but, at the same time, recommend maintaining social distance. The same is maintained by the experts who advise Fernández.

What did you fact-check?: Biomagnetism cures coronavirus.
Explanation: Biomagnetism is an alternative therapy that uses magnets to create static magnetic fields and supposedly modify the magnetic fields of the body itself, thus relieving pain or healing diseases. There is no hard scientific evidence to back it up.

What did you fact-check?: French President Emmanuel Macron exempts the French from rent, and electricity, water and gas bills, to tackle the coronavirus pandemic crisis.
Explanation: Misbar has verified the news which turned out to be misleading. The economic measures announced by the French President on March 16, when the country entered the stage of quarantine restrictions, did not include any exemption from paying bills, but it is about postponing their payment. Also, this delay is not for individuals or families, but rather for smaller companies.

What did you fact-check?: Salty and sour foods cause the “body of the COVID-19 virus” to explode and dissolve.
Explanation: “Consuming fruit juices or gargling with warm water and salt does not protect or kill COVID-19,” the World Health Organization Philippines told VERA Files.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates, who is supporting COVID-19 vaccine research, visited in New Zealand during May.
Explanation: The Gates Foundation said Mr Gates has not been in New Zealand in 2020.

What did you fact-check?: A picture from Beirut, the capital of Lebanon in 1918, as if history repeats itself during the days of the spread of the Spanish flu.
Explanation: Misbar checked the circulating image and found the claim misleading, because the original image shows the latest fashion trends of women for the year 1913, that is, taken before the spread of the Spanish flu that broke out in 1918-1919.

What did you fact-check?: A German doctor revealed a global terrorism conspiracy that employed the COVID-19 pandemic as a tool.
Explanation: Other than a few accurate remarks on the video in question, the speech is a collection of distortions both of statistics and scientific research.

What did you fact-check?: An article stating that Italian authorities knew about a promising drug that could cure Covid-19, but they ignored it.
Explanation: The drug (dexamethasone) was known, but it was not reccomended by the WHO for COVID-19 patients. The WHO changed its position on June 16, after a study carried out by Oxford University proved that dexamethasone can actually have a positive effect on patients.

What did you fact-check?: WHO says Coronavac, vaccine produced by Sinovac Biotech, hasn’t been tested anywhere in the world before Brazil.
Explanation: The vaccine has already undergone two phases of testing and was administered to 744 Chinese people.

What did you fact-check?: Iván Duque Márquez, president of Colombia, compares COVID-19 figures with other countries without due context.
Explanation: In his television program on managing the pandemic in Colombia, the president presents charts that ignore the differences between countries and omit some that are better.

What did you fact-check?: Donald Trump said Brazil is the only country in which the Supreme Court is hampering the national government’s ability to deal with COVID-19. Also, he criticized Brazilian state governors.
Explanation: Trump did not mention in any occasion the Brazilian Supreme Court or governors, the entire quote is a complete fabrication.

What did you fact-check?: Photos claimed to show 1,200 people buried in Italy.
Explanation: The images were not taken in Italy but in Sri Lanka and were unrelated to the pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing a light show at the Eiffel Tower in Paris is shared with messages indicating that it is a tribute to the victims of COVID-19.
Explanation: It is a hoax. The video shows the celebration of the 130th anniversary of the Parisian monument in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: João Doria, governor of São Paulo, said CoronaVac, the Chinese vaccine that will be tested in Brazil, will be tested only on elderly people, who will receive 1.5 thousand reais (around 250 American dollars).
Explanation: Doria never said that. The eligibility criteria for volunteers is not decided by state governors, but by the company and their partners in Brazil, Instituto Butantan. These criteria have not been fixed yet. Paying medical research subjects is illegal in Brazil.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming seawater with lemon prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Explanation: Lemon seawater does not block the virus and does not prevent COVID-19 and experts warn of the risks that this practice could bring.

What did you fact-check?: The title of an article suggests the low-cost steroid dexamethasone will heal anybody with COVID-19.
Explanation: The drug was found to be effective only on critically-ill COVID-19 patients that require ventilators and supplemental oxygen. There was no observed benefit on patients who did not require respiratory support.

What did you fact-check?: EU Commission president Ursula von der Leyen proposed for workers to do without their salary in solidarity with the economy.
Explanation: Ursula von der Leyen never made such a statement.

What did you fact-check?: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) says masks don’t work and violate OSHA oxygen levels.
Explanation: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) encourages workers to use face masks or cloth face coverings at work, in accordance with recommendations by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for reducing community transmission of COVID-19. At the moment, the use of face masks or coverings are not mandated by OSHA, but left to the employer’s discretion. Cloth face coverings are generally safe to use and do not lead to oxygen deficiency, since gas molecules like oxygen and carbon dioxide are much smaller than the pores in fabric and pass through the covering easily. By blocking much larger respiratory droplets, which carry the virus, face masks and coverings help to protect others in the community and limit COVID-19 spread.

What did you fact-check?: CoronaVac, a vaccine that is being developed in China and will be tested in Brazil, was only tested on monkeys.
Explanation: The first and second phases of clinical trials are undergoing in China, with human subjects.

What did you fact-check?: False positive tests results are responsible for big outbreaks in slaughterhouses, as the PCR test reacts to animal coronaviruses (cross-reaction).
Explanation: PCR tests can't show positive results for animal coronaviruses of cows, pigs or chicken.

What did you fact-check?: While the world was worried with COVID-19, Chinese companies were able to purchase Volvo, Pirelli, Thomas Cook and part of Mercedes Benz.
Explanation: All these companies are partly owned by Chinese corporations, in some cases controlled, but all these deals went through before COVID-19 was discovered.

What did you fact-check?: The cure for coronavirus: ginger, lemon, onion and garlic.
Explanation: These natural ingredients do not cure the virus.

What did you fact-check?: A German doctor revealed a global terrorism conspiracy that employed the COVID-19 pandemic as a tool.
Explanation: Other than a few accurate remarks on the video in question, the speech is a collection of distortions both of statistics and scientific research.

What did you fact-check?: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) says masks don’t work and violate OSHA oxygen levels.
Explanation: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) encourages workers to use face masks or cloth face coverings at work, in accordance with recommendations by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for reducing community transmission of COVID-19. At the moment, the use of face masks or coverings are not mandated by OSHA, but left to the employer’s discretion. Cloth face coverings are generally safe to use and do not lead to oxygen deficiency, since gas molecules like oxygen and carbon dioxide are much smaller than the pores in fabric and pass through the covering easily. By blocking much larger respiratory droplets, which carry the virus, face masks and coverings help to protect others in the community and limit COVID-19 spread.

What did you fact-check?: Don’t buy fish in Egypt because it contains a new virus called SARS-COV-2.
Explanation: There is no evidence that fish can transmit COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A viral image of a doctor who died from treating patients with coronavirus at the Llano de Corrientes Hospital, Argentina.
Explanation: A post circulates that mourns the death of "AnibalAnsalas" (sic) for caring for people with COVID-19 but the image of the professional corresponds to a Spanish porn actor.

What did you fact-check?: A picture which would show Vicenza football team supporters partying in the street after the team’s promotion, during the Covid-19 emergency in Italy.
Explanation: The picutre is real but it was taken in August 2019. It has nothing to do with the COVID-19 pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: Nurse says Brazilian states and municipalities earn federal funding for every death recorded for COVID-19.
Explanation: The extra resource for combating the pandemic provided by the brazilian Ministry of Health varies according to the size of the population and the complexity of the service provided in the health units, not by the volume of deaths in the region.

What did you fact-check?: CoronaVac, a vaccine that is being developed in China and will be tested in Brazil, is being funded by Bill Gates.
Explanation: CoronaVac and INO-4800, the one being funded by Gates, are different vaccines, being developed by different companies in different countries, with different technologies.

What did you fact-check?: Few people have died of the new coronavirus, so one should not be afraid of it.
Explanation: It is wrong to compare deaths for various causes.

What did you fact-check?: Top Georgian health official Gamkrelidze said there will not be a second wave of the coronavirus.
Explanation: Gamkrelidze hasn't made such a statement. He has not ruled out the possibility of the second wave.

What did you fact-check?: A picture from Beirut, the capital of Lebanon in 1918, as if history repeats itself during the days of the spread of the Spanish flu.
Explanation: Misbar checked the circulating image and found the claim misleading, because the original image shows the latest fashion trends of women for the year 1913, that is, taken before the spread of the Spanish flu that broke out in 1918-1919.

What did you fact-check?: Senegalese doctor says chloroquine is the secret for a very low number of deaths by COVID-19 in Senegal.
Explanation: Senegal uses chloroquine as a treatment for COVID-19. Doctor Mussa Seydi defends the drug, but says it is not the only reason why deaths are such low.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing a light show at the Eiffel Tower in Paris is shared with messages indicating that it is a tribute to the victims of COVID-19.
Explanation: It is a hoax. The video shows the celebration of the 130th anniversary of the Parisian monument in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Few people have died of the new coronavirus, so one should not be afraid of it.
Explanation: It is wrong to compare deaths for various causes.

What did you fact-check?: ‘Laser’ thermometers damage the retina.
Explanation: WhatsApp audios and Facebook videos claim that the laser of the devices can affect the eyes. Ophthalmology experts contradict those versions.

What did you fact-check?: Delhi police released this coronavirus guideline.
Explanation: The viral guideline document is falsely attributed to Delhi police.

What did you fact-check?: Video of patients dancing in a COVID-19 quarantine centre is from Mumbai.
Explanation: Video of patients dancing at COVID-19 quarantine centre is not from Mumbai, but Tripura.

What did you fact-check?: The US government’s Center for Disease Control has officialized the emerging scientific evidence on coronavirus transmission with a rank of circumstances and enviroments by risk of contamination.
Explanation: The Center for Disease Control has not given those instructions.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of Joice Hasselmann, Brazilian federal deputy (representative) who recently was diagnosed with COVID-19, walking on a hospital corridor without a mask. The caption states she is faking the disease.
Explanation: The photo was taken in March 2, 2020, when Hasselmann received a hysterectomy.

What did you fact-check?: President Trump’s claim that he inherited no ventilators from the Obama administration.
Explanation: There were 16,660 ventilators available in the Strategic National Stockpile.

What did you fact-check?: From June 24, Ukraine is going to restore strict lockdown.
Explanation: Tougher lockdown measures may be re-introduced in some regions if necessary.

What did you fact-check?: Gov. Gavin Newsom “has no legal authority” to make wearing face coverings mandatory in California.
Explanation: Gov. Newsom has broad authority under the California Emergency Services Act to issue health mandates during a pandemic. Two constitutional law experts said Newsom does, indeed, have the power to make face coverings mandatory under that act. They said unless face coverings are shown to be ineffective, Newsom’s requirement should hold up against legal challenges. Top public health officials and recent studies say wearing a face covering is an effective measure for reducing the spread of COVID-19 when people gather.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors of a hospital in New Zealand are cheering in this video after they cure the last COVID-19 patient of their country and shut the COVID-19 ward.
Explanation: The video is from a place in Italy's Madonna delle Grazie where doctors cheered after no more COVID-19 cases were registered.

What did you fact-check?: A text by C. S. Lewis, from 1942, talks about a “pandemic of fear”. It says the devil took many souls to hell because they became too attached to their earthly lives, through fear.
Explanation: The text was not written by C. S. Lewis, but by a Christian activist in 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Joice Hasselmann, brazilian federal deputy, appears without a mask in a photo in the hospital even after a positive diagnosis of COVID-19
Explanation: The image was recorded on March 2, when she was recovering from a hysterectomy, surgery for complete removal of the uterus.

What did you fact-check?: 5G antennas are being installed in Popayán, Columbia.
Explanation: A publication on Facebook claims that 5G antennas are being installed in the historic center of the Cauca capital, but this technology has not yet reached Colombia. And no, it is not responsible for COVID-19 either.

What did you fact-check?: A picture of the Egyptian doctor, Mohamed Hashad, carrying an oxygen cylinder in an attempt to save the lives of Covid-19 patients in an isolation hospital in Egypt. He died after contracting coronavirus.
Explanation: Misbar investigated the image and found the allegation to be misleading, because it actually shows an Iraqi technical nurse named Wissam Al-Ghazi.

What did you fact-check?: To be able to manipulate the lockdown measures, Ukraine has classified data on the general mortality rate.
Explanation: The number of confirmed COVID-19 cases provide sufficient grounds for quarantine restrictions.

What did you fact-check?: The federal police found thousands of reais inside the house of Pará state Health secretary. This money was supposed to go to COVID-19-related equipment.
Explanation: The video actually shows a police raid on other police officers accused of drug trafficking. Not related to the health secretary.

What did you fact-check?: Two photos: one, of a swollen amygdala, the other, a healthy one. The caption says the first one is from a COVID-19 patient.
Explanation: The picture is from 1958, from a patient infected with Straptococcus bacteria. Amygdalitis is not a COVID-19 symptom, although it may occur as a result of secondary infection.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type.
Explanation: The post claiming coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Gates Foundation planting microchips during COVID19 swab testing.
Explanation: No, Gates Foundation is not planting microchips during COVID-19 swab testing. This viral post is fake.

What did you fact-check?: An alleged statement from a College of Physicians of Spain in which the population is warned about COVID-19 and what is involved in assisted ventilation, and there is a “call for common sense” in the lack of confinement.
Explanation: There is no evidence that it is from a Spanish College of Physicians. From the General Council of Medical Colleges (CGCOM) there is no evidence that it is a text from any school in Spain. The alleged statement has also reached Latin American countries and a fragment of it has been circulating at least since April.

What did you fact-check?: A picture with a quote attributed to Bill Gates, stating: “The vaccine won’t be safe, but let’s get it out quickly anyway, and worry about the consequences later”
Explanation: Bill Gates never said so. The quote comes from an interview Bill Gates did for BBC Breakfast, that has been distorted and misinterpreted.

What did you fact-check?: “OSHA says masks don’t work” to reduce COVID-19 transmission “and violate OSHA oxygen levels.”
Explanation: No, OSHA does not say that 'masks don’t work' against COVID-19. OSHA recommends that masks be worn to help slow the spread of COVID-19. Masks aren’t a cure to prevent spread of COVID-19, experts say. But they are an effective tool in slowing transmission.

What did you fact-check?: CoronaVac, vaccine that is being developed in China and will be tested in Brazil, was not tested anywhere else in the world.
Explanation: The vaccine is currently being tested in China.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors of a hospital in New Zealand are cheering in this video after they cure the last COVID-19 patient of their country and shut the COVID-19 ward.
Explanation: The video is from a place in Italy's Madonna delle Grazie where doctors cheered after no more COVID-19 cases were registered.

What did you fact-check?: PCR tests also detect common cold viruses.
Explanation: PCR testing is based on the specific genetic information (RNA sequences) of the novel coronavirus and therefore it does not detect genetic information of other coronaviruses that cause ordinary colds. Thus this test only tests positive for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Patricia Bullrich (former Minister of Security in Argentina): “Only 25% of Argentinian companies have come to have some help from the State”.
Who said/posted it?: Patricia Bullrich (presidenta del PRO y ex ministra de Seguridad de Argentina)
Explanation: The former Argentine minister was based on a single program of the national government, subsidized loans at a rate of 24%, which according to the Central Bank were delivered to "a quarter of the MSMEs of Argentina." There are other programs that benefit other companies, such as Work and Production Assistance (ATP). However, no official or private study estimates what percentage of companies received any state aid during the COVID-19 pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: Joice Hasselmann, brazilian federal deputy, appears without a mask in a photo in the hospital even after a positive diagnosis of COVID-19
Explanation: The image was recorded on March 2, when she was recovering from a hysterectomy, surgery for complete removal of the uterus.

What did you fact-check?: SARS-CoV-2 is a “bacterial infection,” not a virus.
Explanation: Several studies and health institutions have confirmed that SARS-CoV-2 is a virus.

What did you fact-check?: CoronaVac, a vaccine that is being developed in China and will be tested in Brazil, is being funded by Bill Gates.
Explanation: CoronaVac and INO-4800, the one being funded by Gates, are different vaccines, being developed by different companies in different countries, with different technologies.

What did you fact-check?: United Nations established the use of a microchip to identify people.
Explanation: The UN has not said anything related to microchips.

What did you fact-check?: A police officer from São Paulo rescued his mother while she was about to be buried alive.
Explanation: The video shows a police officer in Amazonas who invaded a hospital because he thought his mother was about to be buried alive. He watched a disinformative video on WhatsApp about a woman who was, allegedly, put inside a corpse bag while still breathing, and thought it was his mother because they wore the same dress. This particular video has been previously debunked too.

What did you fact-check?: Cardinal Antonio Cañizares, from Spain, has assured that one of the vaccines that is being investigated against COVID-19 is made from cells of aborted fetuses.
Explanation: There are no "aborted fetus cells" used in biomedical research. There are two immortalized cell lines that come from cells removed during the analysis of two fetuses resulting from two medically aborted abortions in 1961 and 1966.

What did you fact-check?: A widely shared video claims to show Brazilian lawmaker Filippe Poubel erupt in anger as he breaks into a field hospital that had claimed to have 5,000 novel coronavirus patients and finds it empty.
Explanation: In reality, the clip depicts the politician expressing his displeasure over a delay in opening a new COVID-19 hospital.

What did you fact-check?: A picture with a quote attributed to Bill Gates, stating: “The vaccine won’t be safe, but let’s get it out quickly anyway, and worry about the consequences later”
Explanation: Bill Gates never said so. The quote comes from an interview Bill Gates did for BBC Breakfast, that has been distorted and misinterpreted.

What did you fact-check?: This video of the Eiffel Tower shows a tribute to victims of Covid-19.
Explanation: The light show of the Eiffel Tower was held for its 130th anniversary in 2019, it is not a tribute to victims of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Mixing Suavitel, vinegar, Clorox and water helps neutralize the coronavirus.
Explanation: The recipe, although it does inactivate SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19, thanks to the virucidal activity of only one of its components, can be dangerous to health. Clorox contains bleach.

What did you fact-check?: Angela Merkel met the leaders of the German states without security distance or masks.
Explanation: The photo is old. At the meeting, Merkel didn't wear a mask - but other politicians did, and they kept distance.

What did you fact-check?: Photo shows cremation ovens being transferred to Yopal, Colombia.
Explanation: The barrels in the photo resemble liquid storage tanks, while the ovens, like crematoriums, are square-shaped.

What did you fact-check?: A picture stating that the governing parties in Italy voted against a proposal, supported by the League and other right-wing parties, to offer an economic reward to nurses and doctors who fought against the Covid-19 epidemic
Explanation: The Italian government has already approved an economic bonus for nurses and doctors. The League's proposal - which was actually rejected - basically wanted to add another bonus on top of the already existing one.

What did you fact-check?: An alleged statement from a College of Physicians of Spain in which the population is warned about COVID-19 and what is involved in assisted ventilation, and there is a “call for common sense” in the lack of confinement.
Explanation: There is no evidence that it is from a Spanish College of Physicians. From the General Council of Medical Colleges (CGCOM) there is no evidence that it is a text from any school in Spain. The alleged statement has also reached Latin American countries and a fragment of it has been circulating at least since April.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows police seizing money diverted from respirators at the home of the health secretary of the Brazilian city of Belém.
Explanation: The video was recorded during a police operation in the city of Barcarena (in the Brazilian state of Pará) against six military police officers accused of embezzling seized cocaine.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus causing COVID-19 has been existing since 2003.
Explanation: Despite the fact that the article in the newspaper Clarín de Argentina circulating on social networks is authentic, it does not refer to COVID-19. The virus that this press release talks about is the SARS outbreak that emerged between 2002 and 2003.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is an amplified bacteria related to 5g.
Explanation: The coronavirus is not a bacteria and has no relation with 5G.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type.
Explanation: The post claiming coronavirus does not affect people with ‘O+’ blood type is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: A post circulating on Facebook claims the latest research shows the mutation of COVID-19, D614G, makes the disease ten times more infectious.
Explanation: The claim came from American virologist William Haseltine's comment on the research of finding of D614G. The study itself doesn't prove if the mutation makes the COVID-19 more infectious.

What did you fact-check?: This coronavirus has an aversion for heat, humidity and UV rays.
Explanation: While there are certainly papers that support that theory, the WHO warns that "COVID-19 is contagious no matter how much available sunlight or temperature." and there are papers to back it up.  Meanwhile the spread of the disease in hot and humid Southeast Asia also continues unabated.

What did you fact-check?: SARS-CoV-2 mutated and became 10 times more infectious.
Explanation: There is no definition of "Novel Beijing coronavirus-D614G". The D614G is referred to as the name of the mutation in an experiment on COVID-19; not a real mutation detected.

What did you fact-check?: Gargling with warm water and salt cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: Gargling with warm water and salt does not eliminate the COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: “WHO has changed its rules to call the coronavirus situation a pandemic.” – Dr. Jaroslav Belsky.
Explanation: The WHO has not changed the definition or description of the term "pandemic."

What did you fact-check?: WHO President Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus dances at a nightclub during the quarantine period.
Explanation: Misbar has investigated the video, which was released on June 12, and found that he is not the World Health Organization director, despite the physical similarities.

What did you fact-check?: Supreme Court released 32,000 prisoners because of COVID-19.
Explanation: Decision to take non violent prisoners into home prison is up to state courts. There was a recommendation from National Justice Council to do it so in order to prevent mass contaminations of COVID-19 inside prisons, but it was not a recommendation from the Supreme Court.

What did you fact-check?: A 19 year old was diagnosed with a respiratory illness that was caused by a daily and prolonged use of a face mask at work that was imposed for COVID-19 protection.
Explanation: The case in question was shared thousands of times in multiple social media accounts, every one of which used a completely different name for the 19 year old. Further, comercially available face masks have large enough pores that are more than enough wide to allow the flow of molecules like oxygen and carbon dioxide thus. Finaly, the idea that breathing in bacteria that we exhale can cause diseases like pleurisy is not backed by any scientific study or official scientific or medical institution. In fact, if an individual exhales those bacteria it means that they are already in his system thus the original argument does not make sense.

What did you fact-check?: Belgian doctors turn their back on WHO director.
Explanation: The Belgians medical personnel turned their backs on Belgian prime minister Sophie Wilmès.

What did you fact-check?: An alleged statement from a College of Physicians of Spain in which the population is warned about COVID-19 and what is involved in assisted ventilation, and there is a “call for common sense” in the lack of confinement.
Explanation: There is no evidence that it is from a Spanish College of Physicians. From the General Council of Medical Colleges (CGCOM) there is no evidence that it is a text from any school in Spain. The alleged statement has also reached Latin American countries and a fragment of it has been circulating at least since April.

What did you fact-check?: The new app to track infections in Germany (Corona Warn-App) is using your personal data and contacts on your smartphone in order to track and identify people.
Explanation: The app doesn't identify people and doesn't access personal data.

What did you fact-check?: Video with the claim that members of Brazilian Parliament broke into a hospital and found it had no coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The video is real, but it does not show members of Parliament looking for coronavirus patients. Actually the local politician Filippe Poubel and his supporters broke into the hospital to prove that it was not yet operating as it was promised by Rio government.

What did you fact-check?: A widely shared video claims to show Brazilian lawmaker Filippe Poubel erupt in anger as he breaks into a field hospital that had claimed to have 5,000 novel coronavirus patients and finds it empty.
Explanation: In reality, the clip depicts the politician expressing his displeasure over a delay in opening a new COVID-19 hospital.

What did you fact-check?: The EU has confirmed that 5G networks are harmful to people’s health.
Explanation: The EU has warned, precisely, that this statement is a hoax connected to the pandemic. EU regulations establish maximum levels of exposure to mobile networks that are 50 times lower than the limits from which health can be affected, according to scientific evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Infrared thermometers can cause damage to the retina.
Explanation: A viral chain on WhatsApp and Facebook alerts about possible damage with the "laser beam" emitted by thermometers that measure temperature without contact. However, thermometers do not emit laser beams, but instead have an infrared sensor that measures the temperature of people.

What did you fact-check?: An alleged alert issued by the WHO due to an infectious outbreak in India due to a virus called Nipah that would be “more deadly than COVID” as published by some Spanish media.
Explanation: It is a hoax

What did you fact-check?: Governor of São Paulo said he signed a contract with China for the production of a coronavirus vaccine in August 2019, which proves that the pandemic is a scam.
Explanation: The agreement between the government of São Paulo and China's Sinovac Biotech was signed on June 10 2020. In August 2019, the São Paulo government just opened a commercial office in Shanghai.

What did you fact-check?: Viral posts circulating in Africa claim Nobel Peace Prize winner Denis Mukwege resigned from the leadership of two COVID-19 task forces in DR Congo because he was told to manipulate patient numbers.
Explanation: The claim is false; Mukwege's resignation statement cited frustration at how the crisis was being managed, but nothing about fake patients. He has rejected the quotes attributed to him in the viral posts.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing people in hospital beds on a street has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook alongside a claim it shows coronavirus patients who were moved outside a hospital in Pakistan because of an overflow of patients.
Explanation: The claim is false; the video in fact shows patients who were evacuated from a hospital in the Pakistani city of Lahore after a fire broke out.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese authorities dumped dead bodies in the sea. These bodies were of patients who had died of coronavirus. The bodies are now washing up on the Hong Kong and Taiwan coasts.
Explanation: The video is from 2014 and shows the coast of Libya, Africa, where bodies had washed up after some people died in an accident.

What did you fact-check?: A post circulating on Facebook claims the latest research shows the mutation of COVID-19, D614G, makes the disease ten times more infectious.
Explanation: The claim came from American virologist William Haseltine's comment on the research of finding of D614G. The study itself doesn't prove if the mutation makes the COVID-19 more infectious.

What did you fact-check?: Supreme Court released 32,000 prisoners because of COVID-19.
Explanation: Decision to take non violent prisoners into home prison is up to state courts. There was a recommendation from National Justice Council to do it so in order to prevent mass contaminations of COVID-19 inside prisons, but it was not a recommendation from the Supreme Court.

What did you fact-check?: A 19 year old was diagnosed with a respiratory illness that was caused by a daily and prolonged use of a face mask at work that was imposed for COVID-19 protection.
Explanation: The case in question was shared thousands of times in multiple social media accounts, every one of which used a completely different name for the 19 year old. Further, comercially available face masks have large enough pores that are more than enough wide to allow the flow of molecules like oxygen and carbon dioxide thus. Finaly, the idea that breathing in bacteria that we exhale can cause diseases like pleurisy is not backed by any scientific study or official scientific or medical institution. In fact, if an individual exhales those bacteria it means that they are already in his system thus the original argument does not make sense.

What did you fact-check?: The new app to track infections in Germany (Corona Warn-App) is using your personal data and contacts on your smartphone in order to track and identify people.
Explanation: The app doesn't identify people and doesn't access personal data.

What did you fact-check?: Egypt Ministry of Education says it will give the family of any student who dies of COVID19 5 thousand egyptian pounds.
Explanation: The ministry of education denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates, who has led harmful vaccination campaigns in developing countries, now plans to use COVID-19 vaccines to surveil the population.
Who said/posted it?: Ty and Charlene Bollinger, The Truth About Cancer
Explanation: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has committed millions to the improvement of health outcomes in developing countries through vaccination campaigns, becoming a prominent target of the anti-vaccine groups. During the last decade, the foundation has also been involved in the development of health-related technology which, along with its active support of the research of COVID-19 treatments and vaccines during the outbreak, has led to the growth of conspiracy theories worldwide. The claim that Gates wants to use COVID-19 vaccines to track the population is unsupported. The vaccines used in the initiatives funded by the Gates Foundation in Africa and Asia were approved and safe.

What did you fact-check?: Mine Phone Sayardaw predicted that COVID-19 infections could exceed 100 million worldwide.
Explanation: Sayardaw U Thukamainda, a close devotee of the monk Mine Phone Sayardaw has categorically denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation building says “Center for Global Human Population Reduction” on its front.
Explanation: The image that circulates on social media is doctored. When searching for the place on Google Maps, it can be seen that the building of the civil organization of the founder of Microsoft does not have any facade like that of the viral image.

What did you fact-check?: According to a statement appearing to be coming from WHO “There is no pandemic. The epidemic does not exist. No vaccine is needed. Healthy people do not need gloves, face masks and other protective equipment. There was no need for a lockdown and a curfew as well as the so-called contact tracing. The virus cannot survive on surfaces – such an isolation was only the demand of governments. Each and every organisation, fitness clubs, theatres, restaurants, cafes and bars can work at full capacity.”
Explanation: There was no such statement made by the WHO official. The statment was fabricated.

What did you fact-check?: Masks are useless, even harmful.
Explanation: The protection of the mask is not only about the wearer, but the aim is to prevent the spread. In addition, it is very difficult for medical and fabric masks recommended to be used by the general population to cause carbon dioxide poisoning.

What did you fact-check?: Schools will not open on September 1. In Ukraine, September 1 is the beginning of the school year.
Explanation: The claim is unsubstantiated. The government has not made such a decision.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 expenses reports have been set on fire in a Nuevo León building, Mexico.
Explanation: The treasurer of Nuevo León, Carlos Garza, reported that a building with information from the Nuevo León Undersecretariat of Revenue in Mexico had burned down but say that it was false that expense reports COVID-19 had been damaged.

What did you fact-check?: A picture of the Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, allegedly taken at the “Stati Generali” conference organized in Rome during the Covid-19 pandemic. In the picture Conte is eating pizza while not respecting social distancing norms or any other safety measure
Explanation: The picture was taken in 2019, and it has nothing to do with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The Hague Tribunal has accepted a complaint against Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez for “genocide”.
Explanation: The Hague Tribunal has just registered the complaint.

What did you fact-check?: Viral posts circulating in Africa claim Nobel Peace Prize winner Denis Mukwege resigned from the leadership of two COVID-19 task forces in DR Congo because he was told to manipulate patient numbers.
Explanation: The claim is false; Mukwege's resignation statement cited frustration at how the crisis was being managed, but nothing about fake patients. He has rejected the quotes attributed to him in the viral posts.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple posts shared thousands of times on Facebook in Nigeria claim to be giving out smartphones to help students attend online classes during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: However, this is one of a growing number of scams aimed at increasing followers of social media pages and accounts.

What did you fact-check?: Eating alkaline foods with high pH eliminates the coronavirus or prevents its spread.
Explanation: Alkaline foods neither protect from COVID-19 nor even alter the pH of the blood in any significant way.

What did you fact-check?: Argentine President Alberto Fernández said that he respects distancing from people and that “all” his selfies are “one and a half meters away”.
Explanation: The Argentine President argued that “many times when I take selfies people think that I am surrounded by people; it is a projection problem ”. There are photos and a video in which the President does not respect the distance recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the Ministry of Health of the Nation, and that it is not a problem of perspective of the photo.

What did you fact-check?: João Doria, governor of São Paulo, signed a contract with Sinovac to develop a vaccine against COVID-19 in August. Therefore, he knew all about the disease and is part of a Chinese conspiracy.
Explanation: Doria never said he signed a contract with Sinovac in 2019. What he actually said is that the partnership between Sinovac and the state government of São Paulo to test a COVID-19 vaccine, signed in June 2020, was only possible because a commercial representation was set up in Shanghai on August 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Video of the president of the Catholic University of Murcia (UCAM), José Luis Mendoza, in which he falsely assures that the coronavirus was predicted at the 2012 London Olympics.
Explanation: The statements coincide with the diffusion of several publications that claim that the prediction was made in one of the performances London 2012 opening ceremony which, in fact, celebrated the British National Health Service (NHS, by its initials in English). Therefore, it is a hoax that the COVID-19 pandemic was predicted during it.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows police seizing money diverted from respirators at the home of the health secretary of the Brazilian city of Belém.
Explanation: The video was recorded during a police operation in the city of Barcarena (in the Brazilian state of Pará) against six military police officers accused of embezzling seized cocaine.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 expenses reports have been set on fire in a Nuevo León building, Mexico.
Explanation: The treasurer of Nuevo León, Carlos Garza, reported that a building with information from the Nuevo León Undersecretariat of Revenue in Mexico had burned down but say that it was false that expense reports COVID-19 had been damaged.

What did you fact-check?: Brazilian Supreme Court denied order for army hospitals to treat COVID-19 patients.
Explanation: A decision in that sense was taken by a federal court, not the supreme court. Also, it determined that opening army hospitals for common population is a decision that has to come from governors and mayors, not from judiciary.

What did you fact-check?: News stories referencing the number “322” and COVID-19 are proof cases tolls are being “synchronized”.
Explanation: The volume of media coverage and the number of local and regional government units around the world provide ample opportunities for cases or deaths to sum to any number. You can find this “connection” for any low three-digit number. A Google News search shows 322 isn’t even a particularly common tally.

What did you fact-check?: “In a very real sense, (Oklahoma has) flattened the curve. … The number of cases in Oklahoma — it’s declined precipitously.”
Explanation: Oklahoma’s daily caseload has risen consistently in June, and to levels higher than at any point in the pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: Governor of São Paulo said he signed a contract with China for the production of a coronavirus vaccine in August 2019, which proves that the pandemic is a scam.
Explanation: The agreement between the government of São Paulo and China's Sinovac Biotech was signed on June 10 2020. In August 2019, the São Paulo government just opened a commercial office in Shanghai.

What did you fact-check?: Maharashtra (India)’s CM Uddhav Thackeray announced reimplementation of lockdown.
Explanation: The viral video is an old one where Maharashtra's CM announced lockdown for the first time.

What did you fact-check?: Tunisian dancer Nermine Safar is honored by the National Anti-Corruption Commission for its efforts to fight Covid-19.
Explanation: Misbar checked the story and found that the image was fabricated, as the name which appeared on the original certificate of appreciation, Moncef Al-Karimi, was deleted, and replaced by the name of Nermin Safar.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is disseminated intravascular coagulation, or pulmonary thrombosis, and ventilators and intensive care units (ICUs) were “never needed” in treating the disease because it can be fought with “antibiotics, anti-inflammatories and anticoagulants.” The disease is also caused by a bacteria that gets amplified by 5G technology.
Explanation: Thrombosis is only one possible effect of COVID. The drugs mentioned in the online posts were meant to address related infections in COVID-19 patients. The disease is viral and not bacterial in nature, and the claims about 5G having to do with the disease are unsupported.

What did you fact-check?: “George Floyd’s ‘murder’ filmed before COVID-19.”
Explanation: George Floyd’s death wasn’t staged, and it wasn’t filmed before the coronavirus pandemic. He died on May 25 after a police officer pressed his knee against Floyd’s neck for nearly 9 minutes. Officers and bystanders can be seen wearing masks in video footage taken before Floyd’s death.

What did you fact-check?: “FREE HORSES!!!! 52 thoroughbred horses need homes. Will go to Sugarcreek this Sat. for slaughter. Gentleman died due to COVID-19 and his son wants nothing to do with them.”
Explanation: This is an outdated and misleadingly edited Facebook post that originated in 2011 after a longtime horse breeder died in Ohio.

What did you fact-check?: “Six months before the COVID ‘plandemic,’ Bill Gates had negotiated a $100 billion contact tracing deal with (the) Democratic congressman sponsor of bill.”
Explanation: There’s no evidence Gates worked with U.S. Rep. Bobby Rush on a $100 billion COVID-19 contact tracing bill months before the COVID-19 outbreak occurred. The bill proposed by Rush would give money not to Gates or his foundation but to organizations that provide COVID-19 testing, contact tracing or other services.

What did you fact-check?: Brazailian parliament went to a hospital that should take in COVID19 patients and found it was empty.
Explanation: The original video shows a visit from a Brazilian parliament member to a hospital under construction that should have been used for COVID-19 patients and was delayed more than a month. The parliament member didn't criticize the government numbers or say anything about a conspiracy.

What did you fact-check?: A post shared thousands of times on Facebook claims to show a map comparing the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States and Canada.
Explanation: This claim is misleading according to the map’s creators because it is comparing cumulative cases between countries with very different populations and population densities.

What did you fact-check?: The Hague Tribunal has accepted a complaint against Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez for “genocide”.
Explanation: The Hague Tribunal has just registered the complaint.

What did you fact-check?: A newspaper article stating that the Italian newspaper “Il Fatto Quotidiano” illicitly benefited from public fundings linked to COVID-19.
Explanation: The newspaper "Il Fatto Quotidiano" actually benefited from a special kind of loan regulated by the "Decreto liquidità", a law passed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, it cannot be considered as "public fundings".

What did you fact-check?: Viral posts circulating in Africa claim Nobel Peace Prize winner Denis Mukwege resigned from the leadership of two COVID-19 task forces in DR Congo because he was told to manipulate patient numbers.
Explanation: The claim is false; Mukwege's resignation statement cited frustration at how the crisis was being managed, but nothing about fake patients. He has rejected the quotes attributed to him in the viral posts.

What did you fact-check?: Telangana (India) Minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav said lockdown will be extended.
Explanation: Telangana Minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav did not say that lockdown will be extended.

What did you fact-check?: Tunisian actress Sophia Sadiq died in Egypt, after she was infected with Covid-19.
Explanation: Misbar verified the news and it turned out to be false, as the Tunisian artist denied the news and told Radio Jawhara FM of Tunisia on Saturday 13 June that she is fine and in good health, and that what is being circulated is just rumors and false news.

What did you fact-check?: “There is no pandemic. Terrorists Gates and Soros arranged the quarantine for world domination”.
Explanation: The new coronavirus pandemic is real. It was not prearranged.

What did you fact-check?: Patients dancing in NSCI Quarantine center in Mumbai.
Explanation: Video is old and of a quarantine center in Tripura.

What did you fact-check?: Delhi public school selling face mask to students.
Explanation: Viral claim is false. DPS management denied this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Mouthwash prevents COVID19
Explanation: Claiming that mouthwash can prevent you from becoming infected or preventing the transmission of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, because its components could inactivate the pathogen is misleading and can cause you to relax sanitary measures that do reduce the risk of contagion.

What did you fact-check?: Britain forbids sex between people who don’t live together.
Explanation: The British government has not introduced such a ban. The articles added to the existing law regulating quarantine measures do not contain a provision regarding sexual intercourse.

What did you fact-check?: H1N1 caused more deaths during the 2009 pandemic than COVID-19. Yet, nobody talked about it.
Explanation: Officially, 18 thousand deaths were confirmed during the H1N1 pandemic. Currently, more than 400 thousand deaths have been confirmed for COVID-19

What did you fact-check?: Photo of a man trying to ressurect his grandmother through mouth-to-mouth breathing. According to the caption, the photo was taken in Minas Gerais, Brazil.
Explanation: The photo is true and current, but it was taken in Mexico

What did you fact-check?: The list shows the medicines issued by a doctor in Gangaram (India) hospital to alleviate coronavirus symptoms.
Explanation: No, these medicines have not been prescribed by a doctor in Gangaram.

What did you fact-check?: A photograph shows a baby breastfeeding on her dead mother who lost her life due to food scarcity during the lockdown.
Explanation: This is image is available since 2013 on the internet. It has being falsely shared as a recent Nationwide COVID-19 Lockdown.

What did you fact-check?: False positive result rate in PCR tests is 50 percent.
Explanation: PCR tests are one of the most reliable methods currently known. Also, there are not enough findings to conclude that PCR tests' false positive ratr is 50 percent.

What did you fact-check?: Telangana (India) Minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav said lockdown will be extended.
Explanation: Telangana Minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav did not say that lockdown will be extended.

What did you fact-check?: Tunisian actress Sophia Sadiq died in Egypt, after she was infected with Covid-19.
Explanation: Misbar verified the news and it turned out to be false, as the Tunisian artist denied the news and told Radio Jawhara FM of Tunisia on Saturday 13 June that she is fine and in good health, and that what is being circulated is just rumors and false news.

What did you fact-check?: Facebook is using your pictures and posts in lawsuits against it amid COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The post claiming that amid COVID-19 pandemic, Facebook has changed its privacy rules, allowing it to use pictures and posts shared by users in lawsuits against them is fake.

What did you fact-check?: A doctor at the SGRH hospital in New Delhi, India prescribed hydroxychloroquine tablet to prevent COVID-19 infection.
Explanation: The prescription is a fake one forging the handwriting, stamp and signature of the said doctor.

What did you fact-check?: Image shows a policewoman who died of COVID-19 on the street, after she was refused a request to go home.
Explanation: According to the reconstruction of the events carried out by the government of Mexico City, the female police officer that appears in the image belongs to the Auxiliary Police of the SSC and operates in the Historic Center. She didn't die, she just suffered heat stroke.

What did you fact-check?: A picture showing Copacabana beach, in Brazil, full of crosses which make it look like a graveyard.
Explanation: The picture is real, but the beach was staged for a protest by a group of activists. The crosses do not mark real graves.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows COVID-19 patients lying dead on the ground in India.
Explanation: The video shows visuals from the Vizag gas plant leak where few people suffocated to death. It has no link to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A photograph shows a baby breastfeeding on her dead mother who lost her life due to food scarcity during the lockdown.
Explanation: This is image is available since 2013 on the internet. It has being falsely shared as a recent Nationwide COVID-19 Lockdown.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of a man trying to ressurect his grandmother through mouth-to-mouth breathing. According to the caption, the photo was taken in Minas Gerais, Brazil.
Explanation: The photo is true and current, but it was taken in Mexico

What did you fact-check?: Lockdown policies are responsible for the high death rates in Spain, Belgium, Italy and France.
Explanation: This is the opposite

What did you fact-check?: Fewer than 100 people have died from COVID-19 in Ireland.
Explanation: Ireland's current death toll from COVID-19 stands at 1,703.

What did you fact-check?: False positive result rate in PCR tests is 50 percent.
Explanation: PCR tests are one of the most reliable methods currently known. Also, there are not enough findings to conclude that PCR tests' false positive ratr is 50 percent.

What did you fact-check?: Indian boy predicted the coronavirus in 2019.
Explanation: Although the boy did speak of future disasters, he never mentioned the coronavirus or a pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: H1N1 caused more deaths during the 2009 pandemic than COVID-19. Yet, nobody talked about it.
Explanation: Officially, 18 thousand deaths were confirmed during the H1N1 pandemic. Currently, more than 400 thousand deaths have been confirmed for COVID-19

What did you fact-check?: A graphic of Zee News TV channels claims that the Home Ministry of India has hinted at a complete lockdown in the country after 15 June. Railway and airway will come to a halt.
Explanation: The grpahic is morphed. The Home Ministry has not hinted at a complete lockdown and TV channel Zee News has not show any such news.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of the facade of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation building that reads, in English, “Center for Global Human Population Reduction.”
Explanation: It is a hoax, the photo is a montage and in the building, which is in Seattle (USA), this phrase does not appear.

What did you fact-check?: Ivermectin is the cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: Doctor supports the use of the drug to treat patients with COVID-19 but denies that it is the cure for the disease. Also, the person who's quoted said posts and bloggers exagerated what he had said about the drug.

What did you fact-check?: The photo of a beach with private and isolated compartments as if it were somewhere in the Algarve, the southern region of Portugal. In addition, it is related to security measures during de-escalation by the coronavirus.
Explanation: It is a hoax. The image is real but it is of a tourist complex that is located on the coast of Turkey and that already offered the cabins before the coronavirus crisis.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows the last COVID-19 patient exiting from the hospital in New Zealand.
Explanation: Video is, in fact, from Italy. It shows the closing down of a coronavirus ward in the town of Matera.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO banned autopsies and Italy changed the protocols for the coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO could not ban autopsies and Italy has not changed the protocols for the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Delhi public school selling face mask to students.
Explanation: Viral claim is false. DPS management denied this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Two persons with coronavirus escaped from a hospital in Bogota.
Explanation: This image shows two famous youtubers, not two coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Britain forbids sex between people who don’t live together.
Explanation: The British government has not introduced such a ban. The articles added to the existing law regulating quarantine measures do not contain a provision regarding sexual intercourse.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of a man trying to ressurect his grandmother through mouth-to-mouth breathing. According to the caption, the photo was taken in Minas Gerais, Brazil.
Explanation: The photo is true and current, but it was taken in Mexico

What did you fact-check?: The list shows the medicines issued by a doctor in Gangaram (India) hospital to alleviate coronavirus symptoms.
Explanation: No, these medicines have not been prescribed by a doctor in Gangaram.

What did you fact-check?: Singer Mohamed Abdo has been infected with the novel coronavirus, and isolates himself in a hotel in Jeddah.
Explanation: Misbar checked the news, and found it to be false. The artist appeared on Al-Arabiya channel hours ago, confirming that his result was negative, and that the video circulated was during his return from abroad, and he went to one of the hotels that the Kingdom chose to perform examinations and health isolation, where he conducted a test COVID-19 before meeting his family.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of a handwritten letter which shows an Indian hospital’s letterhead has been shared in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts alongside a claim that it is a genuine prescription issued by a doctor at the hospital for a COVID-19 patient.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the hospital denied that the prescription was issued by one of their doctors and said the signature was forged.

What did you fact-check?: Gov. of Wisconsin Tony Evers “removed the American flag from the Capitol building”.
Explanation: The picture presented as proof was from a rally in support of reopening Wisconsin on April 24, 2020. Like most protests, that occurred on the West side of the building, where the flagpole atop the entrance is controlled by the state Assembly. The Assembly only flies the U.S. flag there when in session, and they weren’t that day. The additional detail about Evers ordering a flag to be removed is nonsense.

What did you fact-check?: COVID patients playing cricket, dancing to ‘Lungi dance’ in Gachibowli stadium in India.
Explanation: The videos shared belong to different quarantine wards in India, not Gachibowli Hyderabad.

What did you fact-check?: Government of Colombia launched a survey on social media called “Return to face-to-face classes in schools and universities”.
Explanation: The Ministry of Education denied that the chain, which circulates on WhatsApp and Facebook, had originated from the entity, and recommended consulting the official channels.

What did you fact-check?: Delhi public school selling face mask to students.
Explanation: Viral claim is false. DPS management denied this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Former Brazilian presidential candidate Fernando Haddad celebrates his birthday with a bunch of guests during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: Photo is from 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook post that says that masks incubate cancer and that the risks of using them are hypoxia (lack of oxygen in the body) and hypercapnia (excess carbon dioxide), which could “cause poisoning in the flow blood, as well as physical and mental disorders.”
Explanation: Using a mask does not cause hypoxia or hypercapnia in healthy people, so it is not the origin of any other pathology.

What did you fact-check?: Director of WHO is dancing in a night club in violation of COVID19 guidelines.
Explanation: The video shows another man not the director of WHO and was published as a meme by the original publisher, after tracking the video it was shot before the quarantine of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Under the influence of hot weather, i.e., high air temperature, the number of patients with coronavirus was supposed to decrease. The novel coronavirus, if it even exists, dies under the high temperature.
Explanation: Hot weather does not affect the number of patients with COVID-19 or the survival of the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: H1N1 caused more deaths during the 2009 pandemic than COVID-19. Yet, nobody talked about it.
Explanation: Officially, 18 thousand deaths were confirmed during the H1N1 pandemic. Currently, more than 400 thousand deaths have been confirmed for COVID-19

What did you fact-check?: The WHO banned autopsies and Italy changed the protocols for the coronavirus.
Explanation: WHO could not ban autopsies and Italy has not changed the protocols for the virus.

What did you fact-check?: The German government reopens its airspace and excludes all Arab countries from the procedure, except for Tunisia.
Explanation: Misbar checked the news that was circulated and found to be false, as Germany did not announce the reopening of its airspace with any Arab country, but decided on June 3 to cancel travel warnings on 29 European countries beginning in the middle of the month.

What did you fact-check?: People who arrived at Tirur, Kerala (India) from Mumbai in train, escaped from the sight of the authorities to avoid quarantine.
Explanation: The Tirur Municipality has refuted the news and have also filed a case against the perpetrators of this false information.

What did you fact-check?: The World Health Organization (WHO) concludes that a Covid-19 carrier is not contagious until symptoms of infection appear on them.
Explanation: Misbar verified the claim and found it misleading. Van Kirchhoff explained that her speech in the press briefing on June 8 about the scarcity of coronavirus transmission from a person who did not show symptoms of infection was understood incorrectly, and that it was not officially declared in the name of the World Health Organization.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that Sarah Huckabee Sanders tweeted, “It’s ‘odd’ that the ANTIFA insurgency happened just as COVID-19 loses steam It’s ‘odd’ that COVID-19 happened the moment impeachment failed. It’s ‘odd’ that impeachment happened the moment Russian hoax failed. The Russian hoax happened because Hillary lost? Notice the pattern?”
Explanation: Sarah Huckabee Sanders didn’t tweet this conspiracy theory, but an account using her photo did.

What did you fact-check?: Using cypress and eucalyptus vapor as a treatment against COVID-19 works.
Explanation: Using cypress and eucalyptus vapor as a treatment against COVID-19 has no scientific basis.

What did you fact-check?: OMS says people infected with COVID-19 without symptons do not transmit the disease.
Explanation: Interview with Maria Van Kerkhove, OMS technique director, was misunderstood. She said they don't know yet how COVID-19 is transmitted from people without symptons. She said studies about it are rare, but it was understood that transmition from people without symptons was rare. OMS came one day after to state clearly that people with no symptons sure can transmite the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows man holding bodies in sacks with only one hand.
Explanation: Video shows the making of a protest. Sacks were not filled with dead bodies from patients with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A message stating that temperature checks can be dangerous for the eyes.
Explanation: There is no evidence that this is the case or that it is necessary to cover your eyes when your temperature is checked this way.

What did you fact-check?: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar is going to the Supreme Court to make the coronavirus vaccine mandatory for all people living in Ireland.
Explanation: A vaccine for COVID-19 does not yet exist and there is no way for Leo Varadkar to go to the Supreme Court on this issue.

What did you fact-check?: Image claiming to be Sri Lankan Soldiers and Police having their meals on the streets during COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: Image shows Indian Police and Army personnel sharing their meals on a street.

What did you fact-check?: São Paulo’s governor, João Doria, admits deaths caused by COVID-19 are recorded twice.
