In fact, the study’s authors concluded that “Effective prevention and control measures are helpful to prevent COVID-19 spread of asymptomatic carriers.” Scientific evidence also suggests that asymptomatic spread can and does occur.

What did you fact-check?: A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows police in India beating a man to death after he violated a nationwide coronavirus lockdown by “venturing out for food”.
Explanation: The claim is false; the video has circulated in reports about police beating an intoxicated man in India’s Madhya Pradesh state in an incident unrelated to the ongoing lockdown; police said two officers had been suspended over the incident for "assaulting" a man.

What did you fact-check?: Brahma Bar, one of São Paulo’s most famous bars, is going to close after going bankrupt during the pandemic.
Explanation: According to the bar's management, they did not go bankrupt and will not close.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple posts shared thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube claim that salt is an effective remedy against the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is false; health experts have said there is no evidence that salt can treat the novel coronavirus disease; as of May 2020, the WHO says there is no remedy for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows women shopping in Delhi’s market during lockdown.
Explanation: This viral video is of Faisalabad in Pakistan, not of Delhi market.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a large crowd in the marketplace at Muhammad Ali road, Mumbai, violating lockdown.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Pakistan. It is being falsely shared as being shot in various cities in India.

What did you fact-check?: Foo Fighters frontman Dave Grohl was diagnosed with COVID-19.
Explanation: No legitimate news organization has reported on the Foo Fighters frontman recently getting sick, much less contracting COVID-19. Its source -- a “Bild newspaper” -- also published its last feature on Grohl in January 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a large crowd in the marketplace at Muhammad Ali road, Mumbai violating current COVID-19 lockdown in India.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Pakistan. It is being falsely shared in the name of various cities in India.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows a baby named Kyle who was recently diagnosed with COVID-19 after getting open-heart surgery five days after being born.
Explanation: It maliciously uses the photo of New Zealander Cameron Bartle just two days after he underwent his first open-heart surgery at five days old, in August 2012. He is now seven years old.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows migrants vandalizing public property in Surat during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: The video is actually from Kathua, Uttar Pradesh. It is being falsely shared as being taken in Surat.

What did you fact-check?: The mayor of the municipality of Socorro, in Santander, Colombia, was arrested for manipulating contracts in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The police of the Santander department said that the photo of the mayor of the municipality of Socorro in which it appears that she was arrested for manipulation of contracts in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic is false.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus multiplies in sewage and pouring bleach in the sewage water would help.
Explanation: Pouring bleach, as said in the whatsapp message, would jeopardize researchers' analysis to make predictions through the COVID-19 RNA left in the sewage.

What did you fact-check?: Axel Kicillof (Governor of the Province of Buenos Aires): 80 days after the first case, Argentina has 10,000 cases; Chile, 60 thousands and Brazil, 200 thousands.
Explanation: The data from the three countries coincide rounded with the reported cases, according to an observatory of the University of Oxford. However, this indicator depends a lot on the number of tests that are carried out, so it is not useful to compare the progress of the pandemic. There are other indicators, however, that do show a more critical situation in the South American countries compared by the Buenos Aires governor.

What did you fact-check?: The video shows a man kissing a bat in a cave in Bursa, Turkey, regardless of the coronavirus.
Explanation: It is true that the man in Bursa entered a cave and kissed bats. But the video dates back to 2017 before the outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: There were “only 48” PCR tests in Tokyo on May 19th.
Explanation: The number of tests conducted by the Tokyo Metropolitan Institute of Public Health alone is indeed 48, however, if we include all PCR test centers commissioned by the Tokyo Metropolitan Government, there were 975 tests on May 19 and 712 on May 20.

What did you fact-check?: Facebook user suggests that confirmed cases are suspected cases of COVID-19 whereas those declared positive are people who actually have the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Individuals who test positive for COVID-19 are considered confirmed cases.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, is a form of bacteria that can be cured by aspirin.
Explanation: There is scientific consensus that COVID-19 is caused by a virus that belongs to the coronavirus family. Both the WHO and the Ministry of Health of Italy say there is no specific treatment or registered cure for COVID-19 to date.

What did you fact-check?: An image of a cactus-shaped antenna claiming that it is a 5G antenna and that they hide them so that “people do not realize that they are radioactive and emit electromagnetic frequency waves”.
Explanation: The photo is not current, nor is it a 5G antenna. It is not taken either in Colombia or in Mexico, but in Arizona, United States in 2009.

What did you fact-check?: Social media commentaris claim a murder of a 37-year-old Chinese researcher studying COVID-19 at the University of Pittsburgh in early May could be a cover-up as he was about to reveal important findings, possibly the U.S. origin of the coronavirus.
Explanation: Local police’s investigation determined the murder suicide was a result of “a lengthy dispute regarding an intimate partner” and had nothing to do with Liu’s coronavirus research. The University of Pittsburgh's official statement also clarified the area of his research, which is not about the origin of the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: People in Saudi Arabia thronged store after lockdown was lifted.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video is older than Dec 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Axel Kicillof (Governor of the Province of Buenos Aires): 80 days after the first case, Argentina has 10,000 cases; Chile, 60 thousands and Brazil, 200 thousands.
Explanation: The data from the three countries coincide rounded with the reported cases, according to an observatory of the University of Oxford. However, this indicator depends a lot on the number of tests that are carried out, so it is not useful to compare the progress of the pandemic. There are other indicators, however, that do show a more critical situation in the South American countries compared by the Buenos Aires governor.

What did you fact-check?: Because of the coronavirus economic crisis, Adidas went into bankruptcy.
Explanation: The Adidas bankruptcy rumor is a joke invented by Olympique Lyonnais' soccer fans dissatisfied with their team jersey designed by Adidas for the next season.

What did you fact-check?: The experts at Nanavati Hospital are giving four common treatments to all patients: Vitamin C, dry ginger, turmeric and steam.
Explanation: No doctor from Nanavati Hospital in Mumbai has recommended the four treatments mentioned in the viral message to COVID-19 positive patients. The claim in the Whatsapp message is fake.

What did you fact-check?: 182 truck drivers who had tested positive for COVID-19 in Kenya were re-tested and found to be negative in Tanzania.
Explanation: Samples from the 19 drivers were retested and found to be negative after Kenya registered 182 cases at the Tanzania border.

What did you fact-check?: Facebook posts shared hundreds of times in South Africa claim that criminals posing as government officials are going around to people’s homes and distributing face masks that are laced with chemicals to knock them out and rob them.
Explanation: However, local police -- like their counterparts elsewhere in the world -- dismissed the claim as a myth.

What did you fact-check?: The mayor of the municipality of Socorro, in Santander, Colombia, was arrested for manipulating contracts in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The police of the Santander department said that the photo of the mayor of the municipality of Socorro in which it appears that she was arrested for manipulation of contracts in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic is false.

What did you fact-check?: Foo Fighters frontman Dave Grohl was diagnosed with COVID-19.
Explanation: No legitimate news organization has reported on the Foo Fighters frontman recently getting sick, much less contracting COVID-19. Its source -- a “Bild newspaper” -- also published its last feature on Grohl in January 2019.

What did you fact-check?: The chloroquine study published in the Lancet cost 50 million dollars.
Explanation: There is no reliable data to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Aspirin cures COVID-19.
Explanation: WHO says that there is no treatment or cure for COVID-19 at the moment.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a large crowd in the marketplace at Muhammad Ali road, Mumbai, violating lockdown.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Pakistan. It is being falsely shared as being shot in various cities in India.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a large crowd in the marketplace at Muhammad Ali road, Mumbai violating current COVID-19 lockdown in India.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Pakistan. It is being falsely shared in the name of various cities in India.

What did you fact-check?: A video which would show a “desperate mother” who lost everything during the pandemic.
Explanation: The video is real, but it was shot in 2017. It has nothing to do with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Russia raises the image of Christ to help it ending the pandemic.
Explanation: The video was shot in Russia, specifically in the city of Kamensk-Uralsky, but the image of Christ was raised in order to celebrate Easter.

What did you fact-check?: Ukrainians over 60 will not be allowed to work anymore. They should be under lockdown.
Explanation: The norm about isolating people over 60 was a temporary measure during the national lockdown in Ukraine.

What did you fact-check?: People in USA march and call for the arrest of Bill Gates.
Explanation: According to our research on this video, we find that videos of protests against lockdown in the United States have been fabricated and shared with misleading claims including Bill Gates’s arrest.

What did you fact-check?: A video shared on Facebook showed the current situation in China as it battles the second wave of coronavirus infections.
Explanation: The video is not new. On February 14, UK-based tabloid Daily Express published an article about it saying the 3 young siblings in the video allegedly died of carbon monoxide poisoning.

What did you fact-check?: Text claims that the North Macedonian Minister of Health Venko Filipce at a press conference held that day (21 May 2020) said that the patients infected with COVID-19 may have to pay a fee (co-payment) for hospital treatment.
Explanation: First of all, this is not a new press conference from 21 May 2020, but an old one from April 24, at which questions are asked by journalists about whether those who are being treated from COVID-19 in hospital will be exempted from co-payment for hospitalization. Second, the minister's response is that a financial construction will be made to free them from co-payments, regardless of whether or not they have health insurance. At the moment, neither the Hospital "8 Septemvri", nor the Infectious Diseases Clinic charge money for the treatment of coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Sloth bear seen in a house garden in Sri Lanka during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: This is an old video of slothbear in a garden in Tamil Nadu, India. It has no relation with lockdown or Sri Lanka.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows three men on crosses who “feel like they’re being crucified by being required to stay at home.”
Explanation: No, this crucifixion photo doesn’t show pandemic protesters. This photo is from at least two years ago.

What did you fact-check?: Cannabis could help prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: This is not a study that passed the peer review, it was conducted on artificial human tissues and not on real organisms. It is a classic preliminary research that may even fail. The authors themselves speak of the need for further studies and research.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a fight to get seating on the terrace of a bar in Spain under the state of alarm.
Explanation: The video was shot in 2016 and reflects a brawl that has nothing to do with the bar.

What did you fact-check?: Brazilian state of Minas Gerais has fewer deaths than São Paulo even though it has not adopted quarantine measures.
Explanation: The simple comparison of numbers made in the publications generates a distorted interpretation because 1) the level of testing in both states was ignored, 2) it cannot be said that the two states are or are not fully implementing social isolation measures, and 3) the size of the population, the demographic density and the greater insertion of São Paulo in the route of national and international flights are also factors that influenced the worsening of the disease outbreak in that state, in comparison with Minas Gerais.

What did you fact-check?: Flu shots are contaminated with dogs’ coronaviruses.
Explanation: Dolores Cahill, in an interview, says flu vaccines are contaminated with dogs' coronaviruses, but it's fake. Dog cell cultures are used to make some vaccines, but these cultures do not contain dog coronaviruses.

What did you fact-check?: A Spanish study with 60 thousand subjects proved that lockdown policies are ineffective.
Explanation: Although the study itself exists, it does not say, in any moment, that lockdown policies were ineffective in the country

What did you fact-check?: An image of a cactus-shaped antenna claiming that it is a 5G antenna and that they hide them so that “people do not realize that they are radioactive and emit electromagnetic frequency waves”.
Explanation: The photo is not current, nor is it a 5G antenna. It is not taken either in Colombia or in Mexico, but in Arizona, United States in 2009.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is harmless and does not cause death.
Explanation: Until May 22, 2020, the number of deaths from COVID-19 in the world had reached 323,256 people and in Indonesia 1,326 people. Patients who die from COVID-19 are not only those who have comorbidities and old age, but also young age groups and without comorbidities.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a lockdown lifting celebration in Saudi Arabia.
Explanation: The video is a video of the police and residents of Al Naif and Al Ras, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, celebrating the lockdown easing on April 26, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a large crowd in the marketplace at Muhammad Ali road, Mumbai violating current COVID-19 lockdown in India.
Explanation: The video is, in fact, from Pakistan. It is being falsely shared in the name of various cities in India.

What did you fact-check?: A video is circulating on social networks showing an alleged death in Chiquimula, Guatemala.
Explanation: The video has the logo of a Chiquimula page, making it misleading. However, the video documents a drill carried out in Colombia.

What did you fact-check?: The outbreak of the novel coronavirus pandemic in Saudi Arabia will end on the 5th of Shawwal (June 2 2020).
Explanation: The image was fabricated.

What did you fact-check?: 5G wireless technology created the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The World Health Organization has stated that there is no link between the disease and exposure to 5G wireless technology.

What did you fact-check?: Cannabis could help prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: This is not a study that passed the peer review, it was conducted on artificial human tissues and not on real organisms. It is a classic preliminary research that may even fail. The authors themselves speak of the need for further studies and research.

What did you fact-check?: A Spanish study with 60 thousand subjects proved that lockdown policies are ineffective.
Explanation: Although the study itself exists, it does not say, in any moment, that lockdown policies were ineffective in the country

What did you fact-check?: 20% of human volunteers for the test for a COVID-19 vaccine developed by Moderna have suffered serious adverse effects.
Explanation: Eight volunteers participated in phase 1 of the clinical trials and developed an immune response and are in good health, with no major sequelae.

What did you fact-check?: People living in quarantine centre refuse to eat food as it was cooked by lower caste women.
Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media claiming that persons seen in the video refused to eat food cooked by a lower caste woman at a quarantine center is misleading. The Bihar police have ruled out any casteist angle to the incident.

What did you fact-check?: Maroole Online Forum website claiming that 14 of the 25 confirmed cases of COVID-19 announced on May 7 are Oromo political prisoners.
Explanation: Ethiopian Federal Prison Commission has said no cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed among Ethiopian prisoners.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a lockdown lifting celebration in Saudi Arabia.
Explanation: The video is a video of the police and residents of Al Naif and Al Ras, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, celebrating the lockdown easing on April 26, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Flu shots are contaminated with dogs’ coronaviruses.
Explanation: Dolores Cahill, in an interview, says flu vaccines are contaminated with dogs' coronaviruses, but it's fake. Dog cell cultures are used to make some vaccines, but these cultures do not contain dog coronaviruses.

What did you fact-check?: People knew about coronavirus even in 2003. However, unlike today, there was no panic, fines, or quarantine back then.
Explanation: SARs-CoV-2 is a new and previously unknown type of coronavirus. In 2003, there was a spread of a different coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Dolores Cahill claims in an interview on TheHighWire that there is already a preventive strategy and treatment for COVID-19 through “nutrition, vitamins and hydroxychloroquine”, therefore social distancing is unnecessary.
Explanation: Contrary to Cahill’s claims, no therapeutic strategy has been proven effective to prevent or treat COVID-19 yet. Current evidence indicates that precautionary measures including frequent handwashing, cleaning and disinfection of frequently touched objects, use of masks, and social distancing are effective to help prevent the spread of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: People living in quarantine centre refuse to eat food as it was cooked by lower caste women.
Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media claiming that persons seen in the video refused to eat food cooked by a lower caste woman at a quarantine center is misleading. The Bihar police have ruled out any casteist angle to the incident.

What did you fact-check?: People in the city of Mumbai, India are not following social distancing, and have gone outside their homes to shop for the festival of Eid.
Explanation: The video is from a market in Pakistan, not India. The market was opened after the Pakistan government relaxed some lockdown restrictions.

What did you fact-check?: A post of Cronica with statements by the President of Sweden on the Argentinian Government.
Explanation: The only Swedish official statement, in relation to the comparisons made by the Argentine president, Alberto Fernández, days ago, was through his embassy in Buenos Aires and did not contain that text. The image is coming from a website used to create false news headlines similar to those of the HD Cronica channel.

What did you fact-check?: People knew about coronavirus even in 2003. However, unlike today, there was no panic, fines, or quarantine back then.
Explanation: SARs-CoV-2 is a new and previously unknown type of coronavirus. In 2003, there was a spread of a different coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows Dean of Kasturba Hospital telling gargling with salt water kills coronavirus.
Explanation: This is a false video going viral, that doesn't show the dean of Kasturba Hospital.

What did you fact-check?: There is nothing called “coronavirus” and it is just a hoax to pass Bill Gates’s vaccine.
Explanation: The novel coronavirus causing COVID-19 exists and was seen on microscopic imagery. The allegation about Bill Gates vaccine is not based on any evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Madagascar is leaving World Health organisation and encourages other countries to do so.
Explanation: Presidence of Madagascar and WHO denied this claim and there is no withdrawal procedure.

What did you fact-check?: Son of brazilian anchor Willian Bonner requested and received COVID-19 emergency aid of R $ 600.
Explanation: There is, in fact, an approved request in Vinicius Bonemer's name, but it's coming from a scamming attempt, according to the Jornal Nacional's anchor post published on Twitter in 21 May and to the Brazilian Ministry of Citizenship in response to Aos Fatos.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a fight to get seating on the terrace of a bar in Spain under the state of alarm.
Explanation: The video was shot in 2016 and reflects a brawl that has nothing to do with the bar.

What did you fact-check?: Wearing a mask during physical activity causes hypercapnia syndrome.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that physical activity causes hypercapnia.

What did you fact-check?: Georgian doctor created medicine Corvirant which treats coronavirus.
Explanation: It is unknown whether the drug Corvirant even exists at all. It has not passed any clinical trial. There are currently no drugs licensed for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19. Efforts are still underway to develop and evaluate medicines to treat COVID-19. Some specific drugs are being tested through clinical trials. Although the primary testing carried out by some companies proved successful, there is no COVID-19 vaccine available for massive use and further stages of clinical trials are still ahead. Scientists do not have an exact answer about when COVID-19 drug or vaccine going well with safety and efficacy testing will be available.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci seen walking in close proximity without mask during the coronavirus pendemic.
Explanation: This picture of Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci was taken in 2018, viral with fake claim.

What did you fact-check?: A team of experts and scientists from the Faculty of Medicine in Rabat announce that a vaccine for Covid-19 is coming soon.
Explanation: There is no truth in the information spread about the development of an anti-coronavirus vaccine in Morocco. The development of a vaccine is a long and time-consuming process which does not take place overnight.

What did you fact-check?: Dolores Cahill claims in an interview on TheHighWire that there is already a preventive strategy and treatment for COVID-19 through “nutrition, vitamins and hydroxychloroquine”, therefore social distancing is unnecessary.
Explanation: Contrary to Cahill’s claims, no therapeutic strategy has been proven effective to prevent or treat COVID-19 yet. Current evidence indicates that precautionary measures including frequent handwashing, cleaning and disinfection of frequently touched objects, use of masks, and social distancing are effective to help prevent the spread of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a lockdown lifting celebration in Saudi Arabia.
Explanation: The video is a video of the police and residents of Al Naif and Al Ras, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, celebrating the lockdown easing on April 26, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is harmless and does not cause death.
Explanation: Until May 22, 2020, the number of deaths from COVID-19 in the world had reached 323,256 people and in Indonesia 1,326 people. Patients who die from COVID-19 are not only those who have comorbidities and old age, but also young age groups and without comorbidities.

What did you fact-check?: Starting on May 20 this year, the Egyptian Minister of Health has placed herself in measures to isolate herself at home, as a result of suspected infection with the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Misbar verified the news, and found it false, especially after the minister appeared on May 21, during the inauguration of the "Bashir Al-Khair" project, alongside President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi. The Ministry of Health itself denied the news on its website.

What did you fact-check?: A team of experts and scientists from the Faculty of Medicine in Rabat announce that a vaccine for Covid-19 is coming soon.
Explanation: There is no truth in the information spread about the development of an anti-coronavirus vaccine in Morocco. The development of a vaccine is a long and time-consuming process which does not take place overnight.

What did you fact-check?: Lesotho has launched a COVID-19 remedy.
Explanation: Leso Oxi is a herbal concoction manufactured in Lesotho, where it is claimed to be effective against the flu, but it is yet to be tested against COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Sloth bear seen in a house garden in Sri Lanka during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: This is an old video of slothbear in a garden in Tamil Nadu, India. It has no relation with lockdown or Sri Lanka.

What did you fact-check?: People living in quarantine centre refuse to eat food as it was cooked by lower caste women.
Explanation: The video doing rounds on social media claiming that persons seen in the video refused to eat food cooked by a lower caste woman at a quarantine center is misleading. The Bihar police have ruled out any casteist angle to the incident.

What did you fact-check?: Worldwide research shows that hydroxychloroquine is the most effective drug against COVID-19.
Explanation: The source of the information cited is, in reality, a poll without statistical validity made by the online forum Sermo. The data, moreover, are from an old poll, from April 2.

What did you fact-check?: South Sudan President Salva Kiir and his first deputy Riek Machar recently became targets of tit-for-tat claims on Facebook alleging they had flown to foreign countries for COVID-19 treatment. For four days, rumours about the two men — bitter rivals since the 2013 civil war — flew thick and fast on social media.
Explanation: Allegations that they were abroad (and even dead in the case of Kiir) were finally put to bed with television appearances from their respective homes in the capital, Juba.

What did you fact-check?: The use of face masks increases the risk of developing COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that the use of face masks increases the risk of developing COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Colombia ranks first in corruption in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: A blog attributes this ranking to the NGO Transparency International, but this organization has not published this. Actually, this is a perception survey conducted by a US media outlet last January.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows an overcrowded Madina market in Hyderabad, India, where people are shopping for Eid.
Explanation: The viral video is not from Hyderabad but Faisalabad in Pakistan.

What did you fact-check?: Madagascar is leaving World Health organisation and encourages other countries to do so.
Explanation: Presidence of Madagascar and WHO denied this claim and there is no withdrawal procedure.

What did you fact-check?: There is nothing called “coronavirus” and it is just a hoax to pass Bill Gates’s vaccine.
Explanation: The novel coronavirus causing COVID-19 exists and was seen on microscopic imagery. The allegation about Bill Gates vaccine is not based on any evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci seen walking in close proximity without mask during the coronavirus pendemic.
Explanation: This picture of Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci was taken in 2018, viral with fake claim.

What did you fact-check?: Son of brazilian anchor Willian Bonner requested and received COVID-19 emergency aid of R $ 600.
Explanation: There is, in fact, an approved request in Vinicius Bonemer's name, but it's coming from a scamming attempt, according to the Jornal Nacional's anchor post published on Twitter in 21 May and to the Brazilian Ministry of Citizenship in response to Aos Fatos.

What did you fact-check?: Wearing a mask during physical activity causes hypercapnia syndrome.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that physical activity causes hypercapnia.

What did you fact-check?: Lithuanian parliament member said that there are some very serious reasons to believe that virus was made artificialy in a laboratory and everything is related to Gates and other millionaires plan to create artificial virus just to sell vaccines afterwards.
Explanation: Scientific community expressed their opinion that the virus is completely natural. There are no evidence of the contrary.

What did you fact-check?: A celebration in Belgium of the Tunisian doctor, Mohamed Mourad, after recovering from the novel coronavirus, which he contracted while working at a hospital in Brussels.
Explanation: Misbar has verified the news that was circulated and found it to be misleading, as the heart doctor, Mohamed Mourad, is a Belgian of Lebanese origin, not a Tunisian, Egyptian, or Palestinian doctor.

What did you fact-check?: Georgian doctor created medicine Corvirant which treats coronavirus.
Explanation: It is unknown whether the drug Corvirant even exists at all. It has not passed any clinical trial. There are currently no drugs licensed for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19. Efforts are still underway to develop and evaluate medicines to treat COVID-19. Some specific drugs are being tested through clinical trials. Although the primary testing carried out by some companies proved successful, there is no COVID-19 vaccine available for massive use and further stages of clinical trials are still ahead. Scientists do not have an exact answer about when COVID-19 drug or vaccine going well with safety and efficacy testing will be available.

What did you fact-check?: People in Jama Masjid market breaking Indian COVID-19 lockdown due to Eid.
Explanation: Video is from Pakistan and not from Delhi.

What did you fact-check?: Kenyan First Lady Margaret Kenyatta is giving out Ksh30,000 grants to help Kenyans during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The post offering these grants was published on a Facebook account impersonating the First Lady, and charges a fee for interested applicants.

What did you fact-check?: Georgian doctor created medicine Corvirant which treats coronavirus.
Explanation: It is unknown whether the drug Corvirant even exists at all. It has not passed any clinical trial. There are currently no drugs licensed for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19. Efforts are still underway to develop and evaluate medicines to treat COVID-19. Some specific drugs are being tested through clinical trials. Although the primary testing carried out by some companies proved successful, there is no COVID-19 vaccine available for massive use and further stages of clinical trials are still ahead. Scientists do not have an exact answer about when COVID-19 drug or vaccine going well with safety and efficacy testing will be available.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that official data show that there were more deaths in Italy in 2019 than in 2020.
Explanation: The source used is wrong. According to ISTAT data, by analyzing a random sample of municipality it appears that in the first 3 months of 2020 there has been an increase of almost 7 thousand deaths. Italy registered 25,354 excess deaths from February 20 to March 31.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci seen walking in close proximity without mask during the coronavirus pendemic.
Explanation: This picture of Bill Gates and Anthony Fauci was taken in 2018, viral with fake claim.

What did you fact-check?: A celebration in Belgium of the Tunisian doctor, Mohamed Mourad, after recovering from the novel coronavirus, which he contracted while working at a hospital in Brussels.
Explanation: Misbar has verified the news that was circulated and found it to be misleading, as the heart doctor, Mohamed Mourad, is a Belgian of Lebanese origin, not a Tunisian, Egyptian, or Palestinian doctor.

Explanation: Presidence of Madagascar and WHO denied this claim and there is no withdrawal procedure.

Explanation: The novel coronavirus causing COVID-19 exists and was seen on microscopic imagery. The allegation about Bill Gates vaccine is not based on any evidence.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows an overcrowded Madina market in Hyderabad, India, where people are shopping for Eid.
Explanation: The viral video is not from Hyderabad but Faisalabad in Pakistan.

What did you fact-check?: Pathogenic viruses do not exist, as the German biologist Stefan Lanka proved in front of a court.
Explanation: Viruses do exist and no, no lawsuit denied their existence.

What did you fact-check?: Kenyan First Lady Margaret Kenyatta is giving out Ksh30,000 grants to help Kenyans during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The post offering these grants was published on a Facebook account impersonating the First Lady, and charges a fee for interested applicants.

What did you fact-check?: The use of face masks increases the risk of developing COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that the use of face masks increases the risk of developing COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Wearing a mask during physical activity causes hypercapnia syndrome.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence that physical activity causes hypercapnia.

What did you fact-check?: Lithuanian parliament member said that there are some very serious reasons to believe that virus was made artificialy in a laboratory and everything is related to Gates and other millionaires plan to create artificial virus just to sell vaccines afterwards.
Explanation: Scientific community expressed their opinion that the virus is completely natural. There are no evidence of the contrary.

What did you fact-check?: Worldwide research shows that hydroxychloroquine is the most effective drug against COVID-19.
Explanation: The source of the information cited is, in reality, a poll without statistical validity made by the online forum Sermo. The data, moreover, are from an old poll, from April 2.

What did you fact-check?: Worldwide research shows that hydroxychloroquine is the most effective drug against COVID-19.
Explanation: The source of the information cited is, in reality, a poll without statistical validity made by the online forum Sermo. The data, moreover, are from an old poll, from April 2.

What did you fact-check?: A Whatsapp message stating that Ikea is giving out €250 gift cards for free.
Explanation: The link for obtaining the gift card actually redirects the user to a form which collects sensitive data. It's a scam, and Ikea is not giving out free gift cards.

What did you fact-check?: People who have received flu vaccines in the past three to five years will “probably test positive” for COVID-19.
Explanation: Medical experts refute the claim, and the Food and Drug Administration hasn’t observed any instances in authorized tests to date. Flu vaccines do not contain the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: French champion of chloroquine Didier Raoult is leaving France to teach in China.
Explanation: His team denied the information, and the email adress informing his editor of the news is false.

What did you fact-check?: A blog article stating that COVID-19 has been misdiagnosed, as the deaths would be caused by problems linked with thrombosis in the first place. According to the article, the two scientists who discovered this have received an “international prize”
Explanation: Thrombosis can be a problem linked with COVID-19, but it's not the first cause of death. Furthermore, the "prize" received by the two scientists is actually granted by the World Boxing Council, and it has nothing to do with science or medicine.

What did you fact-check?: The image shows Los Angeles County Department of Public Health Director Dr. Barbara Ferrer looking sickly.
Explanation: The image has been digitally manipulated to make Ferrer look ill.

What did you fact-check?: A viral video shared on multiple social media platforms shows a woman outside a US store making several misleading claims about the use of face masks including that they do not protect from COVID-19 and that their use makes you sick.
Explanation: Research backed by leading academic institutions and international health bodies recommends they be used along with other measures to help limit the spread of the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: South Sudan President Salva Kiir and his first deputy Riek Machar recently became targets of tit-for-tat claims on Facebook alleging they had flown to foreign countries for COVID-19 treatment. For four days, rumours about the two men — bitter rivals since the 2013 civil war — flew thick and fast on social media.
Explanation: Allegations that they were abroad (and even dead in the case of Kiir) were finally put to bed with television appearances from their respective homes in the capital, Juba.

What did you fact-check?: Kenyan First Lady Margaret Kenyatta is giving out Ksh30,000 grants to help Kenyans during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The post offering these grants was published on a Facebook account impersonating the First Lady, and charges a fee for interested applicants.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows an overcrowded Madina market in Hyderabad, India, where people are shopping for Eid.
Explanation: The viral video is not from Hyderabad but Faisalabad in Pakistan.

What did you fact-check?: A celebration in Belgium of the Tunisian doctor, Mohamed Mourad, after recovering from the novel coronavirus, which he contracted while working at a hospital in Brussels.
Explanation: Misbar has verified the news that was circulated and found it to be misleading, as the heart doctor, Mohamed Mourad, is a Belgian of Lebanese origin, not a Tunisian, Egyptian, or Palestinian doctor.

What did you fact-check?: Top White House coronavirus adviser Dr. Anthony Fauci served on the Clinton Foundation’s board of directors for 20 years.
Explanation: There is no record of Fauci ever sitting on the Clinton Foundation’s board. A spokesperson confirmed he has never served on its board or worked for the foundation.

What did you fact-check?: South Sudan President Salva Kiir and his first deputy Riek Machar recently became targets of tit-for-tat claims on Facebook alleging they had flown to foreign countries for COVID-19 treatment. For four days, rumours about the two men — bitter rivals since the 2013 civil war — flew thick and fast on social media.
Explanation: Allegations that they were abroad (and even dead in the case of Kiir) were finally put to bed with television appearances from their respective homes in the capital, Juba.

What did you fact-check?: German police can enter homes and forcibly vaccinate people.
Explanation: This is not true, and there is no evidence of this happening.

What did you fact-check?: Video and photo show that Indonesian President Jokowi attended a concert during the COVID-19 Pandemic
Explanation: The music concert that Jokowi attended in the video and photo was held in 2017, before the COVID-19 pandemic. The charity concert that was held by the MPR, BPIP, and BNPB on May 17, 2020 yesterday was also a virtual concert.

What did you fact-check?: Pathogenic viruses do not exist, as the German biologist Stefan Lanka proved in front of a court.
Explanation: Viruses do exist and no, no lawsuit denied their existence.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of the Algerian doctor, Wafaa Boudissah, while he is working on admitting Covid-19 patients.
Explanation: Misbar checked the image which turned out to be misleading, as it shows Taylor Poynter, an emergency physician at the Chicago Hospital emergency room.

What did you fact-check?: People who have received flu vaccines in the past three to five years will “probably test positive” for COVID-19.
Explanation: Medical experts refute the claim, and the Food and Drug Administration hasn’t observed any instances in authorized tests to date. Flu vaccines do not contain the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Wearing a face mask for a prolonged period of time causes hypoxia and/or hypercapnia.
Explanation: Using face masks does not cause hypoxia nor excessive carbon dioxide intake. The World Health Organization (WHO) Philippines said there is no evidence that using face masks for a prolonged period of time causes any adverse effect on the brain or heart function.

What did you fact-check?: The President of the United States of America Donald Trump has been tested positive for COVID-19.
Explanation: A viral video on social media claimed that US President Donald Trump has been tested positive for coronavirus is misleading. The video has been edited to spread misinformation.

What did you fact-check?: Brazil has a 99.995% COVID-19 survival rate.
Explanation: Experts consulted by Aos Fatos affirm that this calculation cannot yet be done due to deficiencies in the accounting of infected and recovered from the disease.

What did you fact-check?: The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) has issued guidelines about the post-lockdown phase.
Explanation: ICMR has denied issuing such guidelines. The viral message has been falsely attributed to ICMR

What did you fact-check?: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat said he has lost faith in religion due to coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: RSS has denied Mohan Bhagwat made such a statement. The viral newspaper clipping is photoshopped.

What did you fact-check?: The Philippines was the first country to declare a lockdown in Southeast Asia.
Explanation: Vietnam was the first country in Southeast Asia to declare a lockdown. In Asia, at least three other countries aside from Vietnam -- China, Saudi Arabia, and Mongolia -- imposed lockdown and quarantine measures ahead of the Philippines.

What did you fact-check?: German police can enter homes and forcibly vaccinate people.
Explanation: This is not true, and there is no evidence of this happening.

What did you fact-check?: Leopard is seen roaming in Delhi’s dwarka during the lockdown period.
Explanation: Video is not from Delhi, it is from Hyderabad where the lion was spotted.

What did you fact-check?: Decreeing the state of alarm because of Covid until June 30 would extend it throughout the summer.
Explanation: The state of emergency has a limited period of validity, the Permanent Deputation controls the Government when there is no session.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows health professionals turning their backs on the mayor of the city of São Paulo.
Explanation: The video shared in the false publications actually shows a protest against Belgium's prime minister, Sophie Wilmès, as she arrived to visit a hospital in Brussels, the country's capital, on May 16.

What did you fact-check?: A family friend of prominent playwright Ratnakar Matkari said he was infected with coronavirus through outside mild packages.
Explanation: Matkari's family has clarified that this is false information and this family friend has not spoken with the family.

What did you fact-check?: The COVID-19 pandemic “was combined at a meeting” in 2019 sponsored by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
Explanation: It is not true that the COVID-19 pandemic "was combined at a meeting" in 2019 sponsored by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.

What did you fact-check?: Leopard is seen roaming in Delhi’s dwarka during the lockdown period.
Explanation: Video is not from Delhi, it is from Hyderabad where the lion was spotted.

What did you fact-check?: German police can enter homes and forcibly vaccinate people.
Explanation: This is not true, and there is no evidence of this happening.

What did you fact-check?: Wuhan has imposed a second lockdown after a resurgence of COVID-19 cases.
Explanation: While the Wuhan government reported six new cases of COVID-19 as of May 10, the Chinese embassy in the Philippines confirmed through a text message to VERA Files that the city has not closed its borders again in May, a month after it re-opened on April 7.

What did you fact-check?: João Doria, governor of São Paulo, said people need to choose between “lockdown or food” in an interview on Brasil Urgente, a national TV show.
Explanation: He did not say people need to choose between "lockdown or food". He said that following social isolation was a matter of life and death, and that, although confinement can be very taxing, specially to the poor, unnecessary exposure to COVID-19 is a deadly threat.

What did you fact-check?: The Philippines was the first country to declare a lockdown in Southeast Asia.
Explanation: Vietnam was the first country in Southeast Asia to declare a lockdown. In Asia, at least three other countries aside from Vietnam -- China, Saudi Arabia, and Mongolia -- imposed lockdown and quarantine measures ahead of the Philippines.

What did you fact-check?: Brazil has a 99.995% COVID-19 survival rate.
Explanation: Experts consulted by Aos Fatos affirm that this calculation cannot yet be done due to deficiencies in the accounting of infected and recovered from the disease.

What did you fact-check?: US President Donald Trump tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: Donald Trump's valet has tested positive for COVID-19, not the President himself.

What did you fact-check?: French champion of chloroquine Didier Raoult is leaving France to teach in China.
Explanation: His team denied the information, and the email adress informing his editor of the news is false.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO said that Colombia is the most organized country in the prevention of coronavirus in America or the second in the world.
Explanation: There is no record that this international organization has recognized, evaluated and compared the performance of Colombia in terms of prevention of COVID-19 with that of other countries.

What did you fact-check?: Video and photo show that Indonesian President Jokowi attended a concert during the COVID-19 Pandemic
Explanation: The music concert that Jokowi attended in the video and photo was held in 2017, before the COVID-19 pandemic. The charity concert that was held by the MPR, BPIP, and BNPB on May 17, 2020 yesterday was also a virtual concert.

What did you fact-check?: Hydroxychloroquine cures COVID-19.
Explanation: Hydroxychloroquine hasn’t been proven to cure COVID-19 and is not used as a treatment for radiation sickness.

What did you fact-check?: Video claiming news channel Fox News reported that Donald Trump has tested positive for COVID-19.
Explanation: This is a doctored clip. Fox news did not air this segment.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors give their backs to São Paulo’s mayor, Bruno Covas, as protest against quarantine measures.
Explanation: Protest happened in Brussels and was against prime minister Sophie Wilmès.

What did you fact-check?: RSS Chief Mohan Bhagwant’s said that COVID-19 shook his faith in religion.
Explanation: This is a false statement from Mohan Bhagwat. He did not make this statement.

What did you fact-check?: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat said he has lost faith in religion due to coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: RSS has denied Mohan Bhagwat made such a statement. The viral newspaper clipping is photoshopped.

What did you fact-check?: A doctor from Kasturba Hospital suggested to not wear masks all the time because otherwise, it could cause death.
Explanation: The hospital clarified that no such message has been released by any doctor of Kasturba Hospital. Expert of Indian Medical Association denied that the claims regarding the use of masks.

What did you fact-check?: The very first detailed report shows Turkey’s coronavirus outbreak was published in NEJM.
Explanation: There is no pre-print of an approved report published in New England Journal of Medicine on Turkey's outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows health professionals turning their backs on the mayor of the city of São Paulo.
Explanation: The video shared in the false publications actually shows a protest against Belgium's prime minister, Sophie Wilmès, as she arrived to visit a hospital in Brussels, the country's capital, on May 16.

What did you fact-check?: “Why did the state do that with COVID patients in nursing homes? It’s because the state followed President Trump’s CDC guidance.”
Explanation: New York’s nursing home policy was not fully in line with CDC. The Cuomo administration issued an advisory March 25 that stated that nursing homes "must comply with the expedited receipt of residents” coming from hospitals, regardless of whether they are infected with the new coronavirus. The CDC warned nursing homes to keep COVID-19 out of their facilities and said nursing homes can admit coronavirus patients, but only if they are able to properly care for them. The Cuomo administration says that regulations that predate the pandemic require nursing homes to admit only those patients for which they can care. However, in the month following the March 25 advisory, nursing home operators felt that they had no choice but to accept these patients.

What did you fact-check?: The image shows Los Angeles County Department of Public Health Director Dr. Barbara Ferrer looking sickly.
Explanation: The image has been digitally manipulated to make Ferrer look ill.

What did you fact-check?: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat said he has lost faith in religion due to coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: RSS has denied Mohan Bhagwat made such a statement. The viral newspaper clipping is photoshopped.

What did you fact-check?: Wuhan has imposed a second lockdown after a resurgence of COVID-19 cases.
Explanation: While the Wuhan government reported six new cases of COVID-19 as of May 10, the Chinese embassy in the Philippines confirmed through a text message to VERA Files that the city has not closed its borders again in May, a month after it re-opened on April 7.

What did you fact-check?: Amazon is delivering economic help in Venezuela because of the pandemic spread of COVID-19.
Explanation: Amazon is not delivering any kind of packages or help in any country.

What did you fact-check?: Top White House coronavirus adviser Dr. Anthony Fauci served on the Clinton Foundation’s board of directors for 20 years.
Explanation: There is no record of Fauci ever sitting on the Clinton Foundation’s board. A spokesperson confirmed he has never served on its board or worked for the foundation.

What did you fact-check?: Brazil has a 99.995% COVID-19 survival rate.
Explanation: Experts consulted by Aos Fatos affirm that this calculation cannot yet be done due to deficiencies in the accounting of infected and recovered from the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Leopard is seen roaming in Delhi’s dwarka during the lockdown period.
Explanation: Video is not from Delhi, it is from Hyderabad where the lion was spotted.

What did you fact-check?: Michigan governor reopened Traverse City “so she could have her daughter’s open house.”
Explanation: Easing one of her COVID-19 stay-at-home orders, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer partially reopened a large swath of northern Michigan. The governor’s office said the reopening did not coincide with any Whitmer family event in Traverse City, which is in the reopened area.

What did you fact-check?: A Whatsapp message stating that Ikea is giving out €250 gift cards for free.
Explanation: The link for obtaining the gift card actually redirects the user to a form which collects sensitive data. It's a scam, and Ikea is not giving out free gift cards.

What did you fact-check?: Video claiming news channel Fox News reported that Donald Trump has tested positive for COVID-19.
Explanation: This is a doctored clip. Fox news did not air this segment.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors give their backs to São Paulo’s mayor, Bruno Covas, as protest against quarantine measures.
Explanation: Protest happened in Brussels and was against prime minister Sophie Wilmès.

What did you fact-check?: French champion of chloroquine Didier Raoult is leaving France to teach in China.
Explanation: His team denied the information, and the email adress informing his editor of the news is false.

What did you fact-check?: São Paulo’s governor João Doria ordered a recall of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine from dugstores.
Explanation: The medecine is used as political tool to divide the governor and federal government. The state government said they receive the medecine and delivers to hospitals. State government has no control over drugstores.

What did you fact-check?: The UN is asking for help from Donald Trump for serious human rights violations in Italy during the management of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The UN has not asked for Donald Trump's help. A representative in Italy of an Ecuadorian association asked the American President for help via Twitter. Italian sites believed that the woman was a UN commissioner.

What did you fact-check?: Daughter of Santander’s CEO in Portugal shared a message about her father’s death from COVID-19.
Explanation: The communications office said the message was invented and that the woman denied thinking like that.

What did you fact-check?: Family of poor migrant commited suicide during lockdown in India.
Explanation: Old picture is falsely linked with lockdown; it is not recent.

What did you fact-check?: “The new Dane County lockdown policy… (has) effectively killed Badger football, hockey, and basketball for 2020.”
Explanation: Dane County’s phased reopening plan during the coronavirus pandemic puts restrictions on businesses and public gatherings. But it is unclear whether and to what degree the policy will impact sporting events at UW-Madison. The university is working with Public Health Madison and Dane County, as well as the Big Ten Conference, to determine how best to resume athletics.

What did you fact-check?: There are no antibiotics to cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: This theory has no basis in any scientific study.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of a queue of buses in India has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim they were organised by a leading opposition politician to transport migrant workers who were left stranded after a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has circulated in reports since February 2019 about a Hindu festival.

What did you fact-check?: Video of leopard roaming on road during lockdown is from Delhi, India.
Explanation: Video of leopard roaming on road is from Hyderabad, not Delhi.

What did you fact-check?: João Doria, governor of São Paulo, said people need to choose between “lockdown or food” in an interview on Brasil Urgente, a national TV show.
Explanation: He did not say people need to choose between "lockdown or food". He said that following social isolation was a matter of life and death, and that, although confinement can be very taxing, specially to the poor, unnecessary exposure to COVID-19 is a deadly threat.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple allegations on the bill drafted to Turkish congress named H.R. 6666.
Explanation: The purpose of the bill is to provide funds to local organizations to ensure that those at risk for COVID-19 to be tested, traced, and quarantined safely in their homes. Bill does not propose to enter the houses by force and to take children from their families. Tests and quarantine will be based on consent when necessary. The draft does not include a regulation on the COVID-19 vaccine. Bill Gates just mentioned the possibility that a digital certificate will show up in the future, indicating that people are being tested and vaccinated due to the new coronavirus; did not say it would be mandatory.

What did you fact-check?: Dr Robert Gallo confessed to being forced to create a virus to wipe out the African race.
Explanation: Dr Gallo was part of the team that discovered that HIV causes AIDS, and there is no evidence that the research was done under duress.

What did you fact-check?: Priyanka Gandhi has started buses to help migrants travel during the COVID-19 lockdown.
Explanation: These buses were started by the Congress for the ease of the passengers to travel to the Kumbh Mela.

What did you fact-check?: Travel in public transport in Kyiv will rise after the lockdown is lifted.
Explanation: Neither private carriers nor the authorities have made the decision to increase the transport fare after lifting the lockdown.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that President Donald Trump is trying to make $451 billion in Medicare cuts “in the middle of a deadly pandemic.”
Explanation: Democratic super PAC uses familiar political play to hit Trump on Medicare. The timeline of events doesn’t support this statement. The $451 billion figure is accurate, but presented in a misleading way. It is not a direct program cut to beneficiaries. Instead, it is the result of lowering payments to providers. It also reflects a 10-year budget window.

What did you fact-check?: US President Donald Trump tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: Donald Trump's valet has tested positive for COVID-19, not the President himself.

What did you fact-check?: A blog article stating that COVID-19 has been misdiagnosed, as the deaths would be caused by problems linked with thrombosis in the first place. According to the article, the two scientists who discovered this have received an “international prize”
Explanation: Thrombosis can be a problem linked with COVID-19, but it's not the first cause of death. Furthermore, the "prize" received by the two scientists is actually granted by the World Boxing Council, and it has nothing to do with science or medicine.

What did you fact-check?: President Donald Trump “cancelled” the U.S. House bill on contract tracing and “expelled WHO.”
Explanation: The president doesn't have the power to "cancel" a bill, and he announced he would withhold payments to the WHO, which is headquartered in Switzerland, not the U.S.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a paramilitary force unit taking charge in Mumbai to control the lockdown situation.
Explanation: Fact Crescendo geolocated the video which confirmed that is from another city called Pune in Maharashtra.

What did you fact-check?: Image of worn-out feet with blisters shows the plight of a woman migrant worker in the lockdown.
Explanation: The image was actually of a woman who had participated in a protest in 2018 in Maharashtra. It has nothing to do with recent migrating laborers' plight.

What did you fact-check?: Daughter of Santander’s CEO in Portugal shared a message about her father’s death from COVID-19.
Explanation: The communications office said the message was invented and that the woman denied thinking like that.

What did you fact-check?: Claim that President Donald Trump is trying to make $451 billion in Medicare cuts “in the middle of a deadly pandemic.”
Explanation: Democratic super PAC uses familiar political play to hit Trump on Medicare. The timeline of events doesn’t support this statement. The $451 billion figure is accurate, but presented in a misleading way. It is not a direct program cut to beneficiaries. Instead, it is the result of lowering payments to providers. It also reflects a 10-year budget window.

What did you fact-check?: Portuguese university discovered the cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: It is not true that a Portuguese university discovered the cure to COVID-19. The university mentioned in the post doesn't even exist.

What did you fact-check?: Substances present in the boldo and in the quina plant treat COVID-19.
Explanation: The Brazilian Ministry of Health and the World Health Organization say that no type of tea has proven effective for treating COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Social media posts claim that actors were caught in the act staging fake COVID-19 cases.
Explanation: The man depicted in the photos in question wearing black was a private sector employee that was quarantied in a hotel and as soon as he developed symptoms for COVID-19 the public health authorities were called to transport him to the hospital. Due to the risk of contamination the man was placed on a special capsule and transported by ambulance to the nearest hospital.

What did you fact-check?: A man sells snacks to Covid-19 patients in Ibn Zahr Hospital in Marrakech, without respecting health safety conditions.
Explanation: Misbar checked the video and found it misleading, as the patients who appeared in the video, according to the Regional Directorate of Health in Marrakech, were following treatment at Ibn Zahr Hospital and all recovered on May 14, 2020, and left quarantine after filming a video showing In it, one of the patients took on the role of a food vendor, and the rest took on the role of supposed customers.

What did you fact-check?: President Donald Trump “cancelled” the U.S. House bill on contract tracing and “expelled WHO.”
Explanation: The president doesn't have the power to "cancel" a bill, and he announced he would withhold payments to the WHO, which is headquartered in Switzerland, not the U.S.

What did you fact-check?: A video from Portugal proves that there are no deaths due to COVID-19. In the coffin of an alleged victim there were only sand and rocks not a body.
Explanation: The video that is being shared is from 2017 and was shot as part of a police investigation in Brazil after allegations for insurance fraud.

What did you fact-check?: São Paulo’s governor João Doria ordered a recall of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine from dugstores.
Explanation: The medecine is used as political tool to divide the governor and federal government. The state government said they receive the medecine and delivers to hospitals. State government has no control over drugstores.

What did you fact-check?: Travel in public transport in Kyiv will rise after the lockdown is lifted.
Explanation: Neither private carriers nor the authorities have made the decision to increase the transport fare after lifting the lockdown.

What did you fact-check?: Articles shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter claim Rwandan President Paul Kagame censured the World Health Organization (WHO) for rejecting a herbal tonic touted by the Madagascan government as a cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: A presidential spokesperson dismissed the claim as “fake news”. No evidence was found to show Kagame made the comments. In fact, he has said his government is avoiding untested remedies.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of a queue of buses in India has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim they were organised by a leading opposition politician to transport migrant workers who were left stranded after a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has circulated in reports since February 2019 about a Hindu festival.

What did you fact-check?: Family of poor migrant commited suicide during lockdown in India.
Explanation: Old picture is falsely linked with lockdown; it is not recent.

What did you fact-check?: The UN is asking for help from Donald Trump for serious human rights violations in Italy during the management of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The UN has not asked for Donald Trump's help. A representative in Italy of an Ecuadorian association asked the American President for help via Twitter. Italian sites believed that the woman was a UN commissioner.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of a queue of buses in India has been shared thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim they were organised by a leading opposition politician to transport migrant workers who were left stranded after a nationwide coronavirus lockdown.
Explanation: The claim is false; the photo has circulated in reports since February 2019 about a Hindu festival.

What did you fact-check?: President Donald Trump “cancelled” the U.S. House bill on contract tracing and “expelled WHO.”
Explanation: The president doesn't have the power to "cancel" a bill, and he announced he would withhold payments to the WHO, which is headquartered in Switzerland, not the U.S.

What did you fact-check?: “A lot of people can get an additional $2,400” from the CARES Act “and they can do it every month!”
Explanation: A radio station Instagram account gets to $2,400 a month by multiplying $600 times four weeks. But that amount is not available to all Americans. The $600 a week is for unemployed people eligible for federal help. The $600 a week benefit under the Federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation is only available through the end of July.

What did you fact-check?: Portuguese university discovered the cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: It is not true that a Portuguese university discovered the cure to COVID-19. The university mentioned in the post doesn't even exist.

What did you fact-check?: Venezuela has the lowest rate of COVID-19 cases from Antarctica to the North Pole.
Who said/posted it?: Jorge Rodríguez, minister of Communications of Venezuela
Explanation: Suriname has a lower case rate than Venezuela.

What did you fact-check?: Daughter of Santander’s CEO in Portugal shared a message about her father’s death from COVID-19.
Explanation: The communications office said the message was invented and that the woman denied thinking like that.

Explanation: The Brazilian Ministry of Health and the World Health Organization say that no type of tea has proven effective for treating COVID-19.

Explanation: These buses were started by the Congress for the ease of the passengers to travel to the Kumbh Mela.

Explanation: A presidential spokesperson dismissed the claim as “fake news”. No evidence was found to show Kagame made the comments. In fact, he has said his government is avoiding untested remedies.

The draft does not include a regulation on the COVID-19 vaccine. Bill Gates just mentioned the possibility that a digital certificate will show up in the future, indicating that people are being tested and vaccinated due to the new coronavirus; did not say it would be mandatory.

What did you fact-check?: India’s main opposition party (Congress) general secretary Priyanka Gandhi arranged 1000 buses to take home the migrants stuck in the state of Uttar Pradesh.
Explanation: The image of buses arranged in a line on the road was taken in February 2019 during a fair organised by the state of Uttar Pradesh.

What did you fact-check?: The Algerian President, Abdel Majid Taboun, awarded the National Order of Merit to the family of the martyr doctor Wafaa Boudissa, and her name was given to a hospital in the country.
Explanation: Misbar communicated with journalists on for the public Algerian radio, who denied the news and said that some sites shared it but it was not correct, and that they have not yet received any official statement in this regard.

What did you fact-check?: Tanzania has reported 16,467 COVID-19 cases, 1,293 deaths, and 118 recoveries as of May 18.
Explanation: Government records show that Tanzania has 509 COVID-19 cases and recorded 21 deaths by May 13.

What did you fact-check?: The UN is asking for help from Donald Trump for serious human rights violations in Italy during the management of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Explanation: The UN has not asked for Donald Trump's help. A representative in Italy of an Ecuadorian association asked the American President for help via Twitter. Italian sites believed that the woman was a UN commissioner.

What did you fact-check?: Northern Ireland was testing for COVID-19 at a rate 10 times that of Scotland, reported on 9 May 2020.
Explanation: Northern Ireland’s test rate for the day of 8 May 2020 was about three-quarters (80%) that of Scotland.

What did you fact-check?: ID2020 is a criminal experiment. Elon Musk is responsible for making everyone wearing masks. The coronavirus was drawn in the computer program.
Explanation: ID2020 is a project on electronic passports. It is the WHO, not Elon Musk, that recommends people wearing masks to protect themselves from infecting. The new coronavirus is real and was captured through the microscope by the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.

What did you fact-check?: A man sells snacks to Covid-19 patients in Ibn Zahr Hospital in Marrakech, without respecting health safety conditions.
Explanation: Misbar checked the video and found it misleading, as the patients who appeared in the video, according to the Regional Directorate of Health in Marrakech, were following treatment at Ibn Zahr Hospital and all recovered on May 14, 2020, and left quarantine after filming a video showing In it, one of the patients took on the role of a food vendor, and the rest took on the role of supposed customers.
