Explanation: Studies do not prove coronavirus is affected by temperature and or inanimate objects.

What did you fact-check?: Summer temperatures will make coronavirus disappear.
Explanation: Not enough is known about the coronavirus to prove this claim.

What did you fact-check?: The wife of a Chinese shop owner in Totana (Murcia, Spain) has coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is not true.

What did you fact-check?: “Spanish newspaper ABC reports there are two possible COVID-19 cases in Gines and Benecazón (Seville, Spain).
Explanation: ABC has not published this article

What did you fact-check?: Florida man is arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.
Explanation: The photo was created using a prank generator site.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese police use a fishing net to arrest a man with a high fever.
Explanation: The video shows a police training exercise.

What did you fact-check?: A man with a gas mask at a supermarket in Lugo (Galicia, Spain).
Explanation: The photo was taken in Austria, not Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Tips against coronavirus like holding your breath and drinking water.
Explanation: These tips don't prevent infection with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.
Explanation: The video shows a mock drill. The China SWAT team in the video is "practicing" how to deal with coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a roof full of bats claims it is the source of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was recorded in Florida in 2011, not in China.

What did you fact-check?: Shaving facial hair ensures safety from COVID-19, further attributing the message to the CDC.
Explanation: This information was directed to workers who use respirators in carrying out their tasks and has nothing to do with preventing the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The Cambodian prime minister has COVID-19.
Explanation: The photo is from 2017; the prime minister was treated for something else.

What did you fact-check?: Beef meat is the best vaccine against COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to prove this.

What did you fact-check?: Election years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.
Explanation: Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors in Japan advise people to drink water every 15 minutes to prevent an infection.
Explanation: The WHO says drinking water does not prevent novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin helps against COVID-19.
Explanation: Health experts told AFP there is insufficient evidence for this claim.

What did you fact-check?: “Every election year has a disease” — SARS in 2004; avian flu in 2008; swine flu in 2010; MERS in 2012; Ebola in 2014 and 2018; Zika in 2016 and the coronavirus in 2020.
Explanation: Most of these diseases were discovered and spread before the election years and were minimally mentioned during campaigns. SARS, avian flu and MERS had virtually no effect on the U.S. during election years.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients in China are caught by officials on a highway.
Explanation: The video shows a mock drill. The China SWAT team in the video is "practicing" how to deal with coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: A man with a gas mask at a supermarket in Lugo (Galicia, Spain).
Explanation: The photo was taken in Austria, not Spain.

What did you fact-check?: It is best to shave your beard to avoid being infected by the coronavirus.
Explanation: Unless you are in contact with people infected by the virus at work, there is no need to shave your beard.

What did you fact-check?: “The coronavirus has made it to Mississippi and the lady that caught it wasn’t around anybody with it, which means it is airborne. If the wind blows it in your direction, you’ll have it also.”
Explanation: According to the CDC and Mississippi, there are no confirmed COVID-19 cases in the state as of 2/28/20. Researchers believe the disease is spread person to person.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is just a big flu.
Explanation: It is too early to make this assumption. Statistics show COVID-19 is not a generic virus.

What did you fact-check?: Clients of a brothel in the Spanish city of Valencia are quarantined after one of their employees tested positive for coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is not true; it is a humor article.

What did you fact-check?: It is possible to self-diagnose by holding your breath for 10 seconds.
Explanation: There is no medical evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: A “poll finds 38% of Americans say they will not drink Corona beer because of the virus.”
Explanation: The poll was conducted by a PR firm which did not release full details about it.

What did you fact-check?: Jackie Chan is quarantined because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: Jackie Chan states that he was not quarantined.

What did you fact-check?: The wife of a Chinese shop owner in Totana (Murcia, Spain) has coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is not true.

What did you fact-check?: Barcelona’s council issued a notification of a new focus in two neighborhoods.
Explanation: The council denied the claim on its Twitter account.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a person infected with coronavirus being detained by the police.
Explanation: This video shows a drill. It was shot 2/21/20 at Henan Tongbai by the police and the emergency response team.

What did you fact-check?: Authorities should implement temperature tests to travelers from China.
Explanation: There is no evidence the tests are precise enough to detect infections with no fever.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese experts warn about a scar in the lung caused by COVID-19. This is more severe than SARS 17 years ago.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this. A Thai medical doctor insists that not every COVID-19 case damages the lungs.

What did you fact-check?: Chloroquine cures COVID-19.
Explanation: Chloroquine showed signs is not a cure for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Airport in Karachi suspends all international arrivals during coronavirus epidemic.
Explanation: Pakistan's civil aviation authority confirmed international arrivals weren't cancelled at the time; photo corresponds with one that circulated about flights suspended at the airport in March 2019

What did you fact-check?: Video shows Chinese officials detaining an infected citizen who refused to be tested.
Explanation: The video shows an exercise, not a real event.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a person infected with coronavirus being detained by the police.
Explanation: This event is not real, it's a drill. It was shot 2/21/19 at Henan Tongbai by the police and the emergency response team.

What did you fact-check?: A “Lithuanian doctor” gives advice to those potentially infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The information is false since instructions to stay at home if infected were not given out by any of the authorities.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Santiago del Estero was confirmed.
Explanation: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Argentina as of 2/27/20.

What did you fact-check?: Health authorities say shaving a beard protects from COVID-19.
Explanation: It's a 2017 graphic about how professionals should wear tight-fitting masks.

What did you fact-check?: A case of coronavirus in the Argentine province of Chaco was confirmed.
Explanation: There are no confirmed cases of coronavirus in Argentina as of 2/27/20.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming alcohol is an effective measure against COVID-19.
Explanation: The post making this claim contains a doctored screenshot from a CNN broadcast.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is not reproducing in warm places.
Explanation: Other coronaviruses have begun to die when the temperature is over 56°C but there are no studies about COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The next thing that we will run short of, following masks, is toilet paper.
Explanation: On Feb.28, the industry association released a statement categorically denying rumours that its production capacity fell (in the wake of the novel coronavirus). "Most (of Japan's) toilet paper and tissue paper are produced in domestic factories, and neither supplies nor production have been impacted by the novel coronavirus," it said.

What did you fact-check?: The German government made a “secret plan” about coronavirus in 2012 that foretold the pandemic.
Explanation: There is no secret plan but a public risk assessment of the German government in 2012 contained a hypothetical epidemic of a fictional coronavirus named Modi-SARS.

What did you fact-check?: Bleach and chlorine can be used to prevent the coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO confirms bleach and other disinfectants might work to kill the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO says the coronavirus might be spread by food.
Explanation: The WHO has no evidence that infections from food are possible.

What did you fact-check?: First case of coronavirus in Alcalá de Henares (Madrid).
Explanation: One screenshot shows a false article created in an app; the other has not been published by El Mundo newspaper.

What did you fact-check?: An Argentinian doctor discovered a vaccine for coronavirus in Spain
Explanation: The statement is false. The man in the attached photo is an actor. The WHO says "there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat" the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Taiwan has severe community transmission. Many people have died.
Explanation: As of 2/27/20, there is no evidence indicating the Taiwan government has hidden real COVID-19 figures or information. The Taiwan Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) has a daily press conference to update the latest confirmed case number and has been transparent.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Gerardo Dovakin found a vaccine against coronavirus.
Explanation: Dovakin is an actor, not a doctor.

What did you fact-check?: A brothel with 86 customers was quarantined after a prostitute tested positive for the coronavirus.
Explanation: This was a satirical comment.

What did you fact-check?: Sevilla’s university has suspended classes because of coronavirus on 2/27/20.
Explanation: The university denied this claim on its Twitter account.

What did you fact-check?: Honduras’s first confirmed case traveled to Taiwan earlier, which means there is a severe community transmission in Taiwan.
Explanation: As of 2/27/20, Honduras has no confirmed cases of COVID-19. A Taiwanese traveler had suspected infection, but tested negative.

What did you fact-check?: El Pais said there is a possible case of coronavirus at the hospital Gregorio Marañón in Spain.
Explanation: El País has not published that article and the typography doesn't match.

What did you fact-check?: An article in El Pais says there is a case of coronavirus at the School of Architecture of Madrid.
Explanation: El País did not publish this article.

What did you fact-check?: Lectures have been suspended at the University of Sevilla due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The university stated the document is false.

What did you fact-check?: A monkey is been infected with the coronavirus in this photo.
Explanation: The photo is a capture of a video taken at least two months before the first COVID-19 symptoms were experienced.

What did you fact-check?: There is a new case of COVID-19 in Sacedón (Spain).
Explanation: The town office denied the claim.

What did you fact-check?: French far right leader Marine Le Pen says the EU didn’t act against the outbreak
Explanation: The EU has activated the civil protection mechanism, launched aid programs, mobilized funds for research and called for more international cooperation and coordination.

What did you fact-check?: Lysol products can kill the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: While Lysol products are advertised to kill 99.9% of bacteria and viruses, including coronavirus, the company is referring to previous strains of the virus. There is no known cure for the novel coronavirus strain.

What did you fact-check?: The cover of a book titled “Tintin in Wuhan” shows the character standing in an old Chinese market wearing special suits, while people are wearing masks.
Explanation: This is a doctored image made from the frames of two different Tintin books.

What did you fact-check?: Iran’s deputy Health Minister: This year we have had 13,200 flu cases which caused the death of 108 people. Our population is a fourth of the U.S. population. Last year, they had 28 million flu cases which resulted in 16,000 deaths. Yet nobody is restricting travel.
Explanation: Flu death rate in the U.S. is less than 0.1% and the deputy minister’s comparison of flu and COVID-19 is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Ministry of Economy and Finance in South Korea and pharmaceutical companies had a secret meeting.
Explanation: There was no meeting.

What did you fact-check?: Each side of protective surgical masks has different functions, indicated by colour, and you should choose the way you wear by whether you are ill or not.
Explanation: This is incorrect. Generally, if they have a coloured side, you should wear your mask with this pointing outward—but always read the manufacturer’s instructions to be sure.

What did you fact-check?: A video accompanying a claim shows bodies being removed from a hospital in Iran during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video has circulated since August 2019 and depicts a funeral procession for pilgrims who died during the annual Islamic pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia's Grand Mosque.

What did you fact-check?: Keeping your throat moist will wash the coronavirus down to your stomach where the virus will die.
Explanation: The WHO and Dr. Norberto Francisco, chief of clinical trials and research at the Lung Center of the Philippines, say drinking water will not prevent a coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: “‘Akira’ is a 1988 movie about an apocalyptic event taking place months before Tokyo 2020 Olympics, showing the WHO advising Japan to postpone the Olympics because of a pandemic risk.”
Explanation: The movie does not include a pandemic and the WHO is never mentioned.

What did you fact-check?: Iran buries coronavirus victims in Iraq; a video from the Najaf Cemetery.
Explanation: Video shows the burial of Iranians who were infected with COVID-19 in Al-Ahwaz cemetery. The video is from 2019, and depicts the burial of Mohamed Nasri who died of CCHF in Al-Ahwaz in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Eat herbs, curmin, like people in India, and you will be safe from COVID-19.
Explanation: This claim has no scientific proof.

What did you fact-check?: Football player Alexis Sanchez is infected with the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Misbar confirmed this statement is false.

What did you fact-check?: Starting in March, if you travel outside of the United States you won’t be allowed back in the country “due to high risk of the coronavirus.”
Explanation: As of 3/6/20, there is no mandate that states Americans are barred from returning to the U.S. from anywhere overseas.

What did you fact-check?: ”America has been vaccinating cattle for coronavirus for years, yet the news tells you it’s new and going to kill you all, so go buy a mask.”
Explanation: The vaccine for cattle won’t help humans and won't protect against this new form of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: “The blood test for coronavirus costs $3,200.”
Explanation: The CDC isn't charging for coronavirus testing but patients could be stuck with associated costs, such as a trip to the emergency room. In Florida, a man who worried he was infected initially faced a $3,270 bill even though he never received a coronavirus test.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water every 10 minutes can send the virus into sthe omach and kill it.
Explanation: The digestive system cannot stop the respiratory system's work and the course of infection.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
Explanation: The WHO hasn't issued an advisory against buying Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China. The claim is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Iranian clerics wear masks after the outbreak.
Explanation: The photo is outdated and manipulated. It was taken at the funeral of Kasem Sulemani.

What did you fact-check?: The outbreak in Taiwan is out of control. President Tsai ordered a corpse burned in front of the presidential office.
Explanation: It is a photo of a self-immolation incident in 2015 in front of the presidential office.

What did you fact-check?: A post says “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explanation: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

What did you fact-check?: Italian Red Cross gives the recipe for making amuchina (hand sanitizer) at home.
Explanation: Italian Red Cross has never shared such a recipe. It could be useful only to disinfect vegetables.

What did you fact-check?: Two cases are confirmed of coronavirus in Huelva, Andalucía (2/26/20)
Explanation: The Andalusian health ministry said there are no coronavirus infections in the Spanish region as of 2/2/6/20.

What did you fact-check?: School has been suspended in Catalonia until 3/2/20.
Explanation: The Catalonian education department did not make this statement

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus was registered in 2004.
Explanation: It was another type of coronavirus that was registered in 2004, not the one that caused the current outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Face masks are a good protection against the coronavirus.
Explanation: Masks are a reliable means of protection only if you are a health professional or are in contact with somebody who is infected.

What did you fact-check?: New cases of coronavirus in Madrid are linked to two universities and a club.
Explanation: The photos about coronavirus were manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: Is it useful to close borders to stop the outbreak?
Explanation: French medical experts say closing borders in order to prevent infected people from entering in France is ineffective. Health tests before entering the country have little effect.

What did you fact-check?: Letters and packages sent from China can cause coronavirus infection.
Explanation: Though some viruses can live for some time on objects like door knobs, the WHO says the new coronavirus cannot live very long in envelopes and boxes.

What did you fact-check?: Hair Weaves And Lace Front Wigs Made In China Likely To Contain coronavirus.
Explanation: There is very little chance of coronavirus spreading this way, and there have not been any reported cases of this happening.

What did you fact-check?: A monkey has been infected with coronavirus in this photo.
Explanation: The photo is a capture of a video taken at least two months before the first cases of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: CDC issued facial hair recommendation for novel coronavirus prevention.
Explanation: Graphic is more than two years old and unrelated to the current outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: You can maintain the alkaline state of the body to avoid contagion.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: There is a confirmed case of coronavirus in a Bogotá hospital.
Explanation: The case was never treated under the suspicion it was coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A “letter” from an uncle in Wuhan claims COVID-19 can be cured with hot water.
Explanation: There is no evidence hot water can cure COVID-19, other facts stated in the said letter are also inaccurate.

What did you fact-check?: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explanation: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

What did you fact-check?: A book published in 1981 said that in 2020 a severe pneumonia-like illness would spread across the world, and calling it “Wuhan-400”.
Explanation: These lines are from two different books

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people convert to Islam because of COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is old, and not related to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Cocaine kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: Fake story was generated by a website that allows people to create their own news stories. This is a previously disproved claim.

What did you fact-check?: Kuwait boycotted the products of the Saudi Almarai Company.
Explanation: Misbar found this claim to be untrue.

What did you fact-check?: A man is allegedly selling medical masks for 80 denars on a bus owned by the Skopje Public Transportation Enterprise.
Explanation: The photo has also been posted on the Facebook page of the site 3minute.net on 2/25/20. According to the status, the photo was taken in the town of Craiova, Romania, and not in Skopje, North Macedonia.

What did you fact-check?: Singapore government said confirmed case No. 12 is a prostitute. As a result, many of her clients are under quarantine.
Explanation: According to the Singapore health ministry, case No. 12 showed symptoms during a family trip in Singapore. The department has not released the occupation of case No. 12.

What did you fact-check?: Multiple allegations around how coronavirus was produced by China.
Explanation: The connection to spies is fictional. No scientific evidence shows the coronavirus was produced as a bioweapon.

What did you fact-check?: My son, who works as a public servant in the Central government, got one box of face masks while the public is restricted to two per week.
Explanation: All public officials of the central government whose duties are not related to disease control are not allowed to apply for official face masks.

What did you fact-check?: “DDP (Democratic Progressive Party) legislator Kao Chia-yu gave my mom two boxes of face masks since DDP has plenty and said the outbreak is out of control.”
Explanation: Legislator Kao denied making such a comment. There are several inaccuracies in the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Photos show many corpses floating in the river in Tainan, a Southern city in Taiwan.
Explanation: They are staged photos from Korean movies "Deranged" and "Train To Busan".

What did you fact-check?: China took advantage of the coronavirus crisis to buy back stocks from its technology companies belonging to foreign investors.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claims in this story, published in 2014. It was not the Chinese but the Russian president at the time, and the emergency was not the coronavirus. The country, the president, the currency and the reason for the emergency were changed.

What did you fact-check?: “Coronavirus: Florida man arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.”
Explanation: The screenshot of “breaking news” is originally from a satirical news site. A news generator watermark is visible in the top right corner, which means the image was created.

What did you fact-check?: The Russian CDC admitted that COVID-19 is human-made.
Explanation: The original document from the Russian health ministry only mentions that COVID-19 is a recombinant virus. It doesn't suggest the COVID-19 is a human-made virus.

What did you fact-check?: The CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.
Explanation: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended shaving beards to ward off the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus patients are being “cremated alive” in China.
Explanation: The Chinese government has ordered the swift cremation of patients who die after contracting the coronavirus. There is no evidence they are being cremated alive.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a road traffic control in China to detect people infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was filmed in China, and is a simulation, not a real incident.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is a bioweapon leaked from a Wuhan lab.
Explanation: Scientists in Wuhan insist there are no links between the virus and labs.

What did you fact-check?: The word “coronavirus” on disinfecting spray reaffirms that the virus was known before the outbreak and could be planned.
Explanation: Coronaviruses have been known for decades. SARS and MERS were caused by coronaviruses. The companies (Lysol, Clorox, etc.) have stated that their products are effective against viruses “similar” to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Bats that hide under Wuhan rooftops caused the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The video was recorded in the U.S. in 2011.

What did you fact-check?: In 1981, the book “The Eyes of Darkness” predicted the spread of the coronavirus.
Explanation: A work of fiction, the book mentions a biological weapon called Wuhan-400 (Originally Gorki-400) that has no similarities to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: China needs coronavirus SWAT (special weapons and tactics) police teams to arrest this coronavirus victim.
Explanation: Video shows a mock drill by Tongbai police practicing to take down coronavirus infected patients if they are uncooperative.

What did you fact-check?: In Poland, people who are not insured have to pay for coronavirus testing, so if they can’t afford it, they will spread it.
Explanation: Anyone who is suspected of having coronavirus will have a medical examination free of charge, regardless of insurance.

What did you fact-check?: A crowd is waiting to greet Colombians living in Wuhan who are being flown to Bogotá.
Explanation: The images are from 2018, when crowds gathered to meet the Colombian National Football Team after the World Cup in Russia.

What did you fact-check?: Indian Government and the WHO advised people not to purchase colors from China for Holi.
Explanation: No such advisory was shared by the government or the Ministry.

What did you fact-check?: Infected taxi driver demands money from his government otherwise he’ll infect others.
Explanation: Story originated from a parody account, no driver is threatneing to spread covid-19 across Nigeria.

What did you fact-check?: Photos show Muslims in Italy praying outside because of the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The photos originated long before the COVID-19 outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Holding your breath lets you check if you have coronavirus.
Explanation: Infected people should still be able to hold their breath for 20 seconds.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus infects chickens in Pakistan.
Explanation: Authorities say it's related to another disease.

What did you fact-check?: “Hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
Explanation: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

What did you fact-check?: These images have previously circulated in reports about an elderly Chinese couple who had unrelated health problems.
Explanation: The claim is misleading; the images have previously circulated in reports which stated they were an elderly Chinese couple suffering from health problems unrelated to the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was found in horses.
Explanation: Technically true since horses can be infected with a coronavirus, but not the SARS-CoV-2.

What did you fact-check?: Infected taxi driver demands money from his government or he’ll infect others.
Explanation: No driver is threatening to spread COVID-19 across Nigeria.

What did you fact-check?: These are measures that protect from novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Health experts refute new claims about coronavirus prevention in Sri Lanka.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese accept Islam en masse (20 million).
Explanation: Video was published with misleading header. After fact-checking, some authors changed descriptions for their videos.

What did you fact-check?: President Trump claims the virus is under control and testing is available.
Explanation: This information from the president over two months has been confusing and contradictory.

What did you fact-check?: China gets meat from the dead bodies of coronavirus victims and transports it to Africa.
Explanation: The photos are from different sources

What did you fact-check?: Bats that hide under Wuhan rooftops caused the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The video was filmed in Miami in 2011.

What did you fact-check?: A 1981 book predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: It is not a prediction.

What did you fact-check?: The mortality rate for the flu is “right around” that of the new coronavirus: “It’s right around 2%.”
Explanation: The mortality rate for the flu is considered by most experts to be about 0.1%. Estimates for the mortality rate for coronavirus are currently around 2%, but this number could change depending on how cases are diagnosed.

What did you fact-check?: A vaccine for COVID-19 has been found.
Explanation: Chinese ambassador to Russia announced progress is being made, but there is no vaccine for COVID-19 yet.

What did you fact-check?: It is a weird and unusual year; an ice tsunami occurred on Xingkai Lake in Heilongjiang.
Explanation: The video of the ice tsunami was filmed at River Yenisei in Dudinka, Russia, in June 2019. It was not filmed in China.

What did you fact-check?: The DPP (Democratic Progressive Party) politician Wang Shijian said Taiwan has more than 500 confirmed cases.
Explanation: The DPP councilor Wang Shijian denied making the statement. As of 2/25/20, Taiwan has 31 confirmed cases and one death.

What did you fact-check?: An armored vehicle was so full of corpses that it slipped off a trailer.
Explanation: The photo shows an armored vehicle accident in Taichung.

What did you fact-check?: Evidence indicates COVID-19 escaped a Chinese lab that was researching it, causing the outbreak.
Who said/posted it?: Steven W. Mosher, New York Post
Explanation: Multiple scientific studies have indicated the virus has a natural origin, and is not the result of human engineering.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows the suspected infected people in eastern Turkey, Van.
Explanation: The video is not new. There is no COVID-19 case in Turkey as of 2/24/20.

What did you fact-check?: Taiwanese manufacturing is awesome. One machine can produce 2.5 million face masks per day.
Explanation: According to the Taiwanese Economy Ministry, each production line of face mask produces around 100,000 masks per day.

What did you fact-check?: “The coronavirus is the common cold, folks.”
Explanation: The 2019 coronavirus is a new virus that had not been previously identified.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus in Parabiago e Nerviano (Lombardia, Italy)
Explanation: There are no cases as of 2/24/20.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is present at Bosch company in Bari (Puglia) because Chinese people visited the week before.
Explanation: There are no cases as of 2/24/20.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus in Sant’Egidio (Abruzzo, Italy).
Explanation: There are no cases as of 2/24/20.

What did you fact-check?: There are two coronavirus cases in Bovalino (Reggio Calabria, Italy).
Explanation: There are no cases as of 2/24/20.

What did you fact-check?: The link between COVID-19 and 5G is being hidden.
Explanation: The link does not exist.

What did you fact-check?: A 1981 book predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The book does talk about a virus called Wuhan-400, but it's not the same as COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese SWAT Team takes down a coronavirus suspect
Explanation: A mock drill video was shared as China committing atrocities on its patients.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus case in Uttar Pradesh district, India.
Explanation: Authorities deny there is a case.

What did you fact-check?: Shoppers in China storm supermarket after coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The video has circulated since at least October 2019, two months before the viral outbreak was first reported.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people convert to Islam because of COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is from May 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Radio host Rush Limbaugh compares novel coronavirus to “the common cold.”
Explanation: Experts say the new coronavirus is more deadly than the viruses that can cause a cold.

What did you fact-check?: A book by D.Koontz, “The Eyes of Darkness,” predicted COVID-19 in 1981.
Explanation: The first edition of the book mentioned the (imaginary) virus was invented by the Russians, not the Chinese.

What did you fact-check?: Photos of the Korean delegation infected with coronavirus in Palestine.
Explanation: Misbar verified the allegations and found that the delegation visited Palestine last January, according to the assurances of the tourer of the delegation, Ahmed Amayreh, which prompted some news sites, such as Ramallah News, to delete the photos and apologize.

What did you fact-check?: Map of the spread of coronavirus In the coming months.
Explanation: The map in unreliable. Misbar investigated and found it to be from Worldpop organization.

What did you fact-check?: Many corpses from South Taiwan were sent to Taichung to burn. Taiwan has a serious community infection.
Explanation: The number of cremations in Taiwan hasn't increased significantly since the COVID-19 outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: A Facebook status from 2012 talked about the spread of coronavirus in 2020.
Explanation: The Facebook status was updated on 1/27/20.

What did you fact-check?: Years ago, there was a hand sanitizer active against Sars-Cov-2.
Explanation: The hand sanitizer is active against coronavirus in general. There is no specific sanitizer against Sars-Cov-2, according to the manufacturing company.

What did you fact-check?: Ketamine can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that Ketamine can prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows an anti-China protest amid the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy.
Explanation: The video shows a march in Rome to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the assassination of Valerio Verbano, an Italian left-wing activist murdered in 1980.

What did you fact-check?: Person who fainted at a subway station has COVID-19.
Explanation: It was not COVID-19; it was another disease.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows an Iranian man running after a cleric claiming to be infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video has been published on Facebook since July 2017.

What did you fact-check?: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus.
Explanation: The predictions of Nostradamus are not correctly translated. Even if Nostradamus truly predicted a “plague," the title says it is taking place in a seaside town. The coronavirus originated in the city of Wuhan, China, which is not a seaside town.

What did you fact-check?: Pigs are buried alive due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is not recent and has nothing to do with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: According to a study the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 was the result of experiements done in a lab located near the market in Wuhan.
Who said/posted it?: Various local news sites and blogs
Explanation: The hypothesis that SARS-CoV-2 is a lab made virus in the context presented by the articles in question is based on an opinion piece that does not constitute a scientific study. All the evidence thus far suggest that the new coronavirus was the result of natural mutation.

What did you fact-check?: Author Dean Koontz foresaw the coronavirus outbreak in his book.
Explanation: There is no connection between the fictional virus in the book and the current COVID-19 outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Video says President Donald Trump spawned the “Wuhan super virus outbreak under code name ‘zyphr.’”
Explanation: There is no evidence that President Trump had anything to do with the creation of the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates wrote a letter saying COVID-19 is teaching humans a lesson.
Explanation: The story was retracted and the letter was fake.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has arrived in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Explanation: There is no confirmation of this information.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people are fleeing China to Vietnam because of coronavirus.
Explanation: People are going from Vietnam to China for work.

What did you fact-check?: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: A post claiming that four individuals in Zanzibar died from COVID-19 after handling a diseased chicken is false. It contains images of a diseased chicken that circulated in other countries claiming to show symptoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Six coronavirus cases confirmed in Wichita, Kansas.
Explanation: No cases have been confirmed there as of 2/21/20.

What did you fact-check?: A suspicious case of coronavirus in a Military Hospital in Maracay originated with an Army member who claimed have visited China in December.
Explanation: The journalist was misinformed. Every source said the patient was never suspected or examined for coronavirus because he came from Chine a month and a half ago.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows racist reactions toward Asian people.
Explanation: They are actors.

What did you fact-check?: These charts show the difference betweem COVID-19, flu and common cold.
Explanation: Charts include inaccurate information about symptoms by claiming people suffering from the novel coronavirus do not develop some symptoms seen in flu or common cold patients such as a runny or stuffy nose, a sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea and muscle pain.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO considers canceling the Mecca pilgrimage.
Explanation: The WHO did not cancel it.

What did you fact-check?: This map shows high sulphur dioxide in Wuhan now due to the burning of corpses.
Explanation: The forecasts are based on past emissions.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese people flee to Vietnam due to COVID-19.
Explanation: The video is from November 2019.

What did you fact-check?: This is artwork from Wuhan.
Explanation: It is from another city, Shandong.

What did you fact-check?: The Japanese government has been refusing to use and introduce a gene test kit manufacturered by Swiss-based pharmaceutical company Roche which is currently in use around the world due to its convenience of use. This is believed to be because the Ministry of Health has already allocated the budget to public project set up to develop their own new tests. If we had used the Roche test kits since day one, we could have prevented the outbreak on the cruise ship.”
Explanation: It is true the Roche test kits were initially unavailable in Japan.  However they are now in use as of mid-Feb. This has been confirmed by an official at the Ministry of Health, and in a manual written by National Institute of Infectious Diseases in Japan.

What did you fact-check?: Post says “people of color may be immune to the coronavirus because of melanin.”
Explanation: Melanin is a natural pigment that gives color to skin and eyes. It does not make you any less susceptible to the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows Chinese officials detaining suspected coronavirus cases.
Explanation: The video shows a police drill in China during the novel coronavirus epidemic.

What did you fact-check?: A child who died in Damascus was infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The director general of Al-Mujtahid Hospital in Damascus, Dr. Samer Khadr, denied any cases of COVID-19 infection.

What did you fact-check?: The Simpsons predicted the new coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: An image from the show was altered to read “coronavirus."

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese man has been lynched because he pretended to have the coronavirus.
Explanation: The man was Philippine, not Chinese. He was lynched because other people thought he could spread the coronavirus in their city.

What did you fact-check?: The drug Arbidol can help fight the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The drug Arbidol (also known as Umifenovir) is a cure for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Social media posts claim Chloroquine, an antimalarial drug, can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: No health authorities have confirmed Chloroquine as a cure for coronavirus. According to WHO Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, results of drug trials are not expected soon. The “malarial chloroquine used in China was not one of the drugs.”

What did you fact-check?: Chinese businessman Guo Wengui multiple allegations on coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation:
- The outbreak was not a disaster in the mid of December. 
- The disease did not spread in US quickly after 18th of Feb. 
- Death rate is being updated day by day; not always same. 
- Wuhan's hospital capacity rise doesn't show the real number of infected. 
- Isolation centers in Wuhan are not concentration camps.

What did you fact-check?: Iraqi Ministry of Health demanded to close the border With Iran because of coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is not true.

What did you fact-check?: The State of Qatar did not report any COVID-19 infections.
Explanation: The Ministry of Public Health in Qatar announced the registration of a confirmed case of respiratory syndrome in the Middle East for a 65-year-old.

What did you fact-check?: Mosques across China reopened after the coronavirus plague.
Explanation: A video shows worship activities in the Dongguan Mosque, China. It is not confirmed if the mosque was closed or reopened.

What did you fact-check?: 20 million Chinese convert to Islam, and coronavirus does not affect Muslims.
Explanation: The video doesn't feature Chinese people, but rather Filipino men. Video footage predates major coronavirus reports.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese converting to Islam after realizing that no Muslim was affected by COVD19 in the country.
Explanation: The video has been available since June 2019 and has no relation to the current outbreak of coronavirus in China.

What did you fact-check?: Evacuation of Yemeni students by the Sultan of Oman in China.
Explanation: The claim is verified to be fake.

What did you fact-check?: Cannabis boosts immunity against COVID-19
Explanation: There is no evidence to suggest that cannabis improves immunity against the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Those are corpses on the street in Wuhan.
Explanation: The video actually shows people sleeping in the street in Shenzhen.

What did you fact-check?: Rainbow shimmers behind a COVID-19 disinfectant truck in China.
Explanation: The photo is from March 2019.

What did you fact-check?: In a video, a Chinese epidemiologist says there are millions infected.
Explanation: Same case of this Newtral verification

What did you fact-check?: This is Dr. Li-wen Liang’s funeral ceremony.
Explanation: Dr. Li-wen died on 2/7/20. The video was uploaded on 11/19/18.

What did you fact-check?: The amount of ACE2 East Asian people have is 4-5 times more than non-East-Asians. That is why they get infected easily.
Explanation: The claim quoted a 2005 study regarding SARS, not COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The 2008 book “End of Days” predicted the current coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Dean Koontz, not Sylvia Browne, wrote about “Wuhan-400”.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese are converting to Islam after realizing that no Muslim was affected by COVID-19 in the country.
Explanation: The viral video is old and not related to coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is a biological warfare weapon.
Explanation: Dr. Francis Boyle said coronavirus is a biological warfare weapon, but there is no context or supporting evidence. It was debunked as a rumor.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese police kill a woman escaping a COVID-19 quarantine in China.
Explanation: The scene shows a motorbike accident.

What did you fact-check?: World labs confirm coronavirus was bioengineered.
Explanation: There is no evidence of this.

What did you fact-check?: African skin and blood is resistant to coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence to suggest "black people’s" immunity to the virus, or “white people’s” vulnerability to it. According to the WHO, anyone in proximity to an infected person is at risk of contracting COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: In Nigeria, Ibrahim Magu, acting EFCC chairman, said corruption caused the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: According to the WHO, COVID-19 is a disease. Health authorities surmise it emanated from the wet markets in China as a zoonotic disease. No evidence suggests it is related to moral misconduct or the activities of corrupt individuals.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows corpses on the streets of Wuhan.
Explanation: The video of Shenzhen shows people from Hubei sleeping in the streets because no one wants to rent them a roll.

What did you fact-check?: In Japan, if the new coronavirus test is negative, the cost is 80,000 yen. If positive, the state will bear the cost.
Explanation: No voluntary testing of the new coronavirus has been performed. The test is "when it is determined that the prefecture is necessary based on travel history and contact history with patients." In this case, the test cost is public expense regardless of negative or positive, and it is "free."

What did you fact-check?: 11 out of 13 people (from the Diamond Princess Cruise ship) who had intially tested negative in tests in Japan, were later confirmed to be positive in the United States.
Explanation: Of the 11 people who disembarked from the cruise ship Diamond Princess and tested positive upon return to the United States, nine had also tested positive in Japanese tests too, and another 2 had results that were not conclusively negative.

What did you fact-check?: A claim was made that India found a cure to coronavirus
Explanation: The headline of the news article is misleading as India has not officially claimed any such cure for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: People queue in Singapore for Halal food.
Explanation: They are queuing for masks.

What did you fact-check?: There is no way to forbid religious gatherings temporarily in South Korea to prevent the virus from spreading.
Explanation: They can be forbidden by the Korean infectious disease prevention law.

What did you fact-check?: Seven children died from coronavirus within one week in Karimganj (Assam, India).
Explanation: Public health officials have denied any coronavirus deaths. The children died in a span of two months due to fever and other illnesses.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking alcohol kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: Drinking alcohol does not cure coronavirus. Alcohol in sanitizers does have an effect on the virus.

What did you fact-check?: This map shows movement of Wuhan residents worldwide.
Explanation: The map has been shared in a misleading context; it actually shows a route map of flight paths around the world.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows the late Chinese doctor Li-wen Liang’s wedding party.
Explanation: The video shows the wedding of a Taiwanese couple and was filmed in Taiwan.

What did you fact-check?: In the midst of the health emergency due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the image of what appears to be a hospital emergency room was shared. The images show that at least three patients are treated on the floor, since all beds are occupied by other patients.
Explanation: The photograph was captured 6 years ago in Venezuela.

What did you fact-check?: Studies show the coronavirus was engineered to be a bioweapon.
Explanation: The same studies show how coronavirus strains have an evolutionary, not engineered, relationship.

What did you fact-check?: Police or military prepare for total containment in Canada.
Who said/posted it?: Text messages and Messenger direct messages
Explanation: Police and army confirmed this information is false.

What did you fact-check?: A quarantined person fled from a facility in Daegu South Korea.
Explanation: The photos were manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: An elderly Chinese couple infected with coronavirus say goodbye while they are in a hospital.
Explanation: The elderly couple was hospitalized for other conditions including lung cancer and respiratory failure.

What did you fact-check?: India has developed a treatment for coronavirus.
Explanation: India has not developed a treatment.

What did you fact-check?: A video says “the coronavirus was invented and patented in the USA and then planted in China.”
Explanation: There is no evidence the coronavirus was “invented.”

What did you fact-check?: This coronavirus-infected patient reached to Dr. Vinod Kumar but he wasn’t given the treatment. He was later referred to Bhagalpur. It further states that one should avoid meat and fish for 3 months and wear mask to protect yourself from coronavirus.
Explanation: The post claiming that coronavirus infected patient reached Bihar and is not given treatment is fake. Health authorities dismiss the hoax report. Further, WHO has also not recommended to avoid fish and meat. It recommended thoroughly cooking meat and eggs. Wearing mask is, however, advisable.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks court’s approval to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Massive live-pig burials follow the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explanation: The burials are not new. Chinese government decided to kill pigs after African swine fever in 2018.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese citizens cram for Friday prayer after coronavirus plague.
Explanation: The video is from 2016, before the coronavirus was first reported in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Exactly every 100 years, a viral epidemic breaks out.
Explanation: The epidemics have not arisen exactly 20 years after the beginning of each century.

What did you fact-check?: Taking a hot bath is an effective remedy against COVID-19.
Explanation: Health experts say there is no evidence that bathing in hot water can prevent the virus. The WHO warned that bathing or showering in very hot water can be “harmful."

What did you fact-check?: This bottle of disinfectant gel proves that the coronavirus existed before 2019.
Explanation: Different strains of coronavirus existed years before COVID-19, which explains why the term "coronavirus" is written on the bottle.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a crow attack and a jumbo mosquito in China during the coronavirus plague.
Explanation: The video was edited by combining several different videos and images.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese are converting to Islam to avoid the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is a religious activity carried out by ICDO in the Philippines that circulated on the internet before the coronavirus was first reported in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Having 14 face masks is enough. They can be reused every 14 days since the incubation period is 14 days.
Explanation: Single-use-masks should not be reused.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Chao Chien Kuo from Wuhan Central Hospital said drinking alcohol can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: Dr. Chao Chien Kuo's comment was a joke in his private chat group, not an official recommendation. There is no evidence that drinking alcohol can prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows the late Chinese doctor Li-wen Liang’s wedding party.
20 million Chinese people converted to Islam after it was proven that the coronavirus does not affect Muslims.
Explanation: Video shows Chinese converting to Islam before the first reported case in Wuhan in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is the name of the vaccine against the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: According to information from the WHO, this is a false headline. There is no vaccine yet for the disease.

What did you fact-check?: Cocaine kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: This post is fake.

What did you fact-check?: The Egyptian Minister of Health announced a cure for coronavirus that is extracted from dates.
Explanation: Misbar found that the image was first published on a Facebook page called Kolloh Rayeh, the same page designed with a fabricated image .

What did you fact-check?: Data shows a massive release of sulfur dioxide gas near Wuhan.
Explanation: The images are not satellite measurements, and a member of NASA said the images did not show a significant increase in SO2 measurements.

What did you fact-check?: Swarms of crows attack the streets of Wuhan.
Explanation: The videos are fake.

What did you fact-check?: Popping bubble wrap exposes people to coronavirus.
Explanation: Bubble wrap is not produced by people blowing air into the plastic.The claim is false.

What did you fact-check?: Cuban medicine cures COVID-19.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: There is a COVID-19 case in Ethiopia.
Explanation: There is no case in Ethiopia as of 2/17/20.

What did you fact-check?: Latest research by Chinese scientists said coronavirus will render most male patients infertile.
Explanation: The study has not been peer-reviewed and does not say coronavirus will definitely cause infertility in men.

What did you fact-check?: There is a COVID-19 case in east Indian state.
Explanation: The local health authority said there are no confirmed novel coronavirus patients in the area as of 2/17/20.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a massive explosion in Wuhan, China, to control the spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video dates back to 2015 when there were giant explosions at the Chinese port of Tianjin. The video has no connection with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Consuming magnesium chloride, sodium bicarbonate, ginger and lemon juice prevents coronavirus infection.
Explanation: No health organization has recommended consuming these products to prevent coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Bus driver in China vomits blood after becoming unconscious behind the wheel.
Explanation: The video dates back to 2015 when a driver in Xiamen, China, was suffering from gastrointestinal bleeding.

What did you fact-check?: Australian couple quarantined onboard Diamond Princess cruise reveal wine drone delivery story.
Explanation: The claim that a couple quarantined on a cruise is false; the couple later told an Australian radio station that their social media posts about the wine delivery were a "prank".

What did you fact-check?: A video claims to show an Eid prayer in China in December 2019.
Explanation: This was a prayer in China in June 2019, unrelated to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The video of a flock of crows was shot in Wuhan, China.
Explanation: A claim stated that these crows were recorded in Wuhan, China; however, the images were recorded in the parking lot of a shopping center in the state of Washington, in the United States.

What did you fact-check?: The novel coronavirus only survives in cold weather and hot ginger tea or salabat can cure COVID-19.
Explanation: The WHO said COVID-19 has spread in countries "with both hot and humid climates, as well as cold and dry.” It also said there remains to be “no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat the novel coronavirus.”

What did you fact-check?: Video shows quarantined people in a building in Shanghai.
Explanation: The video shows tower blocks in Shanghai, not Wuhan – and the clip has been edited to include the audio

What did you fact-check?: Thailand cures COVID-19 with anti-HIV drugs.
Explanation: Thai doctors say their treatment helped a coronavirus patient recover, but it was not a "cure."

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus outbreak in Georgia is caused by the EU-Georgia Association Agreement.
Explanation: Scientists agree that the SARS-CoV-2 is not a man-made virus and it originated in animals - most likely in bats.

What did you fact-check?: Africans are more resistant to COVID-19.
Explanation: Dr. Ngumbau Kitheka, a resident doctor at the Kenyatta National Hospital, told PesaCheck there is no scientific evidence to suggest black people have a better chance of fighting the virus, stating that the disease is likely to affect those with weaker immune systems.

What did you fact-check?: Upon approval from Supreme People’s Court, China will kill 20,000 patients with novel coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no such case being tried at the Supreme People’s Court of China. The high court’s record of scheduled hearings does not show that it was set to decide on such a case on 2/7/20.

What did you fact-check?: High levels of sulfur dioxide in Wuhan “may be a sign of mass cremations of victims of the coronavirus.”
Explanation: The photo shows sulfur dioxide projections. It is not a real-time satellite image.

What did you fact-check?: New confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Kolkatta reported by Press Trust of India.
Explanation: There are no confirmed coronavirus patients in Kolkata, as confirmed both by the airport authority of Kolkata and the Traveller.

What did you fact-check?: Two videos say that in Ibagué there are cases of COVID-19 and that the Colombian government is covering it up.
Explanation: This information is false.

What did you fact-check?: A large amount of sulfur dioxide was observed in Wuhan because up to 14,000 bodies were incinerated.
Explanation: The source of the information is "Windy.com", but even if the body was burned, "Windy.com" does not show real-time sulfur dioxide.

What did you fact-check?: China declares nuclear war on America.
Explanation: The claim is false, with no basis in the Chinese official or international media.

What did you fact-check?: The map is “based on traces of Wuhan citizens,” between the outbreak of the new coronavirus and the blockade of Wuhan.
Explanation: This map is an image showing the routes of passenger aircraft around the world, and is not "based on traces of movement"

What did you fact-check?: China has announced the success of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Health Minister of Egypt, against coronavirus
Explanation: The WHO says there is no known cure or vaccine for the coronavirus at this time.

What did you fact-check?: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte orders state hospital to accept COVID-19 patients from Wuhan.
Explanation: Duterte’s speeches have made no mention of PGH being used for Chinese patients with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: China has announced the sucess of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Ealth Miniter of Egypt, against coronavirus
Explanation: WHO says there is no known cure of vaccine to the coronavirus for now.

What did you fact-check?: An “official” mask to combat the novel coronavirus was released.
Explanation: The mask for sale is the Monata reusable dust pollution mask, which is used for woodworking, house cleaning, gardening and other outdoor activities.

What did you fact-check?: Black skin is resistant to coronavirus.
Explanation: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory and experts have already denied it.

What did you fact-check?: Cloud and rain from Wuhan brought the virus to Taiwan.
Explanation: COVID-19 spreads from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth when an infected person coughs or exhales. coronavirus can't survive in clouds.

What did you fact-check?: This burned building is a place of coronavirus patient isolation.
Explanation: The burning building was an apartment in California Park, Yubei District, Chongqing City on 1/1/20, not a hotel where COVID-19 patients were isolated.

What did you fact-check?: SO2 map proves the massive human cremation in Wuhan.
Explanation: Calculations about the possible sulfur burning and certain degree of air pollution are inconsistent.

What did you fact-check?: This photo is a “chinese tapa”¨from a bat.
Explanation: The photo is not of a Chinese dish, but of a soup from Guam island (United States).

What did you fact-check?: The windy diagram of sulfur dioxide emission level over Wuhan indicated massive corpses burning there.
Explanation: Fa-lun Gong media and other outlets published news about this topic.

What did you fact-check?: A residential building was set on fire in Wuhan to control spread of coronavirus.
Explanation: A fire broke out in a different city in China, and officials said the fire had no connection to the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: High-rise buildings have become human incinerators to combat the spread of the coronavirus.
Explanation: There was no concrete evidence to prove that buildings were being burned to stop coronavirus. The source is not credible.

What did you fact-check?: Sulfur dioxide pollution in Wuhan reveals that China is burning bodies of victims.
Explanation: The map is not a real-time air quality report, but a forecast based on past datas, which therefore cannot take account of alleged recent events.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows police killing COVID-19 affected people in China.
Explanation: The video was edited with three unrelated clips. Yiwu Police have clarified that the armed police in the video were on duty to kill a rabid dog. The last clip is related to an accident.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO declared COVID-19 is the abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus in December 2019.
Explanation: The WHO declared the official name of coronavirus as COVID-19, which stands for coronavirus disease.

What did you fact-check?: People in Wuhan are locked inside their houses trying to escape a building fire.
Explanation: The fire was caused by faulty electrical wiring. The video is not related to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a Chinese epidemiologist saying there are millions of people infected.
Explanation: The epidemiologist said if the Chinese Government had not taken action, there would be millions infected by the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows crows are flocking to Wuhan.
Explanation: This video shows crows in the Chinese city of Xining, 1,000 miles from Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: A video claims to show Chinese Muslims performing a communal Friday prayer in a mosque despite the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explanation: The claim is false. The video is from the western Chinese city of Xining in 2011, nine years before the novel coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking much hot water can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this.

What did you fact-check?: A map shows hundreds of thousands of Wuhan residents (or even 5 million of them) traveling out of the city before the lockdown.
Who said/posted it?: Tweet by a research group at University of Southampton. Later many news outlets in UK and Australia
Explanation: The map is “an illustrative picture of the global air network” that shows international flight connections.

What did you fact-check?: Nan-shan Zhong said there is no vegetarian getting COVID-19.
Explanation: No such statement has been made. There is no evidence to support it.

What did you fact-check?: Someone from Bosnia and Herzegovina was captured on the Diamond Princess cruiser in quarantine. After testing negative for coronavirus, he returned to BiH.
Explanation: This man was not on the cruiser, was not quarantined and was not tested for the virus.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese news website Tencent filters that there are more than 24,000 deaths from coronavirus.
Explanation: Tencent denied that information and said doctored images circulated on social media featuring false information they never published

What did you fact-check?: Weed kills the coronavirus.
Explanation: Weed does not kill the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Claims of cannibalism in China: People are cutting a baby in order to eat it.
Explanation: The image shows an autopsy on a baby.

What did you fact-check?: There is a Cuban drug used in China against the coronavirus.
Explanation: Story cites the president and the Cuban embassy in China claiming this medicine is being used by the Health Secretary in China, but there is no proof and Interferón 2B has other uses.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown.
Explanation: The video does not show a family killed by the coronavirus. The family reportedly died from carbon monoxide poisoning in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Satellite images show increase in SO2 emissions around Wuhan.
Explanation: Images were from a weather forecast, based on historical data and meteorological conditions. There is no use of real-time data.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 means “China Outbreak Virus.”
Explanation: COVID-19 means coronavirus disease.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 was caused by 5G antennas.
Explanation: There is no proof the 5G network is related to the outbreak of novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A video claims to show a plane carrying medical supplies to China.
Explanation: The video shows a plane in Kenya carrying humanitarian aid bound for China.

What did you fact-check?: Boiled ginger can cure COVID-19
Explanation: Doctors deny this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Ginger can cure and protect you from COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no scientific proof.

What did you fact-check?: China orders citizens to abandon/kill their pets as they can transmit coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proof that Chinese authorities have ordered the killing of pets. There is proof that some Chinese authorities have approved killings of stray dogs and cats in order to stop the spread of the virus. The WHO says there is no evidence that the virus can be transmitted through pets.

What did you fact-check?: Video of police killing COVID-19 affected people in China.
Explanation: The video was edited with three unrelated clips. Yiwu Police have clarified that the armed police in the video were on duty to kill a rabid dog. The last clip is related to an accident.

What did you fact-check?: Chicken infected from coronavirus found In Bangalore.
Explanation: The image is old and not related to the 2019 novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was created in a lab in Wuhan.
Explanation: No scientific evidence supports that the coronavirus was created in a lab. According to the WHO, “Both Chinese and external expert groups are working in trying to identify the animal source of this new virus.”

What did you fact-check?: In a voice note, a pilot greets from the airport of San José del Guaviare and says that he is in quarantine along with other people, between 18 and 22. They arrived in that city by plane and were diagnosed with the coronavirus.
Explanation: Audio includes an alleged pilot infected with the new coronavirus, but there is no confirmed case in Colombia.

What did you fact-check?: In Japan, Okinawa Prefecture Governor Tamaki Denny was seen Kachashi dancing with the mayor of Nanjo City. It was reported that “the governor and the mayor danced while the people were terrified about the new coronavirus infection.”
Explanation: It is true that Governor Tamaki danced Kachashi with Mayor Zukeran on 1/25/20, but before a cruise ship anchored in Naha.

What did you fact-check?: The Pinol brand of disinfectant is the solution to the coronavirus.
Explanation: COVID-19 was discovered at the end of 2019 and cleaners have not proven effective against this virus.

What did you fact-check?: Philippines has issued an order mandating a compulsory quarantine for all travelers returning from 23 countries.
Explanation: Philippine authorities did not issue this warning after the novel coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: USPS stops accepting items for China and Hong Kong
Explanation: USPS said on 2/12/20 it would continue to accept items bound for China and Hong Kong but could temporarily not offer time guarantees on those shipments. It clarified that it will temporarily halt its transit service that ships mail from other countries to China and Hong Kong.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows crows in the Chinese city of Xining.
Explanation: Alongside the video was a claim saying that the crows in this video were in Wuhan, China following the outbreak; this video is misleading because it shows crows in a Xining, a city which is 1,000 miles away from Wuhan

What did you fact-check?: Black people are more resistant to COVID-19.
Explanation: Dakar's Institut Pasteur denies the claim.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water and keeping your throat moist can prevent the novel coronavirus from attaching to your throat.
Who said/posted it?: Philippines Health Secretary Francisco Duque III
Explanation: The WHO said drinking water, while good for overall health, does not prevent coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: Using cocaine kills the coronavirus
Explanation: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. In fact, there is still no cure for the COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: A video clip shows the killing of people infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: The clip is fabricated and made up of three non-related clips.

What did you fact-check?: Epidemics spread in the 20th year every 100 years.
Explanation: This allegation is false.

What did you fact-check?: Satellite images showing high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
Explanation: This is a forecast based on historical data.

What did you fact-check?: Putting an onion in your room can help prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Bats responsible for the outbreak of coronavirus originated from the rooftop of a house in Wuhan.
Explanation: The video is about nine years old and is from Miami, USA.

What did you fact-check?: This is a person with coronavirus in Calella, Barcelona (2/13/20).
Explanation: This is denied by health authorities.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese government requests the Supreme People’s Court for permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the disease
Explanation: China has not sought the permission of the country's Supreme People's Court to execute 20,000 coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Hold your breath for 10 seconds; if you are able to do this, you are not infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim. People must have a test conducted by hospitals or legitimate labs to determine infection with COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: China scientist Ms. Shih generated coronavirus.
Explanation: A SARS-like cluster of circulating bat coronaviruses shows potential for human emergence.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.
Who said/posted it?: Andrew W. Saul, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service
Explanation: Maintaining an adequate intake of vitamin C is important for staying healthy. However, evidence from clinical trials shows that regular vitamin C supplementation does not prevent viral respiratory tract infections such as the common cold, which can be caused by coronaviruses, in the general population. Although some studies have shown a reduced incidence of the common cold in individuals undergoing severe physical stress, such as marathon runners.

What did you fact-check?: Hand sanitizer form 2010 is labeled against COVID-19.
Explanation: The hand sanitizer marked in 2010 was designed for general coronavirus and is now related to COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Germans quarantined in La Gomera by the coronavirus leave home isolation without permission.
Explanation: The Ministry of Health of the Canary Islands denies they have returned to Germany.

What did you fact-check?: “THE CHINESE HAVE BEGUN TO USE THEIR HUMAN CORPSE TO PROCESS INTO PRODUCTS SUCH AS CORNED BEEF TO SHIP TO AFRICA. Please share with your contacts. Very important”
Explanation: The video might be of Tibet or China’s Sichuan as residents of both these territories perform such rituals. However, it is unknown if the visuals in this video belong to Sky Burial. The video is not related to the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese elderly couple infected with coronavirus says goodbye while they are in a hospital.
Explanation: The elderly couple was hospitalized for other conditions including lung cancer and respiratory failure.

What did you fact-check?: China is seeking court’s approval to kill 20,000 people positive with coronavirus
Explanation: There is no evidence for the claim that the Chinese court had ordered to kill the 20,000 patients affected with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C and Omega prevent the new coronavirus.
Explanation: They cannot prevent coronavirus infection.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus arrives in Colombia.
Explanation: The Wuhan coronavirus was found in a patient in the town of Ibagué, Colombia, with a written diagnosis. The image shows a different coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus cases reported in Rome, Georgia.
Explanation: The medical facility issued a statement saying there was no confirmed case.

What did you fact-check?: There are two COVID-19 cases in Libreville, Gongo.
Explanation: Authorities deny this.

What did you fact-check?: Raúl Rodolfo Abhuz Khan, a biochemical engineer from Karmalah laboratories, created the coronavirus.
Explanation: The screenshot used to "denounce" the "multi-million dollar pharmaceutical business" behind the coronavirus. The news was not published and the man in the photo is Raúl Álvarez (Auronplay), a well-known Spanish youtuber.

What did you fact-check?: Videos state that 25,000 Chinese are being killed.
Explanation: Three different videos -- two unrelated to the coronavirus and one with overlaid music -- are combined with false claims.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese supreme court OK’d euthanasia for 20,000 people.
Explanation: China has made no such announcement.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is more deadly than Ebola or HIV.
Explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. The post’s claim that coronavirus is the most deadly disease in history is not correct. Global fatalities for HIV and Ebola are far higher, figures from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show.

What did you fact-check?: China killed COVID-19 patients because it couldn’t find a cure.
Explanation: There is no evidence of COVID-19 patients by China being killed. The video is formed of 3 clips

What did you fact-check?: This is how to test your lung for COVID-19 self-check.
Explanation: It is a general lung test, not a specific test for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.
Who said/posted it?: Andrew W. Saul, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service
Explanation: Maintaining an adequate intake of vitamin C is important for staying healthy. However, evidence from clinical trials shows that regular vitamin C supplementation does not prevent viral respiratory tract infections such as the common cold, which can be caused by coronaviruses, in the general population. Some studies have shown a reduced incidence of the common cold in individuals undergoing severe physical stress, such as marathon runners.

What did you fact-check?: Silver Solution used on strains of coronavirus “totally eliminates it. Kills it. Deactivates it.”
Explanation: There are no remedies that cure any strain of human coronavirus including COVID-19. Sellman’s "silver solution" and colloidal silver can be harmful.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks court’s approval to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The post is false.

What did you fact-check?: The Sudanese minister did put on a mask while meeting the Chinese ambassador.
Explanation: The original image was posted on the official page of the Sudanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 2/3/20.

What did you fact-check?: Photos show a Chinese man eating “human baby soup” have circulated on social networking platforms. He is seen sitting at a table with a stillborn baby served in front of him.
Explanation: The photos are from a performance art show by Chinese artist Zhu Yu in 2000.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 is officially found in bats.
Explanation: Bats are not "officially” the source of the outbreak; they are “likely” the source.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus antivirus was discovered by Israeli and Chinese doctors.
Explanation: Remdesivir as an antivirus is being pursued in collaboration with various institutions, and is not related to a specific ethnicity or religion.

What did you fact-check?: Thailand is successfully curing coronavirus patients with marijuana.
Explanation: Antiflu and anti-HIV drugs used by doctors in Thailand to treat patients with the coronavirus do not contain cannabis.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus epidemic will disappear in April thanks to the heat, as President Donald Trump said.
Explanation: It's impossible to predict the evolution of the epidemic because this coronavirus is a new strain. Weather probably plays a role, but it remains to be determined.

What did you fact-check?: Miles Kwok: China military admitted that coronavirus is made by China. It is a human-made bio-weapon.
Explanation: Miles Kwok did not mention or suggest that COVID-19 is a human-made bio-weapon.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus-infected chicken has been found in Bengaluru, India.
Explanation: The image is outdated and not related to coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: 20 million Chinese convert to Islam after coronavirus.
Explanation: No Chinese website published this news. The image circulated is the memorial service for the President of the Islamic Association of Shanghai Province in 2018 upon his death. No official party has announced that a large number of Chinese have embraced Islam after the spread of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: “Breaking: UK prepares for full lockdown after hundreds of new cases — Wuhan super virus updates.”
Explanation: Only about a dozen coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the United Kingdom as of 2/11/20.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows coronavirus patients and doctors.
Explanation: The original video is from South Africa, not China.

What did you fact-check?: Cats and dogs can be infected and can contaminate humans with COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that pets such as dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus, say WHO and French medical experts.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese Government requests court permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There is no credible source stating this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Russian doctor taught: washing the nostrils with soap can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that rinsing nostrils has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. There is no specific medicine to prevent or treat COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: In the Chinese city of Shandong, no one gets COVID-19 because it’s full of garlic.
