Explanation: There is no evidence that garlic has protected people from infection with the new coronavirus. There was a confirmed case in Shandong as of 2/11/20.

What did you fact-check?: Overseas Chinese bought flights to ship medical supplies from Melbourne to South China.
Explanation: To ship medical supplies donated by Chinese entrepreneurs in Kenya, the Chinese airline upgraded passengers to business class and used economy class for all donations.

What did you fact-check?: A Chinese pirate movie called “Coronavirus” is sold in Mexico City.
Explanation: The video is a 2013 South Korean film called "Gamgi."

What did you fact-check?: People are lying on the ground in China because they contracted the coronavirus.
Explanation: Video comes from South Africa during a initiation rite at a private school.

What did you fact-check?: Cats and dogs can be infected and can contaminate humans with COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus, according to the WHO and French medical experts.

What did you fact-check?: People in Wuhan are locked inside their houses by the Chinese government.
Explanation: The video shows people in Wuhan offering their respects to the whistleblower, Dr. Li Wenliang.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks approval from the court to kill over 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: No credible news platforms have published this information. There is no such hearing in the supreme court schedule.

What did you fact-check?: Police publicly kill a coronavirus-infected woman in China.
Explanation: The video is not related to coronavirus. The woman in the video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

What did you fact-check?: China orders citizens to abandon/kill their pets as they can transmit coronavirus.
Explanation: Several state outlets have asked citizens not to abandon their pets. There is no evidence local authorities are ordering the killing of pets.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates predicted coronavirus.
Explanation: Bill Gates did not predict the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A person with coronavirus is in Andorra on 2/10/20.
Explanation: As of 2/10/20, there is no confirmed case of coronavirus in Andorra.

What did you fact-check?: Can cannabis cure coronavirus?
Explanation: There is no government mandate, research or WHO comments supporting cannabis as a cure for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A child from China has coronavirus in Galicia, Spain.
Explanation: There are no children infected with coronavirus in Spain at this date, 2/10/20.

What did you fact-check?: There is a case of coronavirus in Andorra.
Explanation: There is no case of coronavirus in Andorra as of 2/10/20.

What did you fact-check?: Special prayer is organized by the Muslim community in China to save people from coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is not related to the recent coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Ecuadorean doctor saves lifes during the Wuhan crisis.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Satellite images show high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
Explanation: The maps are not satellite images, and do not show actual levels of sulphur dioxide. They are forecasts based on historical data and weather patterns.

What did you fact-check?: China officially said the new coronavirus had “confirmed aerosol infection” and that “in short, airborne infections” were spread.
Explanation: Aerosol infections are rare and different from airborne infections.

What did you fact-check?: This photo shows a new coronavirus case in New South Wales.
Explanation: Local authorities denied it.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 was stolen from Canada by Chinese spies and accidentally released in Wuhan.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Hong Kong police are misappropriating face masks for personal use.
Explanation: The photo has been circulating since 2018.

What did you fact-check?: Green chiratta can prevent COVID-19.
Explanation: There is scientific evidence for this.

What did you fact-check?: Pets can contaminate humans.
Explanation: According to the WHO, there is no evidence that dogs or cats can be infected with the new coronavirus. French medical experts confirm that a virus crossing the species barrier is rare.

What did you fact-check?: China sought Supreme Court approval to euthanise 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: This article claimed that China sought the United States Supreme Court to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients; that claim was false. The article was published on a site that has regulary produced hoax reports

What did you fact-check?: Koreans who were on the cruise ship Diamond Princess cannot be brought back.
Explanation: It is possible by negotiating with the government of Japan.

What did you fact-check?: A woman infected with the coronavirus was killed by Chinese police.
Explanation: The woman in the video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

What did you fact-check?: There is a case of coronavirus in Caserta.
Explanation: There is no case of coronavirus in Caserta as of 2/10/20

What did you fact-check?: An Ecuadorian doctor saves lives during the Wuhan crisis.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Crackdown on drunken driving stopped due to risk of COVID-19 transmission
Explanation: The crackdown is ongoing, and a separate operation.

What did you fact-check?: Novel coronavirus came to South Korea through a yellow sandstorm.
Explanation: The virus dies after staying in the air for some time.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is found in broiler chicken.
Explanation: There is no evidence to prove that coronavirus is found in the broiler chickens. The WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic water can cure novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Garlic may have some antimicrobial properties. There is no evidence that eating garlic has protected people from the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The people in this video show coronavirus patients in China.
Explanation: The video shows initiation activities at a secondary school in South Africa.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese citizens join Muslim prayers because of a fear of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was taken during Eid prayer at the Yiwu Mosque, China, in June 2019, before the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak occurred.

What did you fact-check?: In Singapore, Hong Kong people ran into the supermarket in a panic to buy toilet paper.
Explanation: The video was filmed in China and uploaded on 10/4/19.

What did you fact-check?: An apartment in Wuhan went on fire after the owner over-sprayed ethanol. He turned on the heat, causing an explosion.
Explanation: The video was filmed in Chongqing, not in Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: India scientists found that the HIV gene is embedded in COVID-19, China’s bio-weapon.
Explanation: Similarity to unique inserts in the COVID-19 spike protein to HIV-1.

What did you fact-check?: In 2012, a Facebook user predicted coronavirus from China.
Explanation: The Facebook status wasn't original. It was modified on the 1/27/20.

What did you fact-check?: Cannibalism in China has caused the outbreak of a new strain of the coronavirus. A Chinese man is preparing a dead baby for consumption.
Explanation: The photo shows a piece of performance art created by a Chinese artist in 2000.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates predicted coronavirus.
Explanation: Bill Gates didn't predict coronavirus 2019-nCoV

What did you fact-check?: China killed pigs over fear of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: A video says weed kills coronavirus.
Explanation: The news clip was created through a meme generator. The WHO has stated there are no cures for the virus.

What did you fact-check?: In a photo of Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan and Chinese President Xi Jinping, Imran Khan is wearing a mask.
Explanation: The image was edited.

What did you fact-check?: Autopsy reveals a Wuhan doctor was murdered in his sickbed.
Explanation: There is no source cited in this report. Other news outlets confirmed Li Wenliang died from the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Dettol cleaners can kill the coronavirus.
Explanation: The coronavirus causing the current outbreak is new and there is no cure for it.

What did you fact-check?: Lysol disinfectant label says it’s tested against the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is unclear because it refers to a family of viruses.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus “causes sudden death syndrome.”
Explanation: There is no evidence the virus causes sudden death syndrome.

What did you fact-check?: Kazakhstanis burned and smashed Chinese restaurants and homes because of the spread of coronavirus in the country.
Explanation: There is no connection between pogroms and coronavirus. It was an ethnic conflict between Kazakhs and Dungans that arose on domestic grounds

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has been found in broiler chicken.
Explanation: The claim is fake.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows people screaming in Wuhan because they feared the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video shows Wuhan residents whistling and shouting to commemorate Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the virus who died on 2/7/20 after getting infected.

What did you fact-check?: The Department of Health (DOH) and the Bureau of Immigration (BI) “issued a lookout bulletin” for the “arrest and detention” of a Chinese man who “escaped the quarantine area” of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA).
Explanation: The BI clarified in a statement the foreigner's "escape" from NAIA's quarantine area is a hoax. The DOH did not issue an  advisory or bulletin about a foreigner who escaped the quarantine area.

What did you fact-check?: A coronavirus-infected girl was admitted to Badulla Hospital in Sri Lanka.
Explanation: “The girl tested negative for coronavirus; she was treated and then discharged."

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is caused by snakes.
Explanation: There is no proof that snakes have caused the spread of the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Ginger ale is an effective cure for the 2019 novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO said drinking traditional herbal teas is “not specifically recommended as COVID-19 remedies as they are not effective to protect yourself and can even be harmful.”

What did you fact-check?: Government of the Philippines gave out free masks on the streets.
Explanation: The government of the Philippines donated face masks to several organizations but didn't distribute face masks for free on the street as of 2/7/20.

What did you fact-check?: There is a patent for the new coronavirus.
Explanation: A post claims the Pirbright Institute in the UK applied for a patent for the novel coronavirus outbreak, but documents show the institute holds a 2015 patent for avian influenza virus, also a coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO announced that among many medicines, the best coronavirus killer is nicotine.
Explanation: The WHO hasn't made this recommendation. There is no cure for COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited a mosque amid the coronavirus outbreak and asked the people of the Muslim community to pray about present crisis.
Explanation: Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to the mosque is not related to coronavirus. The video is nearly four years old.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus has already existed, even in domestic animals, and there is a vaccine to fight it.
Explanation: Wuhan coronavirus is not related to canine coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Taking chlorine dioxide helps fight coronavirus.
Explanation: Chlorine dioxide does guard against the coronavirus or against other diseases and is harmful.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks court approval to kill over 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the outbreak.
Explanation: There is no evidence that China went to courts seeking such approval.

What did you fact-check?: Tencent revealed the real number of deaths.
Explanation: The screenshot is questionable.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows COVID-19 patients in China.
Explanation: The video shows a school initiation in South Africa.

What did you fact-check?: The Asterix comic books and The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: Coronavirus has been around since the 1960s. The Simpsons image was edited.

What did you fact-check?: This video shows workmen uncovering a bat-infested roof in the US state of Florida in 2011.
Explanation: A video shows bats nesting in the roof; however, the claim is misleading because it has been circulating the internet since July 2011 and actually shows repairs being made to the roof because of a bat-infested house in Miami

What did you fact-check?: A video shows the Vietnam government giving out free face masks on the streets.
Explanation: The video documented a charity event organized by a motorcycle group, not the Vietnam government.

What did you fact-check?: If you have a runny nose or cough, you don’t have COVID-19.
Explanation: Runny nose and dry cough are two symptoms of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Thai department of health published an infographic on how to properly wear face masks.
Explanation: Ministry of Health denied this.

What did you fact-check?: A doctor said coronavirus can be alive in temperatures of 25-26C. Drinking hot water can help prevent it.
Explanation: Coronavirus can be active in temperatures of 25-26C. Drinking hot water does not prevent it.

What did you fact-check?: Professor Wong Kin-Chung offers tips to delay the progress of COVID-19: Rinse mouth with cold salty water; drink water and red wine; take Vitamin C; eat chicken soup, shiitake mushrooms, astragalus, codonopsis and ginseng.
Explanation: There is no evidence that those items can prevent COVID-19. Wong Kin-Chung cannot be confirmed as a medical professor, doctor or nutritionist.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese court gave permission to kill 20,000 patients infected with coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence that the Chinese court had ordered to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: Tencent claims that over 24,000 patients have died in China.
Explanation: Screenshots can be manipulated; the number is not confirmed by the government.

What did you fact-check?: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There is no information to prove that China plans to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Sanitizer manufacturer Dettol knew about the new coronavirus before it was reported.
Explanation: Dettol label mentions it kills coronavirus, but does not refer to the current strain. The products have not been tested for the new strain.

What did you fact-check?: 20 million Chinese people convert to Islam after learning that COVID-19 doesn’t affect muslims.
Explanation: COVID-19 affect muslims and doesn't discriminate by religion. There is no evidence of the conversion of 20 million Chinese people to islam.

What did you fact-check?: China has sought to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to control the spread of the virus.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim, which originates from a suspicious website.

What did you fact-check?: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
Explanation: A hoax website, which has been called out multiple times by various fact-checkers for spreading fake news, has published an article without any source of information to claim that China is planning to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows the Biohazard Container Discovery at the American Consulate General in Wuhan.
Explanation: No news was found from the Xinhua news agency or other media related to the findings of the biohazard container.

What did you fact-check?: Weed (cannabis) cures coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese president visits a mosque and says prayers about the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The video was taken in 2016, before the coronavirus was first reported in Wuhan in December 2019.

What did you fact-check?: Research shows that parts of the HIV genetic code have been inserted into the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Researchers from India claim to have found HIV genetic sequences on the novel coronavirus, and speculate that it might indicate the new virus was artificially created. These genetic sequences can be found in many different viruses, including some other strains of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The Dettol disinfectant label says COVID-19 was tested.
Explanation: COVID-19 is a family of viruses.

What did you fact-check?: Xi Jinping visits a mosque for coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is from July 2016.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang had dinner in Wuhan during the epidemic.
Explanation: The photo was taken in 2013 in Sichuan.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows an infected baby with a doctor.
Explanation: Video was uploaded on 1/14/20. There was no reported case at that time. It does not fit the COVID-19 quarantine protocol.

What did you fact-check?: Woman eats bat soup contaminated with coronavirus in China.
Explanation: The video was recorded on the island of Palau, Micronesia in 2016.

What did you fact-check?: WHO calls for isolation of China due to the coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO does not recommend restrictions on travel or trade with China.

What did you fact-check?: The label on Dettol disinfectant spray claims it is proven to “kill coronavirus;” the company knew about the new strain since 2019.
Explanation: The recent outbreak in China is COVID-19. The source of infection, animal host and reservoir are currently unknown.

What did you fact-check?: Ultimo (Italian singer) has coronavirus.
Explanation: As of 2/6/20 in Italy, there are only 2 cases of coronavirus (2 Chinese citizens).

What did you fact-check?: People infected with coronavirus die in the street while doctors travel through the infection zone.
Explanation: The images are from different events. The first photo corresponds to a performance in Germany and the second portrays two doctors caring for Ebola sufferers in Uganda.

What did you fact-check?: Share this post on Facebook, and get free face masks.
Explanation: Taiwan FactCheck Center has shared the post but didn't get any feedback. The post was not deleted or revised.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C stops or slows novel coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Health Impact News, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service
Explanation: There no known cure for coronavirus and no evidence to suggest Vitamin C can treat or prevent it.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was created in a laboratory in Wuhan.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: China is seeking court’s approval to kill all who tested positive with coronavirus.
Explanation: The National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China makes no mention of any such case.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows people behaving abnormally in China due to coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is old and does not show the recent coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has not “hit” Ghana.
Explanation: There are reports of two suspects exhibiting symptoms of the virus, but both men tested negative, according to Dr. Asare, chief executive officer of Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows bats found under the tiles of many roofs in Hubei, China, that were the source of coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was not taken in China. It’s a 2011 video uploaded on 7/5/11 by Miami based Istueta Roofing. The bats were found under the tiles during the process of replacing a roof for a customer.

What did you fact-check?: President Xi Jinping visits Masjid to pray for coronavirus victims.
Explanation: The video is from 2016 and shows Xi Jinping visiting a mosque.

What did you fact-check?: China asks for permission to kill 20,000 infected cases.
Explanation: There is no evidence about this.

What did you fact-check?: Doctors confirm the novel coronavirus may arrive in Brazil through AliExpress packages.
Explanation: Specialists agree it's unlikely that a virus would survive more than a few hours outside a host, on a solid surface.

What did you fact-check?: This is a market in China where bats and snakes were served as food.
Explanation: The market was in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: A case of the novel coronavirus was registered in a hospital in Maranhão, Brazil.
Explanation: It was a different type of coronavirus, HCoV-OC43, which causes regular colds.

What did you fact-check?: A study is linked to coronavirus.
Explanation: The study was linked to filoviruses and had the minimal role of Wuhan virology institute.

What did you fact-check?: There is a case of COVID-19 in Alberta, Canada, on 2/5/20.
Explanation: Authorities deny it.

What did you fact-check?: Tinospora crispa plants can treat COVID-19.
Explanation: Philippine health experts dismiss the claim that tinospora crispa plants can treat novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Boiled garlic water can protect from COVID-19.
Explanation: Health experts refute claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus can be cured with a bowl of garlic water.
Explanation: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory and there is still no cure to the COVID-19 disease.

What did you fact-check?: Several posts say that coronavirus deaths are linked to 5G technology.
Explanation: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. People die because they were infected with the virus SARS-CoV-2.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus found in broiler chicken
Explanation: No evidence proves this claim. The WHO has clarified that meat cooked properly can be consumed.

What did you fact-check?: The health insurance fee in South Korea will increase because of the treatment cost for Chinese patients.
Explanation: The cost of treatment for foreigners will be paid from the state budget, not by insurance companies.

What did you fact-check?: China seeks approval from the court to kill over 20 000 coronavirus patients.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: You can’t transmit the virus to other people if you don’t feel its symptoms.
Explanation: The French health minister corrected this misinformation.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus discovered In broiler chicken.
Explanation: Unrelated images of ailing chickens claim coronavirus has been discovered in broiler chicken.

What did you fact-check?: First case of coronavirus in San Vicente del Raspeig (Alicante, Spain).
Explanation: There has been no case detected in Alicante.

What did you fact-check?: A Bulgarian doctor claims that alcohol helps cure or prevent the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The WHO says an alcohol-based hand sanitizer is recommended. It is a well known fact that there is no cure for the virus.

What did you fact-check?: Confirmed cases of coronavirus have been found in Shaheen Bagh, Delhi.
Explanation: There have been three cases of coronavirus in India as of 2/5/20.

What did you fact-check?: Cow urine cures coronavirus.
Explanation: This claim made by Hindu Mahasabha President Swami Chakrapani is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: “The Simpsons” predicted the new coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The episode referred to a flu from Japan, not China, and one of the photos was manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: Spain’s Health Secretary advises against selling products from China.
Explanation: The Health Secretary has denied making such recommendations.

What did you fact-check?: Rinsing your mouth with salted water will prevent coronavirus infection.
Explanation: A doctor's team has debunked the claim

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is caused by bat soup.
Explanation: There is no evidence that eating bat soup causes coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Farts were recorded by infrared temperature sensors recently installed in airports and train stations to monitor temperatures of passengers amid the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The farts were added digitally.

What did you fact-check?: Health Canada has advised that keeping the throat moist by drinking water can prevent infection.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence from Health Canada to support this claim.

What did you fact-check?: Children under 8 are immune to the novel coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Socila Media and some News Agencies
Explanation: WHO reports indicate children as young as 2 have been infected.

What did you fact-check?: Videos show pigs being buried in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The videos are old and not related to the recent coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
Explanation: The WHO has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties but there is no evidence it can protect people from the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Dettol sanitizer can kill tthe coronavirus. The company knew about the coronavirus back in 2019.
Explanation: The Dettol bottle refers to the previous strains of coronavirus, not COVID-19. The manufacturer cannot confirm levels of effectiveness against the new strain.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has infected broiler chicken.
Explanation: There is no evidence that broiler chicken has been infected with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: “Coronavirus epidemic in Poland.”
Explanation: There is no claim or statement by Polish officials of an epidemic

What did you fact-check?: People from Wuhan can share a laundry room although they are in quarantine.
Explanation: People in Wuhan should clean their clothes in their room, by themselves.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese president visits a mosque to ask Muslims to pray to fight the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video dates back to 2016, when Chinese President Xi Jinping visited a mosque in northwest China.

What did you fact-check?: Macedonian citizens are afraid to order from AliExpress because of coronavirus.
Explanation: According to the Post Office, the coronavirus is not transmitted by packages.

What did you fact-check?: Videos show pigs being buried in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The videos are old and not related to the recent coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Weed, slang for the cannabis plant, can “kill coronavirus.”
Explanation: As of 2/18/20, the WHO said "there is still no specific medicine recommended to prevent or treat" the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese kill their pets due to epidemic anxiety.
Explanation: A photo of a dead dog was verified. There is no evidence of a massive pet killing in China.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The claim that drinking boiled garlic water cures the coronavirus is wrong according to health authorities. International organizations do not recommend the remedy.

What did you fact-check?: When transporting patients, people who wear only a facial mask violate safety measures.
Explanation: They also use ambulances with negative pressure ventilation equipment.

What did you fact-check?: Label on disinfectant says the new coronavirus strain is not new.
Explanation: The disinfectant can only eliminate other types of coronaviruses that are found on hard and non-porous surfaces. It is not effective on the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: There are 40,000 Chinese foreign workers in Morowali quarantined with coronavirus.
Explanation: Only 5,390 foreign workers are employed at the company.

What did you fact-check?:
1. Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visited a mosque and seek protection to the country from coronavirus. 
2. Chinese president Xi Jinping visited a mosque in China after realizing the fact that only Allah can save China from this epidemic.
Explanation: The first video is of former malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi who visited a mosque in China during his visit in 2015. The second video is also an old one, President Xi Jinping paid a visit to the Xincheng Mosque in Yinchuan city, capital of NW China's Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region on Tuesday, July 19, 2016.

What did you fact-check?: When the first group of Japanese evacuated from Wuhan to Tokyo, each evacuee took one ambulance.
Explanation: Among 206 Japanese evacuees being withdrawn from Wuhan on 1/29/20, 199 took seven buses and five took ambulances to the hospital for further examination.

What did you fact-check?: The novel coronavirus contains “pShuttle-SN” sequence, proving laboratory origin.
Who said/posted it?: Alex Jones, Info Wars; Mike Adams, Natural News
Explanation: The pShuttle-SN vector was designed by researchers seeking to develop a potential SARS vaccine. The new coronavirus does not contain a sequence from the pShuttle-SN vector.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows people in China fainting on the street after they were infected with the coronavirus
Explanation: The photo was taken in 2014 in Germany while commemorating Holocaust victims.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese prime minister visits a mosque following the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The man in the video is former Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was shot during his visit to Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque in July 2015.

What did you fact-check?: There is a confirmed case of coronavirus in the Macarthur Region of Australia.
Explanation: This news has not been reported by any news outlets.

What did you fact-check?: A Sri Lankan girl finds a cure for coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no cure for coronavirus yet.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows pigs buried alive.
Explanation: This video is from January 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A Postobon tank in Colombia was infected with coronavirus and all sodas were contaminated.
Explanation: The company and the Ministry of Health deny the infection

What did you fact-check?: Prime Minister of China visited a mosque and realized the only protection from coronavirus is to bow before Allah.
Explanation: The Associated Press archive video was uploaded in 2015 and shows ex-Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi visiting a mosque in China in 2004, not during the coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: “Kochi Prefectural Assembly, who returned from Wuhan, refused the test while it was infected with coronavirus.”
Explanation: No coronavirus infection has been confirmed in Kochi Prefecture, and no tests have been carried out.

What did you fact-check?: Pigs mulled in China are blamed for coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is from the African swine flu outbreak in China in 2018-19.

What did you fact-check?: Broiler chickens were found to have coronavirus in Mumbai.
Explanation: Chickens have not been identified as a source for the coronavirus and the photos are not linked to coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Dettol sanitizer kills coronavirus and the company knew about the existence of the virus before the outbreak in China.
Explanation: Dettol kills older strains of coronavirus but has not been tested on the new strain.

What did you fact-check?: 300.000 people are infected with the new coronavirus in China.
Explanation: The number is lower, according to China.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese prime minister visited a mosque to gain protection for coronavirus.
Explanation: The 2015 video is of the Malaysian Prime minister visiting a mosque in Beijing.

What did you fact-check?: Face masks can be steamed for reuse.
Explanation: Experts warn against it.

What did you fact-check?: COVID-19 comes from rhino horns.
Explanation: The origin is unknown and rhino horns cannot hold any virus.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows a Japanese medical professional providing aid in Wuhan.
Explanation: The photo has circulated in reports about a Japanese medical team traveling to China in 2008.

What did you fact-check?: Sri Lanka has eradicated coronavirus.
Explanation: One patient recovered but experts said it's not enough to mention eradication.

What did you fact-check?: “It is not safe to receive a letter or a package from China.”
Explanation: According to the WHO and other experts, people receiving packages from China are not at risk of contracting the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Zhong Nanshan said saline solution can kill the virus.
Explanation: Several Chinese media outlets and experts say this is false.

What did you fact-check?: There is a person with coronavirus in Huelva on 2/4/20.
Explanation: According to the Spanish Health Ministry, there is just one case of coronavirus in Spain at this time. The image has been manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: There is a person with coronavirus in Galicia on 2/4/20.
Explanation: According to the Spanish Health Ministry, there has been just one case of coronavirus in Spain until now. The image has been manipulated.

What did you fact-check?: A doctor named Leslie Chow discovered the coronavirus and died after contact with coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The photo corresponds with American actor Ken Jeong. The doctor Lin Wenliang was the first to warn of the risk of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A doctor faints during surgery on a coronavirus patient.
Explanation: The video shows a doctor fainting during open heart surgery. It was recorded in a hospital of Zhaotong in Yunnan, China.

What did you fact-check?: We made a Q&A of what we know about the videos of people fainting in the middle of the street.
Photos show coronavirus is found in broiler chicken.
Explanation: The photos are outdated and have nothing to do with the coronavirus. They are about sick chickens.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is not new; there is a vaccine for dogs.
Explanation: The current outbreak was caused by a new strain.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows bat infestation under a tiled roof, the source of coronavirus in Hubei, China.
Explanation: The video is 8 years old and not from China.

What did you fact-check?: A case of novel coronavirus has occurred in Huelva, Spain.
Explanation: As of 2/3/20, there hasn't been any cases of novel coronavirus in Huelva, Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Video from China shows people fleeing from coronavirus quarantine.
Explanation: The video is from an anti-government protest that was posted in December 2019 before the coronavirus quarantine began.

What did you fact-check?: A neighbor of Noia (region of Galicia, Spain) has been infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: The photo has been altered and it has not been published. There has been no new case of coronavirus in Spain.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a family that died from novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was found on the internet since the last week of December 2019. But the first death from the novel coronavirus was not reported until the second week of January 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Video of Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visiting a mosque and offering prayers seeking protection to the country from coronavirus.
Explanation: The man in the video is not Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang. He is former Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was taken in 2015 and shows Badawi visiting Nan Xia Po Mosque in Beijing for Friday prayers.

What did you fact-check?: The novel coronavirus “will not spread” in the Philippines due to the country’s high temperature and relatively high humidity.
Explanation: The World Health Organization (WHO) told Rappler that 2019-nCoV "has spread to countries with both hot and humid climates, as well as cold and dry."

What did you fact-check?: Dettol sanitizer can kill coronavirus. The company knew about the coronavirus in 2019.
Explanation: The coronavirus mentioned on the Dettol bottle is the previous strains of coronavirus, not the 2019 novel coronavirus. Dettol has clarified that it cannot confirm effectiveness against the new strain.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows bats found under the tiles of many roofs in Hubei, China. They were the source of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was not taken in China. It’s a video from 7/5/11 by a Miami based roofing company, Istueta Roofing. The bats in the video were found under the tiles during the process of replacing a roof for a customer in Miami.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has killed 112,000 people and infected 2,800,000 in China.
Explanation: Currently, the coronavirus has killed more than 400 people and infected over 20,000 in China.

What did you fact-check?: Israeli spy Dany Shoham claims the new coronavirus is linked to the Chinese secret program for the production of biological weapons at the Institute of Virology in Wuhan, the epicenter of the infection.
Explanation: On 1/29/20, two credible media outlets denied the claims. Foreign Policy says the Wuhan virus is not a laboratory bio-weapon, stressing that conspiracy theories are spreading faster than the coronavirus itself.

What did you fact-check?: This image is related to the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The image has nothing to do with coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Japan has sent a 1,000-man medical team to Wuhan.
Explanation: Taken on 5/20/08, the image shows a 22-member medical team at Japan’s Narita International Airport before flying to Chengdu city in China, hit by an earthquake.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows domesticated and exotic animals being sold in a wet market in Wuhan, China.
Explanation: The video is a composite of two different clips, one of Langowan Traditional Market and the other of Tomohon Traditional Market, both in Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma gave US$5 million to a Filipino student who developed a vaccine for novel coronavirus.
Explanation: No vaccine has been developed to stop the new coronavirus. Jack Ma's donation to a Filipino student cannot be confirmed.

What did you fact-check?: Chickens cause coronavirus.
Explanation: There has been no confirmation of a link between chickens and the new coronavirus. The WHO has said that it is looking into animal sources.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus can be transmitted through sweat from Chinese canned food factory workers.
Explanation: Transmission of the coronavirus is only possible through close contact and body fluid when sneezing and coughing.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows infected people in China.
Explanation: The photo was taken in 2014 in Frankfurt in memory of Holocaust victims.

What did you fact-check?: A coronavirus victim was secretly cremated.
Explanation: The boxes photographed at Tianhe International Airport in Wuhan contain protective clothing bought by the Zall Foundation to help control the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Study indicates that black tea and Pu’er tea can prevent coronavirus
Explanation: There has been no evidence to suggest that drinking tea has protected people from infection.

What did you fact-check?: According to the Chinese CDC, tea can reduce the risk of contracting coronavirus.
Explanation: Chinese CDC has not published such a study. There is no evidence that tea cures the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus contains HIV “insertions” and shows signs of being created in a lab.
Explanation: This claim from a poorly done study was retracted. There is no evidence that the new virus was bioengineered.

What did you fact-check?: Chlorine dioxide kits sold online under various “MMS” names — Miracle Mineral Solution, Miracle Mineral Supplement, Master Mineral Solution — will cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: MMS does not cure coronavirus infection and can be dangerous.

What did you fact-check?: Vitamin C can “stop” the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence that Vitamin C can stop or treat the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A viral video is depicting the condition in which animals are being stored in the Wuhan market.
Explanation: The market depicted in the video in question is from Indonesia, not China.

What did you fact-check?: There are cases of the news coronavirus in Maturín city.
Explanation: As of February 2, no COVID-19 cases had been reported in Maturín.

What did you fact-check?: Two Italian scientists, named Concetta y Francesca, were the first to isolate the new coronavirus in Europe
Explanation: Those two doctors were not the first ones to isolate the new coronavirus in Europe. The isolation was achieved before them in France, but also in Japan, Australia and China.

What did you fact-check?: 3 preliminary studies that went viral are incorrect.
Explanation: They are three authentic publications, but they were either too preliminary, or social networks overstated their conclusions.

What did you fact-check?: A viral image suggests that cocaine kills coronavirus.
Explanation: According to the WHO, there is no cure for the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The common flu kills 60 times more people than the coronavirus every year.
Explanation: The common flu should not be compared to the coronavirus because influenza is seasonal and predictable with vaccines. The the new coronavirus is still an unknown, but according to current information, it has a higher mortality rate than the flu.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows bats, the main source of the coronavirus, on many roofs in Hubei district.
Explanation: The 8-year-old video from Miami, Florida, is not linked to the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: There is an herbal cure for COVID-19.
Explanation: Health experts in Sri Lanka say there is no evidence asafoetida or other herbal medicines can protect people from infection.

What did you fact-check?: Drinking water will prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: Facebook posts claimed that drinking water will prevent the coronavirus; however, according to health authorities that is wrong

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows people who died from the virus in Frankfurt, Germany.
Explanation: No, this is a 2014 photo of people participating in an art project in Frankfurt, Germany

What did you fact-check?: South Korean presidential Blue House forbids the term “Wuhan pneumonia.”
Explanation: The information was based on guidance from the WHO.

What did you fact-check?: Three photos show coronavirus hospitals In China.
Explanation: The photos are misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Dettol can kill the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The company said coronavirus cannot be eliminated by using its liquid soap.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a doctor fainting in the operating room after being infected with the new coronavirus.
Explanation: According to Chinese media, he fainted after performing surgery for 17 hours.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic soup can cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: According to the WHO, there is no cure for the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a doctor fainting in the operating room after being infected with the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There are no evidences to support that information.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows pigs buried in China because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is a year old; the pigs were buried after the outbreak of African swine flu.

What did you fact-check?:
More than 35 million people in China are now on a travel lockdown. More than 2700 have been sickened, and 81 have died.
Nothing happens without Allah’s permission and He is aware of all things.
Explanation: The shared image is not from China. This image was taken on 14 March 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, where people lay down in a pedestrian zone as part of an art project in remembrance of the 528 victims of the Katzbach Nazi concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a new hospital for coronavirus patients in China.
Explanation: The video has been available on the internet since 2018 and does not show the new hospital for coronavirus patients in China.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists from Australia create the first vaccine for novel coronavirus
Explanation: There is no vaccine for the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates helped fund a patent for coronavirus.
Explanation: The Pirbright Institute said the patents involve infectious bronchitis virus only, and the Gates Foundation did not fund that work.

What did you fact-check?: The Korean Government took every facial mask from factories and sent them to China.
Explanation: Some sellers made this false claim to consumers.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows coronavirus victims in China.
Explanation: The photo from 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese politician Xi Jinping has said that Chinese scientists found a cure for the coronavirus in cow urine.
Explanation: Chinese politician Xi Jinping did not make the statements about cow urine.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a bat-infested roof in Hubei, China, claiming to be the source of the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was shot in Miami, Florida, in 2011.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus can be cured by drinking one bowl of freshly boiled garlic water.
Explanation: There is no known cure for the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows pigs buried in China because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The video is a year old; the pigs were buried after the outbreak of African swine flu.

What did you fact-check?: Pigs are being burned alive in China to control the coronavirus.
Explanation: A year-old viral video is not about the coronavirus in China.

What did you fact-check?: “You’re more likely to die of influenza right now” than the 2019 coronavirus.
Explanation: Based solely on the numbers, you're more likely to die if you get the 2019 coronavirus than if you get the flu. But, as of March 10, the flu is more common in the United States than the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: In a video, the Chinese prime minister offers namaz (prayer) during the coronavirus scare.
Explanation: The 2015 Associated Press video shows the former Malaysian prime minister taking part in Friday prayers in Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque during a five-day trip to China.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic water can cure the new coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no proof that garlic water is a coronavirus cure.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows a Japanese professor who says Taiwan doesn’t need to join the WHO.
Explanation: The man in the photo is Japanese adult video star Shigeo Tokuda.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows the Wuhan market.
Explanation: The video was filmed in Indonesia, not Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: The Wuhan coronavirus was leaked from the Wuhan P4 lab.
Explanation: The claim is speculation and quoted from an outdated study.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus contains “HIV insertions.”
Explanation: This claim is based on a study comparing short protein sequences between the 2019 novel coronavirus and HIV, likely to give false positives. The authors did not check for potential similarities between COVID-19 and other organisms. These short protein sequences were similar to many other organisms, not just HIV.

What did you fact-check?: “The coronavirus was engineered by scientists in a lab.”
Explanation: There is no evidence that the coronavirus was created in a lab.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists “are shocked to discover that weed kills coronavirus.”
Explanation: The CDC reports there is no specific antiviral treatment recommended for the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus is as dangerous as the plague and cholera.
Who said/posted it?: Statment made by Matteo Salvini, italian politician and leader of Lega.
Explanation: At present, this claim cannot be confirmed.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The image is not a photo of the coronavirus; it is graphic rendering.

What did you fact-check?: 27 patients with coronavirus are in a Rome hospital.
Explanation: As of 2/3/20, there are no coronavirus cases at the Umberto I Hospital in Rome.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is in Arezzo, a city in Tuscany, Italy.
Explanation: As of 2/3/20, there are no coronavirus cases in the city of Arezzo.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is in Cecina, a city in Tuscany, Italy.
Explanation: As of 2/3/20, there are no coronavirus cases in the city of Cecina.

What did you fact-check?: Italy is the first European Union country to isolate the coronavirus.
Who said/posted it?: Statment made by Nicola Zingaretti, italian politician and secretary of the Democratic Party
Explanation: France was the first European country to isolate the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A photo of people lying in the street is accompanied by a caption implying they are coronavirus victims in China.
Explanation: The photo taken in 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists claim the Wuhan coronavirus is an HIV-1 engineered “super weapon.”
Explanation: The research cited was not peer-reviewed, and the paper was withdrawn. A note identifies it as a preliminary study.

What did you fact-check?: An image shows Leslie Chow, a doctor who died in China fighting the coronavirus.
Explanation: The image shows actor Ken Jeong; Leslie Chow is one of his characters.

What did you fact-check?: A photo caption reads: “The person in this image came with the Chinese lady who tested positive for coronavirus, fled to avoid medical tests and is reportedly hidden in the Delgoda (Sri Lanka) area.”
Explanation: The photo is of Tharin Gunawardhana, an undergraduate student from the University of Moratuwa and a Sri Lankan national

What did you fact-check?: In the bottle of a specific Dettol product there is a mention on the coronavirus from October of 2019, which means that the company knew about the outbreak before it occurred.
Explanation: The term "coronavirus" does not apply solely to SARS-CoV-2, it describes a group of viruses that share certain traits. One of those viruses is SARS-CoV-2 but its not the only one. Including SARS-CoV-2 there are about 7 more coronaviruses. So the bottle of the disinfectant in question did not predict the emergence of the new coronavirus, it was referencing other coronaviruses that their product can protect against. The company has issued an announcement denouncing the claim that their product is effective against the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: WHO confirmed 50 new cases in Guayaquil, in Ecuador.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: QQ instant messaging announced the real death toll is 25,000.
Explanation: Epidemiologists say that such a high death rate is impossible at this time.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows coronavirus victims lying on the ground.
Explanation: The photo taken in 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: The white side of a surgical mask should be worn on the outside, with the colored side on the inside.
Explanation: The colored side of the surgical mask should be worn on the outside. N95 masks are better than normal surgical masks.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus outbreak is the start of a depopulation program, based on links established by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: The San Marcos 2020 National Fair in Aguascalientes, Mexico, was canceled by the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The San Marcos National Fair, one of the most important and oldest in Mexico, was not cancelled because of the coronavirus; the organizers confirmed.

What did you fact-check?: A post says that WHO has advised against unprotected sex with animals to prevent a coronavirus infection.
Explanation: The image attributed to the World Health Organization was digitally manipulated. The recommendation was never to avoid unprotected contact with wild and farm animals.

What did you fact-check?: “The Simpsons” has predicted the coronavirus since 1993.
Explanation: The episode refers to a virus called the Osaka Flu, transmitted through a factory in Japan. The name of the virus in the video was fabricated.

What did you fact-check?: The religious beliefs of some Macedonian citizens are being used to create panic and misinformation about the new coronavirus by citing Russian texts portraying it as the beginning of a worldwide catastrophe.
Explanation: Totalitarian and authoritarian regimes around the world have often supported the dissemination of prophecy stories that foretell disasters and conspiracy theories as a means of keeping subjects in a state of constant fear. Such stories are often republished because they attract attention.

What did you fact-check?: Biohazard containers found at US consulate in Wuhan
Explanation: The Xinhua News Agency did not publish any photos of the containers , and the material itself is illustrated with a stock photo, on which the characters were placed.

What did you fact-check?: “Scientists found similar sequences in the coronavirus as in HIV.”
Explanation: There is some similarity between the new coronavirus and the proteins of HIV. "Similar sequences can be found in many organisms."

What did you fact-check?: The Taiwanese flag is printed on masks to prevent the Chinese from buying them.
Explanation: Production of masks with the Taiwanese flag started in 2019 and they have no connection to this coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Garlic water prevents the novel coronavirus, according to a Chinese doctor.
Explanation: The WHO has not prescribed any preventive methods for coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: “How to prevent the coronavirus (…) Drink fennel tea twice a day. Fennel tea has the same component as Tamiflu medicine, used to treat H1N1”.
Explanation: Fennel tea doesn't has the same component as Tamiflu and Tamiflu is not recommended by WHO to treat the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: “How to prevent the coronavirus: Drink fennel tea twice a day. Fennel tea has the same component as Tamiflu medicine, used to treat H1N1”.
Explanation: Fennel tea does not have the same component as Tamiflu. Tamiflu is not recommended by WHO to treat the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Boiled ginger can cure the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Health experts say there is no scientific evidence boiled ginger cures the coronavirus. The WHO advises those with symptoms to seek medical care and avoid home remedies.

What did you fact-check?: A U.S. soldier stationed in Lithuania is the first confirmed case of coronavirus in the country.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: The new coronavirus is artificial. The virus affects predominantly the “Mongoloid race”.
Explanation: The new coronavirus has a natural origin. Anyone can contract it regardless of race.

What did you fact-check?: The WHO confirmed 50 new cases in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on 2/2/20.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows a man travelling alone on a plane to China.
Explanation: The photo shows an Egyptian man returning to Egypt from China, not traveling to Beijing.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows coronavirus victims in China.
Explanation: The photo taken in 2014 shows people lying down in a pedestrian zone in Frankfurt, Germany, as part of an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: The novel coronavirus can be cured by one bowl of freshly boiled garlic.
Explanation: The WHO has issued a clarification that garlic may have some antimicrobial properties, but there is no evidence that it can protect people from the novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus arrived in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Explanation: The coronavirus has not arrived in the Balkan region.The story is about a man from Serbia who is in quarantine in India.

What did you fact-check?: “When using a medical mask, you’re supposed to wear the white side out when you’re not sick.”
Explanation: Global health agencies and medical mask producers agree that the colored side of the mask should always be worn on the outside.

What did you fact-check?: The homeopathic drug Arsenicum Album 30 can prevent coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that Arsenicum Album 30 can prevent coronavirus. The WHO does not list any medications that can prevent infections.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus responsible for COVID-19 is a mix of SARS and HIV.
Explanation: The coronavirus is not a mix of HIV and SARS, although some symptoms may be similar.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows a medical team of 1,000 sent by Japan to Wuhan.
Explanation: The photo was taken in May 2008 when a medical team from Japan helped China recover from the Sichuan earthquake.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a doctor falling down because of the coronavirus.
Explanation: The doctor in the outdated video was on the floor because a patient's relative punched him in the face.

What did you fact-check?: The Gates Foundation was the real agent behind the pandemic.
Explanation: A simulation the Gates Foundation funded was based on another coronavirus in the same family.

What did you fact-check?: A coronavirus case was confirmed in the Istanbul Medical School Hospital.
Explanation: A patient was isolated in the hospital but not diagnosed. There is no confirmed case in Turkey.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus can be transmitted through free Fire Game and Xiaomi mobile phones.
Explanation: The coronavirus cannot be transmitted through inanimate objects.

What did you fact-check?: There are 5 coronavirus Suspect Patients in Indonesia, one of whom died.
Explanation: Video of a simulation activity of handling the Wuhan coronavirus at RSUP Dr. Kariadi, Semarang on January 30, 2020 ago.

What did you fact-check?: The novel coronavirus is not a new virus.
Explanation: Many coronavirus strains have already been discovered, and new strains regularly emerge from mutations.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is “a military bio-weapon developed by China’s Army.”
Explanation: There is no evidence that the Chinese military developed COVID-19 as a bioweapon.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows the newly built hospital in Wuhan.
Explanation: The photo from the internet depicts a modular apartment building.

What did you fact-check?: A video caption said: “Doctor affected by the virus in a hospital in Wuhan, China.”
Explanation: In previous instances of the video, captions confirmed by media experts said the doctor collapsed in Yunnan province because of overwork and hypoglycemia.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus “arrived” in Cúcuta, Colombia.
Who said/posted it?: Luis Guillermo Vélez in his column for La República
Explanation: A column not clearly labeled as satirical led readers to believe there were confirmed cases of coronavirus in Colombia's largest city bordering Venezuela.

What did you fact-check?: Facts about coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: An FAQ on the recent coronavirus outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows dead people on the streets of China.
Explanation: Taken in 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, the photo shows victims of a Nazi concentration camp and has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic.

What did you fact-check?: Charles Lieber, a Harvard University professor who was arrested, had a connection to the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Charles Lieber, a nanoscientist, was charged with lying about participating in a Chinese recruitment program and his affiliation with a Chinese university. He has no connection to the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A dry throat make you more vulnerable to be infected by coronavirus.
Explanation: Already fact-checked by Maldita.es, but they found it said Spain instead of Canada.

What did you fact-check?: A bowl of garlic cures “Wuhan’s coronavirus.”
Explanation: Health authorities have not recommended garlic as a cure.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus is unknown and kills in seconds.
Explanation: The coronavirus is not unknown and does not kill in a few seconds.The WHO says the virus is part of a family of viruses that includes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV). Also, fatality and severity of the disease may be determined by age and other pre-existing health conditions.

What did you fact-check?: China builds a hospital for coronavirus patients in 48 hours.
Explanation: It is an extension of Huanggang Central Hospital, scheduled to open in May 2020. A dedicated work force made the empty building into a fully operational hospital within two days, which was mistaken as the Huoshenshan Hospital proposed to be constructed in six days. Huoshenshan Hospital is still under construction and expected to open to patients on Feb. 3, 2020.

What did you fact-check?: Photos show part of Huoshenshan Hospital in Wuhan, built in five days.
Explanation: The building is the medical center Dabie Mountain, reconfigured to accommodate coronavirus patients and located in Huanggang, 46 miles from Wuhan.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus 2019-nCoV was patented in the past and is human-made, a project in which the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation is involved.
Explanation: "The patent mentioned in the articles in question is about the development of a vaccine for the IBV virus which belongs in a sub-family of the wider category of viruses termed coronaviruses. In short the patent was not for the coronavirus 2019-nCoV."

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is a “virus weapon” as lethal as Ebola. Everyone who is infected dies.
Explanation: A Washington Times article does not provide evidence of this. According to the CDC, the source of the new coronavirus is likely wildlife. The mortality rate is 2-3%. Most fatalities are the elderly or those with underlying conditions.

What did you fact-check?: A video showing where “the coronavirus began” was made in Wuhan.
Explanation: The video was made in Langowan, Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows corpses strewn about in China due to the coronavirus.
Explanation: Taken in 2014 in Frankfurt, Germany, the photo shows people lying in a pedestrian zone for an art project remembering the Katzbach concentration camp victims.

What did you fact-check?: Fennel tea can cure the coronavirus.
Explanation: Doctors are not saying fennel tea can kill the coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese spies stole the coronavirus from a Canadian lab.
Explanation: This has been confused with the investigation of a Chinese scientist in Canada in 2019.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows a new hospital in Wuhan.
Explanation: The photo shows the Tangiers Hospital in Algeria.

What did you fact-check?: Singapore closed a subway station after a case of COVID-19.
Explanation: Singapore authorities denied the subway station closed because of COVID-19.

What did you fact-check?: Punjab authorities have advised citizens not to eat goat meat for 60 days.
Explanation: Pakistani officials deny they issued a warning about the dangers of eating goat meat.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus isn’t new because “Lysol has it listed as one of the viruses it kills.”
Explanation: Lysol says some of its surface cleaning products, including its disinfectant spray, have been effective against viruses “similar to” the 2019 novel coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: A team of medical trainees from JKUAT (a university in Kenya) have developed and tested a vaccine successfully.
Explanation: The university has denied the claim. Additionally, a doctor contacted by PesaCheck has indicated that a vaccine cannot be developed within a month.

What did you fact-check?: There is a link between the COVID-19 and irregular migration.
Who said/posted it?: Statment made by Matteo Salvini, italian politician and leader of Lega. The statment was published on official Salvini's Facebook, Twitter and Instagram account.
Explanation: There is no connection between the spread of COVID-19 and the irregular migration in the Mediterranean Sea.

What did you fact-check?: China builds a hospital for coronavirus patients in 48 hours.
Explanation: The building has been under construction since 2018. China has added 1.000 beds for new coronavirus patients.

What did you fact-check?: An institute funded by Bill Gates will contribute to 65 million deaths in the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The healthcare work by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has not contributed to the spread of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: The Canadian Department of Health issues an emergency notification asking people to drink warm water.
Explanation: The notification was not issued by the Canadian Department of Health.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows a market in the Chinese city of Wuhan, where the deadly coronavirus strain emerged.
Explanation: The video shows a market on Indonesia’s Sulawesi island.

What did you fact-check?: Over 1,500 people have died from the new coronavirus (Jan. 31)
Explanation: As of Jan. 31, the coronavirus death toll is 213.

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus was called a “plague” by the WHO; 2.9 million were infected and 950,680 died.
Explanation: A global emergency was declared by the WHO. As of 1/31/20, 213 people have died from the coronavirus and 9,800 cases have been confirmed in mainland China. Cases have been discovered in more than a dozen countries.

What did you fact-check?: A container of soda in Colombia was infected with the coronavirus.
Explanation: There is no evidence the soda was contaminated.

What did you fact-check?: “2019-nCoV is old and there is already a cure to it”
Explanation: Although human coronavirus was first discovered in the 60s, the current 2019-nCoV outbreak was first identified recently.

What did you fact-check?: Scientists and experts answer questions and rumors about the coronavirus (bat soup, Wuhan P4 Laboratory, patented virus, people collapsing, etc).
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: franceinfo hosted a chat with a scientist in order to answer questions about the coronavirus, including fake news
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: The coronavirus is enabled by 5G technology.
Explanation: There is no scientific proof that the coronavirus is linked to 5G technology.

What did you fact-check?: A video of an Indonesian traditional market is being used to depict Wuhan, China.
Explanation: A video shot in July 2019 in Indonesia is being used to falsely depict a market in Wuhan, China, where the coronavirus originated.

What did you fact-check?: Fennel tea is a cure against the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The fact that the fennel tea is infused with the same substance of the Tamiflu remedy, people assumed it could kill the coronavirus. Experts deny, however, this relationship between fennel and the drug, which, in turn, is not indicated for the treatment of coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: The “proper” way to wear a surgical mask is blue side out if you are sick and white side out if you do not want to be infected by the virus.
Who said/posted it?: City of Manila Vice Mayor Honey Lacuna
Explanation: The World Health Organization, the Philippine Red Cross, the Philippine Department of Health, the San Francisco Department of Public Health

What did you fact-check?: Doctors recommend Vitamin C and fennel seed tea to warn off the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Corpses of coronavirus victims are scattered on a street in Wuhan, China.
Explanation: Taken on 3/24/14, the photo shows people lying in a pedestrian zone for an art project remembering victims of the Katzbach concentration camp.

What did you fact-check?: A video shows the new hospital set up in China for coronavirus patients.
Explanation: The video is found to exist on the internet since at least 2018.

What did you fact-check?: Bill Gates predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: The Bill Gates Foundation did particiapte in a pandemic drill, but it was based on another virus model and another epidemic from years ago.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus outbreak attributed to an advisory from India’s Health Ministry.
Explanation: The notification is falsely attributed to India's Health Ministry.

What did you fact-check?: A coronavirus vaccine was patented in 2004.
Explanation: Several IFCN members have confirmed the patent was for SARS.

What did you fact-check?: A video indicates one case of the coronavirus infects another 14 people.
Explanation: It's not clear the video indicates the infection rate and according to the WHO, the rate is lower than this claim.

What did you fact-check?: A photo shows coronavirus victims lying in the streets in China.
Explanation: The photo is an art project created in Frankfurt, Germany, on 3/24/14 to commemorate the victims of the Nazi concentration camp in Katzbach.

What did you fact-check?: People who have ACE2, especially those with hypertension, are easily infected with COVID-19.
Explanation: The information is from a commercial ad featuring false health information.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was discovered by Ali Mohamed Zaki in 2012.
Explanation: The coronavirus discovered by Zaki is the MERS-CoV type, not COVID-19, which was first reported in Wuhan, China, not in Saudi Arabia.

What did you fact-check?: Dr. Kuo Yen-Jen of Taiwan suggested smearing sesame oil into the nostril can prevent flu and COVID-19.
Explanation: There is no evidence that smearing sesame oil into the nostril prevents coronavirus infection. To date, there is no treatment recommended for it.

What did you fact-check?: Environmental enzymes can prevent COVID-19. Use them to wash vegetables, wash your mouth, nostrils and hands.
Explanation: This claim comes from a commercial ad with false health information.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus was created in a lab in order to destroy the Chinese economy. A vaccine is already available.
Explanation: There is no evidence to support these facts.

What did you fact-check?: It’s not a virus but 5G that is causing disease and deaths
Explanation: The deaths from COVID-19 have nothing to do with 5G.

What did you fact-check?: Mélange Of Unrelated Videos From China Shared Misleadingly In Context To Recent Corona Virus Outbreak.
Explanation: A mix of different unrelated videos from China have been merged to create this misleading video shared in context to coronavirus. People infected by coronavirus 2019-nCoV, do not exhibit the symptoms such as howling like dogs and biting as shown in the video.

What did you fact-check?: Manir Hossain, a 23-year-old man from India’s Tripura, died in a hospital in Malaysia due to the new coronavirus.
Explanation: Upon our investigation, we this to be false. An Indian citizen from Tripura did not die due to the new coronavirus in Malaysia. The reason for his death was Status Epilepticus Secondary Meningoencephalitis.

What did you fact-check?: We did a Q&A on the facts about the coronavirus.
Explanation: Q&A on the facts about the coronavirus

What did you fact-check?: The Canadian Ministry of Health issued a press release indicating the states in which they are taking security measures to combat the coronavirus 2019-nCoV.
Who said/posted it?: Posts on various social media pages and accounts
Explanation: The Canadian Health Ministry didn't issue such statement. The security measures mentioned are incorrect.

What did you fact-check?: Gates Foundation has funded the development of the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The article was based on a false connection of facts concerning the Gates Foundation and the Pirbright Institute which resulted in a misleading context and, ultimately, in a disinformative article.

What did you fact-check?: In Japan, “It’s the Democratic party’s fault that health insurance system is abused by foreigners”
Explanation: According to Japan Tourism Agency, this information is false.

What did you fact-check?: “Tokyo Olympic Games 2020 will be canceled because of coronavirus.”
Explanation: According to The Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, this information is false.

What did you fact-check?: The Canadian Department of Health issued an emergency notification recommending that people keep their throats moist to protect from the novel coronavirus.
Explanation: The bulletin is false and there is no scientific evidence that shows that drinking water prevents against coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: 4,600 Chinese arrived to Hakata Port, in Japan.
Explanation: According to Hakata-city, this information is misleading.

What did you fact-check?: Chinese pet owners are killing their cats and dogs by throwing them out of the window, in fear of their pets spreading the coronavirus. This comes after memos were issued by authorities for pet owners to get rid of their animals.
Explanation: The pet killings happened within the context of the Chinese local authorities issuing real memos that ordered citizens to get rid of their pets and the dissemination of the misinformation about the transmission of the coronavirus 2019-nCoV, but we cannot verify that the motivation of the owners of the animals has been related to the disease outbreak.

What did you fact-check?: Video of Wuhan market where the new coronavirus started to spread.
Explanation: This videos is not from China, but from Indonesia.

What did you fact-check?: Photo of several people lying on the ground in the middle of the street, allegedly in China.
Explanation: The photo was taken in Frankfurt, Germany, in 2014.

What did you fact-check?: Authors of a tabletop exercise in Oct 2019 predicted that Wuhan coronavirus might kill 65 million people.
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: WHO told people to avoid sex with live animals.
Explanation: The image has been altered and the real text reads

What did you fact-check?: A video of a girl collapsing in a store because she was affected by coronavirus.
Explanation: The incident took place in Malaysia and the girl has been identified as Nur Izzah Izzati. Malaysia’s Health Ministry also confirmed that the claim attached to the video is fake.

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a parasite being removed for someone’s lips, sharing it in relation with coronavirus.
Explanation: The video was uploaded on YouTube on October 24, 2019 with the title “Amazing Botfly Removal on Lips”.

What did you fact-check?: Spanish Health Department has released a notification about the new coronavirus.
Explanation: The Spanish health department did not issue that notification.

What did you fact-check?: The biological research laboratory Ruilan Bao Hu San Biotech Limited in Shanghai, the city where #coronarvirus originated, has a logo like that of the Umbrella Corporation of RESIDENT EVIL and corona is an anagram for Racoon. WTF
Explanation: There are no proofs of the relation between the Chinese company RLSW and coronavirus, neither that Shanghai is the place where it all started. Moreover the anagram of the word "corona" is not the same as Raccoon, the name of the city where takes place the video game Resident Evil.

What did you fact-check?: Coronavirus has killed over 10,000 people (Jan. 30)
Explanation: The latest report from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control says there are currently 170 deaths related to the new coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Romania developed a coronavirus vaccine able to cure white people only.
Explanation: There is no known cure for the coronavirus. This is a hoax.

What did you fact-check?: Five foods that help you avoid the coronavirus
Explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

What did you fact-check?: Video shows a plate of bat soup that allegedly started the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: There is yet no confirmation regarding the exact cause of the new coronavirus outbreak, although some scientists agree that bats can be (and have been in other occasions) carriers of coronavirus.

What did you fact-check?: Video of a woman eating bat soup and its relation with the coronavirus outbreak.
Explanation: There is yet no confirmation regarding the exact cause of the outbreak. Also, the video was filmed in Palau in 2016, so there is no relation with the current coronavirus in China.

What did you fact-check?: Novel coronavirus is commuicated by package or imported goods shipping from China to Korea.
Explanation: Currently there is no evidence to support transmission of novel coronavirus by imported goods. Also there have not been such cases in Korea.

What did you fact-check?: The Chinese government announced on official document “Garlic is a preventive food for Novel coronavirus.”
Explanation: The official document is not from China's central government. It's from Shanghai city government. On this original document, there is no mention about garlic or preventive food.

What did you fact-check?: According to a certain document, there are infected cases in some areas of South Korea, but the Korean government is hiding the cases. (Jan. 30)
Explanation: The documents are confirmed as crafted documents. These case are under investigation by Korean police.

What did you fact-check?: According to a certain document, there are infected cases in some areas of South Korea, but the Korean government is hiding the cases.
Explanation: The documents are confirmed as crafted documents. These case are under investigation by Korean police.

What did you fact-check?: “Some Japanese people infected with the novel coronavirus were refused from a charter flight from Wuhan to Tokyo (on Jan.30) without any Japanese legal basis.”
Explanation: It is true that two Japanese people who may have been infected could not take a charter flight. They were not permitted to go through the Chinese immigration office because they were stuck at the quarantine station by Chinese medical staff. Japan didn't refuse them.

What did you fact-check?: Two ways of wearing a surgical mask: Colored side out if you are sick and white side out if you do not want to become sick.
